James had foregone the services of another secretarial service.
reasoning_samples: To establish an enforceable contract, James must prove that there was a valid offer, acceptance, and consideration. The conversation between Professor James and Mary Digit suggests that there may be a contract. James's statement to bring the manuscript to Mary Digit can be considered a promise to type the manuscript, which is a valid consideration. When Mary Digit responded with 'Wouldn't that be nice', it could be inferred as an acceptance of James's offer. Therefore, the fact that 'When' and 'Wouldn't that be nice' implied a promise to type the manuscript (A) would be most helpful in an action by James against X-L because it directly addresses the elements of a contract, specifically the offer and acceptance.

question: In 1%7 Owen held Blackacre, a tract of land. in fee simple absolute. In that year he executed and delivered to Price a quitclaim deed which purported to release and quitclaim to Price all of the right, title and interest of Owen in Blackacre. Price accepted the quitclaim and placed the deed in his safety deposit box. Owen was indebted to Crider in the amount of S35,000. In September. 1971, Owen executed and delivered to Crider a warranty deed, purporting to convey the fee simple to Blackacre, in exchange for a full release of the debt he owed to Crider. Crider immediately recorded his deed. In December, 1971, Price caused his quitclaim deed to Blackacre to be recorded and notified Crider that he (Price) claimed title. Assume that there is no evidence of occupancy of Blackacre and assume, further, that the jurisdiction where Blackacre is situated has a recording statute which requires good faith and value as elements of the junior claimant's priority. Which of the following is the best comment concerning the conflicting claims of Price and Crider?
choices: Price cannot succeed, because the quitclaim through which he claims prevents him from being bona fide (in good faith).
The outcome will turn on the view taken as to whether Crider paid value within the meaning of the statute requiring this element.
The outcome will turn on whether Price paid value (a fact not given in the statement).
Price's failure to record until December, 1971, estops him from asserting title against Crider.
reasoning_samples: The recording statute requires good faith and value as elements of the junior claimant's priority. A quitclaim deed, by its nature, does not convey any title or interest in the property, but rather releases any rights the grantor may have. Therefore, Price's quitclaim deed does not provide him with good faith title to the property, as he is aware that Owen may still have an interest in the property. This lack of good faith title prevents Price from being a junior claimant with priority over Crider's deed, making option A the best comment concerning the conflicting claims of Price and Crider.

question: Davis decided to kill Adams. He set out for Adams' house. Before he got there he saw Brooks, who resembled Adams. Thinking Brooks was Adams, Davis shot at Brooks. The shot missed Brooks but wounded Case, who was some distance away. Davis had not seen Case. In a prosecution under a statute that proscribes attempt to commit murder, the district attorney should indicate that the intended victim(s) was (were)
choices: Adams only
Brooks only
Case only
Adams and Brooks
reasoning_samples: The correct answer is A because Davis' intention was to kill Adams, not Brooks. Although Davis thought Brooks was Adams, his actual intention was solely directed at Adams. Therefore, the district attorney should indicate that the intended victim was Adams only. This is in line with the principle that a defendant's intent is determined by what he actually intended, not what he mistakenly believed. In this scenario, Davis' action was an attempt to commit murder against Adams, which is the intended target.

question: A state statute requires any person licensed to sell prescription drugs to file with the State Board of Health a report listing the types and amounts of such drugs sold if his sales of such drugs exceed $50,000 during a calendar year. The statute makes it a misdemeanor to "knowingly fail to file" such a report. Nelson, who is licensed to sell prescription drugs, sold $63,000 worth of prescription drugs during 1976 but did not file the report. Charged with committing the misdemeanor, Nelson testifies that he did a very poor job of keeping records and did not realize that his sales of prescription drugs had exceeded $50,000. If the jury believes Nelson, he should be found
choices: guilty, because this is a public welfare offense
guilty, because he cannot be excused on the basis of his own failure to keep proper records
not guilty, because the statute punishes omissions and he was not given fair warning of his duty to act
not guilty, because he was not aware of the value of the drugs he had sold
reasoning_samples: This is a public welfare offense, which is a type of crime that is intended to protect the public from harm. The statute in question is designed to ensure that the State Board of Health has accurate information about the sale of prescription drugs, which is essential for public health and safety. Public welfare offenses typically do not require a mens rea (guilty mind) element, and the defendant's lack of knowledge or intent is not a defense. In this case, Nelson's failure to file the report, even if unintentional, still poses a risk to public health and safety, and he should be held accountable for his actions. Therefore, the correct answer is A, guilty, because this is a public welfare offense.

question: Lender met Borrower on the street, demanded that Borrower pay a debt owed to Lender, and threatened to punch Borrower in the nose. A fight ensued between them. Mann came upon the scene just as Lender was about to kick Borrower in the head. Noting that Lender was getting the better of the fight, Mann pointed a gun at Lender and said, "Stop, or I'll shoot." If Lender asserts a claim against Mann based on assault, will Lender prevail?
choices: Yes, because Mann threatened to use deadly force.
Yes, unless Mann was related to Borrower.
No, if it was apparent that Lender was about to inflict serious bodily harm upon Borrower.
No, because Lender was the original aggressor by threatening Borrower with a battery.
reasoning_samples: Mann's use of deadly force in threatening to shoot Lender constitutes an unlawful act of self-defense. The use of deadly force is only justification for the use of force when there is an imminent threat of death or serious bodily harm. In this scenario, Lender is not in imminent danger of death or serious bodily harm, as Mann is merely threatening to shoot Lender to stop the fight. Therefore, Mann's actions are not justified, and Lender can prevail on his claim of assault against Mann. Option A is the best answer because it accurately reflects the applicable legal principle regarding the use of deadly force in self-defense.

question: Peter sued Don for breach of contract. The court admitted testimony by Peter that Don and his wife quarreled frequently, a fact of no consequence to the lawsuit. Don seeks to testify in response that he and his wife never quarreled. The court
choices: must permit Don to answer if he had objected to Peter's testimony
may permit Don to answer, whether or not he had objected to Peter's testimony
may permit Don to answer only if he had objected to Peter's testimony
cannot permit Don to answer, whether or not he had objected to Peter's testimony
reasoning_samples: The court admitted testimony by Peter that Don and his wife quarreled frequently, which is a fact of no consequence to the lawsuit. However, Don seeks to testify in response that he and his wife never quarreled, which is a direct response to Peter's testimony. Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, if a party introduces evidence on a matter, the other party may introduce evidence to rebut or meet the introduced evidence. Since Peter's testimony was admitted, Don has the right to respond to it. Therefore, the court must permit Don to answer if he had objected to Peter's testimony, as it is a direct response to the admitted testimony.

question: The requirement that candidates for licenses must be graduates of barber schools in Aurora is probably
prompt: The State of Aurora requires licenses of persons "who are engaged in the trade of barbering." It will grant such licenses only to those who are graduates of barber schools located in Aurora, who have resided in the state for two years, and who are citizens of the United States.
choices: unconstitutional as an undue burden on interstate commerce
unconstitutional as a violation of the privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
constitutional, because the state does not know the quality of out-of-state barber schools
constitutional, because barbering is a privilege and not a right
reasoning_samples: This requirement is a restriction on interstate commerce because it limits the availability of licenses to graduates of barber schools located in Aurora, effectively discriminating against out-of-state schools. By doing so, it creates an undue burden on interstate commerce, as it prevents individuals from other states from obtaining the same licenses. This restriction may be seen as a barrier to trade between the states, which is prohibited by the Commerce Clause of the US Constitution. Therefore, this requirement is probably unconstitutional as an undue burden on interstate commerce.

question: The requirement that candidates for licenses must be citizens is
prompt: The State of Aurora requires licenses of persons "who are engaged in the trade of barbering." It will grant such licenses only to those who are graduates of barber schools located in Aurora, who have resided in the state for two years, and who are citizens of the United States.
choices: constitutional as an effort to ensure that barbers speak English adequately
constitutional as an exercise of the state's police power
unconstitutional as a bill of attainder
unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection
reasoning_samples: The requirement that candidates for licenses must be citizens is constitutional as an exercise of the state's police power. The state has a legitimate interest in ensuring that its barbers are able to communicate effectively with its citizens, particularly in a profession that involves providing personal services. The state's requirement that barbers be citizens is a reasonable means of achieving this goal, as it is likely that citizens will have a higher proficiency in English. This is a classic example of a state exercising its police power to protect the health, safety, and welfare of its citizens. The state's requirement is not a denial of equal protection, as it is not based on a suspect classification such as race or national origin. Nor is it a bill of attainder, as it does not impose punishment on a specific individual or group. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

question: Assume that a resident of the state of Aurora was denied a license because she had been graduated from an out-of-state barber school. Her suit in federal court to enjoin denial of the license on this ground would be
prompt: The State of Aurora requires licenses of persons "who are engaged in the trade of barbering." It will grant such licenses only to those who are graduates of barber schools located in Aurora, who have resided in the state for two years, and who are citizens of the United States.
choices: dismissed, because there is no diversity of citizenship
dismissed because of the abstention doctrine
decided on the merits, because federal jurisdiction extends to controversies between two states
decided on the merits, because a federal question is involved
reasoning_samples: The suit is between a resident of the state of Aurora and the state of Aurora itself. Since the plaintiff and the defendant are citizens of the same state, there is no diversity of citizenship. Therefore, the federal court lacks subject matter jurisdiction over the suit, and it must be dismissed. This is in accordance with 28 U.S.C. ยง 1332, which requires diversity jurisdiction to be based on the citizenship of the parties in different states.

question: Which of the following is the strongest ground on which to challenge the requirement that candidates for barber licenses must have been residents of the state for at least two years?
prompt: The State of Aurora requires licenses of persons "who are engaged in the trade of barbering." It will grant such licenses only to those who are graduates of barber schools located in Aurora, who have resided in the state for two years, and who are citizens of the United States.
choices: The privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
The due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
The equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
The obligation of contracts clause
reasoning_samples: The privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment is the strongest ground to challenge the requirement that candidates for barber licenses must have been residents of the state for at least two years. According to the clause, no state shall 'deny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws.' If the state is denying licenses to individuals who have not been residents of Aurora for two years, it is essentially preventing them from engaging in the trade of barbering, which is a fundamental right protected by the privileges and immunities clause. This requirement creates a discriminatory barrier for individuals who are citizens of the United States but have not lived in the state for two years. The clause aims to ensure that no state unfairly denies equal opportunities to its citizens, which is precisely what is happening here. Therefore, the privileges and immunities clause provides the strongest ground to challenge the residency requirement for barber licenses.

question: John was fired from his job. Too proud to apply for unemployment benefits, he used his savings to feed his family. When one of his children became ill, he did not seek medical attention for the child at a state clinic because he did not want to accept what he regarded as charity. Eventually, weakened by malnutrition, the child died as a result of the illness. John has committed
choices: murder
involuntary manslaughter
voluntary manslaughter
no form of criminal homicide
reasoning_samples: John did not intentionally or recklessly cause the death of his child. While his actions may have been negligent, they do not fall under the categories of involuntary or voluntary manslaughter. Murder requires a specific intent, which is not present in this case. Therefore, no form of criminal homicide is the best answer.

question: If Carr asserts a claim against the students who washed his car, his best theory is
prompt: Professor Merrill, in a lecture in her psychology course at a private university, described an experiment in which a group of college students in a neighboring city rushed out and washed cars stopped at traffic lights during the rush hour. She described how people reacted differently-with shock, joy, and surprise. At the conclusion of her report, she said, "You understand, of course, that you are not to undertake this or any other experiment unless you first clear with me." Four of Merrill's students decided to try the same experiment but did not clear with Merrill. One subject of their experiment, Carr, said, "I was shocked. There were two people on each side of the car. At first I thought negatively. I thought they were going to attack me and thought of driving away. Then I quieted down and decided there were too many dirty cars in the city anyway." Charitable immunity has been abolished in the jurisdiction.
choices: assault
negligence
invasion of privacy
false imprisonment
reasoning_samples: Carr's best theory is assault because he was subjected to a sudden and unexpected physical contact (the washing of his car) that was intended to or had the effect of causing him apprehension of immediate harmful or offensive contact. The students' actions, although not intended to be malicious, were sufficient to cause Carr to fear for his safety. This meets the elements of an assault claim. Negligence (B) is not the best theory because the students' actions were not merely careless or reckless, but rather intentional. Invasion of privacy (C) is not applicable because there is no indication that the students invaded Carr's private affairs or conversations. False imprisonment (D) is not the best theory because Carr was not confined or restrained in any way.

question: If Carr has a valid claim against the students, will he also prevail against the university?
prompt: Professor Merrill, in a lecture in her psychology course at a private university, described an experiment in which a group of college students in a neighboring city rushed out and washed cars stopped at traffic lights during the rush hour. She described how people reacted differently-with shock, joy, and surprise. At the conclusion of her report, she said, "You understand, of course, that you are not to undertake this or any other experiment unless you first clear with me." Four of Merrill's students decided to try the same experiment but did not clear with Merrill. One subject of their experiment, Carr, said, "I was shocked. There were two people on each side of the car. At first I thought negatively. I thought they were going to attack me and thought of driving away. Then I quieted down and decided there were too many dirty cars in the city anyway." Charitable immunity has been abolished in the jurisdiction.
choices: Yes, if the students would not have performed the experiment but for Merrill's lecture.
Yes, if Carr's claim against the students is based on negligence.
No, because the students were not Merrill's employees.
No, because Merrill did not authorize the car wash as a class project.
reasoning_samples: Carr's claim against the students is based on the students' negligence in performing the car wash experiment without clearing it with Professor Merrill. The key issue here is whether the students would have performed the experiment but for Merrill's lecture. If they would not have, then Merrill's lecture can be seen as the proximate cause of the harm to Carr. This is an application of the 'but for' test, which is used to determine causation in tort law. Since the students' actions were a direct result of Merrill's lecture, the university can be held vicariously liable for the students' negligence. Therefore, if Carr has a valid claim against the students, he will also prevail against the university.

question: Oxnard owned Goldacre, a tract of land, in fee simple. At a time when Goldacre was in the adverse possession of Amos, Eric obtained the oral permission of Oxnard to use as a road or driveway a portion of Goldacre to reach adjoining land, Twin Pines, which Eric owned in fee simple. Thereafter, during all times relevant to this problem, Eric used this road across Goldacre regularly for ingress and egress between Twin Pines and a public highway. Amos quit possession of Goldacre before acquiring title by adverse possession. Without any further communication between Oxnard and Eric, Eric continued to use the road for a total period, from the time he first began to use it, sufficient to acquire an easement by prescription. Oxnard then blocked the road and refused to permit its continued use. Eric brought suit to determine his right to continue use of the road. Eric should
choices: win, because his user was adverse to Amos and once adverse it continued adverse until some affirmative showing of a change
win, because Eric made no attempt to renew permission after Amos quit possession of Goldacre
lose, because his user was with permission
lose, because there is no evidence that he continued adverse user for the required period after Amos quit possession
reasoning_samples: Eric's user of the road was initially with permission from Oxnard. However, once the user became adverse to Amos (who was in adverse possession of Goldacre), it continued to be adverse until Eric acquired an easement by prescription, which he did. Since Eric's user was adverse to Amos and not to Oxnard, Oxnard's subsequent refusal to permit continued use does not affect Eric's rights. Therefore, Eric should win because his user was adverse to Amos and once adverse, it continued adverse until some affirmative showing of a change. This is in line with the law of adverse possession, where a possessor's use becomes permanent and hostile, and continues until the possessor acquires title by prescription.

question: In an appropriate action to determine the respective interests of Sharon and Stanley in Greenacre, if Stanley is adjudged to be the owner of the northerly ten acres of Greenacre, the most likely reason for the judgment will be that
prompt: A brother and sister, Bruce and Sharon, acquired as joint tenants a twenty-acre parcel of land called Greenacre. They contributed equally to the purchase price. Several years later, Bruce proposed that they build an apartment development on Greenacre. Sharon rejected the proposal but orally agreed with Bruce that Bruce could go ahead on his own on the northerly half of Greenacre and Sharon could do what she wished with the southerly half of Greenacre. Bruce proceeded to build an apartment development on, and generally developed and improved, the northerly ten acres of Greenacre. Sharon orally permitted the southerly ten acres of Greenacre to be used by the Audubon Society as a nature preserve. Bruce died, leaving his entire estate to his son, Stanley. The will named Sharon as executrix of his will, but she refused so to serve.
choices: the close blood relationship between Sharon and Bruce removes the necessity to comply with the Statute of Frauds
Sharon's conduct during Bruce's lifetime estops her from asserting title to the northerly half of Greenacre
the joint tenancy was terminated by the oral agreement of Sharon and Bruce at the time it was made
Sharon had a fiduciary obligation to her nephew Stanley by reason of her being named executrix of Bruce's will
reasoning_samples: The joint tenancy was terminated by the oral agreement of Sharon and Bruce at the time it was made. This is because a joint tenancy can be severed by an oral agreement between the joint tenants, as long as the agreement is made with the intent to sever the joint tenancy. In this case, Sharon and Bruce orally agreed to divide the land between them, which would have the effect of terminating the joint tenancy. This agreement was made at the time it was made, and not later, so it would be effective to terminate the joint tenancy. Therefore, if Stanley is adjudged to be the owner of the northerly ten acres of Greenacre, the most likely reason for the judgment will be that the joint tenancy was terminated by the oral agreement of Sharon and Bruce at the time it was made.

question: In an appropriate action to determine the respective interests of Sharon and Stanley in Greenacre, if Sharon is adjudged to be the owner of all of Greenacre, the most likely reason for the judgment will be that
prompt: A brother and sister, Bruce and Sharon, acquired as joint tenants a twenty-acre parcel of land called Greenacre. They contributed equally to the purchase price. Several years later, Bruce proposed that they build an apartment development on Greenacre. Sharon rejected the proposal but orally agreed with Bruce that Bruce could go ahead on his own on the northerly half of Greenacre and Sharon could do what she wished with the southerly half of Greenacre. Bruce proceeded to build an apartment development on, and generally developed and improved, the northerly ten acres of Greenacre. Sharon orally permitted the southerly ten acres of Greenacre to be used by the Audubon Society as a nature preserve. Bruce died, leaving his entire estate to his son, Stanley. The will named Sharon as executrix of his will, but she refused so to serve.
choices: the Statute of Frauds prevents the proof of Sharon's oral agreement
Bruce could not unilaterally sever the joint tenancy
Sharon's nomination as executrix of Bruce's estate does not prevent her from asserting her claim against Stanley
the record title of the joint tenancy in Greenacre can be changed only by a duly recorded instrument
reasoning_samples: The Statute of Frauds requires that any agreement that cannot be performed within one year must be in writing to be enforceable. In this case, Sharon and Bruce's oral agreement to sever the joint tenancy and allow each to develop their respective halves of Greenacre cannot be performed within one year, as it would take several years to develop the land. Therefore, the Statute of Frauds prevents the proof of Sharon's oral agreement, making her the sole owner of Greenacre. This is the most likely reason for the judgment.

question: Mary Webb, a physician, called as a witness by the defendant in the case of Parr v. Doan, was asked to testify to statements mTd by Michael Zadok, her patient, for the purpose of obtaining treatment from Dr. Webb. Which of the following is the best basis for excluding evidence of Zadok's statements in a jurisdiction with a doctor-patient privilege?
choices: An objection by Dr. Webb asserting her privilege against disclosure of confidential communications made by a patient
An objection by Parr's attorney on the grounds of the doctor -patient privilege
A finding by the trial judge that Zadok had left the office without actually receiving trearment
The assertion of a privilege by Zadok's attorney, present at the trial as a spectator at Zadok 's request, and allowed by the trial judge to speak
reasoning_samples: The doctor-patient privilege is a confidential communication privilege that protects the confidentiality of communications between a patient and their physician. In this scenario, Dr. Webb is the physician and the holder of the privilege. Since the statements made by Zadok were for the purpose of obtaining treatment from Dr. Webb, they are confidential communications protected by the doctor-patient privilege. Therefore, the best basis for excluding evidence of Zadok's statements is an objection by Dr. Webb asserting her privilege against disclosure of confidential communications made by a patient. This is because Dr. Webb has a personal interest in maintaining the confidentiality of her patient's communications, and it is her privilege that is being asserted.

question: A leading question is LEAST likely to be permitted over objection when
choices: asked on cross -examination of an expert witness
asked on direct examination of a young child
asked on direct examination of a disinterested eyewitness
related to preliminary matters such as the name or occupation of the witness
reasoning_samples: A leading question is a question that suggests its own answer. While leading questions are generally not permitted over objection, there are certain exceptions. Preliminary matters, such as the name or occupation of the witness, are typically considered non-substantive and are allowed to be established through leading questions. This is because the primary goal of establishing these facts is to facilitate the witness's testimony, rather than to elicit substantive evidence. In contrast, leading questions on direct examination of a witness, especially an expert witness or a disinterested eyewitness, are generally not permitted over objection as they can be seen as suggestive and potentially misleading. Similarly, leading questions on cross-examination of an expert witness may be subject to objection if they are seen as attempting to impeach the witness's credibility or expertise. Therefore, the least likely scenario in which a leading question would be permitted over objection is when it relates to preliminary matters such as the name or occupation of the witness.

question: If Tom asserts a claim against Passer for damages for his injuries, will Tom prevail?
prompt:
Passer was driving his pickup truck along a lonely
road on a very cold night. Passer saw Tom, who was
a stranger, lying in a field by the side of the road and
apparently injured. Passer stopped his truck, alighted,
and, upon examining Tom, discovered that Tom was
intoxicated and in danger of suffering from exposure
to the cold. However, Passer returned to his truck
and drove away without making any effort to help Tom.
Tom remained lying at the same place and was
later injured when struck by a car driven by
Traveler. Traveler, who was drowsy and inattentive,
had veered off the road into the field and hit Tom.
Traveler did not see Tom prior to hitting him.
choices: Yes, because by stopping and examining Tom, Passer assumed a duty to aid him.
Yes, if a reasonably prudent person under the circumstances would have aided Tom.
No, if Passer did not, in any way, make Tom's situation worse.
No, because Tom himself created the risk of harm by becoming intoxicated.
reasoning_samples: When Passer stopped his truck, alighted, and examined Tom, he assumed a duty to aid Tom. This is because by taking these actions, Passer took on a level of responsibility for Tom's well-being. By examining Tom and determining that he was intoxicated and in danger, Passer became aware of the risk of harm that Tom faced. However, instead of taking action to mitigate that risk, Passer chose to abandon Tom and drive away. This failure to act after assuming a duty to aid Tom constitutes a breach of that duty. As a result, Passer's actions (or lack thereof) directly contributed to Tom's injuries, making Passer liable for damages. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

question: If Tom asserts a claim against Traveler, will Tom prevail?
prompt:
Passer was driving his pickup truck along a lonely
road on a very cold night. Passer saw Tom, who was
a stranger, lying in a field by the side of the road and
apparently injured. Passer stopped his truck, alighted,
and, upon examining Tom, discovered that Tom was
intoxicated and in danger of suffering from exposure
to the cold. However, Passer returned to his truck
and drove away without making any effort to help Tom.
Tom remained lying at the same place and was
later injured when struck by a car driven by
Traveler. Traveler, who was drowsy and inattentive,
had veered off the road into the field and hit Tom.
Traveler did not see Tom prior to hitting him.
choices: Yes, because Traveler was negligent in going off the road.
Yes, because Tom was in a helpless condition.
No, because Traveler did not see Tom before Tom was struck.
No, because Tom's intoxication was the cause in fact of his harm.
reasoning_samples: Tom's claim against Traveler is based on the theory of negligence. To prevail, Tom must show that Traveler's actions (or lack thereof) were the cause in fact of Tom's harm. In this case, Traveler's negligence in veering off the road and hitting Tom is the direct cause of Tom's harm. Although Traveler did not see Tom before hitting him, this is not a defense to the claim, as Traveler's negligence in driving off the road is still the cause of the harm. Tom's intoxication and helpless condition are not relevant to determining whether Traveler was negligent. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as Traveler's negligence in going off the road is the cause in fact of Tom's harm.

question: Roofer entered into a written contract with Orissa to repair the roof of Orissa's home, the repairs to be done "in a workmanlike manner." Roofer completed the repairs and took all of his equipment away, with the exception of a 20-foot extension ladder, which was left against the side of the house. He intended to come back and get the ladder the next morning. At that time, Orissa and her family were away on a trip. During the night, a thief, using the ladder to gain access to an upstairs window, entered the house and stole some valuable jewels. Orissa has asserted a claim against Roofer for damages for the loss of the jewels. In her claim against Roofer, Orissa will
choices: prevail, because by leaving the ladder Roofer became a trespasser on Orissa's property
prevail, because by leaving the ladder Roofer created the risk that a person might unlawfully enter the house
not prevail, because the act of the thief was a superseding cause
not prevail, because Orissa's claim is limited to damages for breach of contract
reasoning_samples: Orissa's claim against Roofer is based on the theory of negligence per se, which arises when a defendant's breach of a duty owed to the plaintiff results in harm to the plaintiff. In this case, Roofer's duty to Orissa was to exercise reasonable care in the performance of his contract. By leaving the ladder against the house, Roofer breached this duty, creating a foreseeable risk that a person might use the ladder to gain access to the house. The fact that the ladder was used by a thief does not break the chain of causation, as the risk of a person using the ladder was foreseeable and within the scope of the duty that Roofer owed to Orissa. Therefore, Orissa will prevail because by leaving the ladder, Roofer became a trespasser on Orissa's property, which is a breach of his duty to exercise reasonable care.

question: Homer and Purcell entered into a valid, enforceable written contract by which Homer agreed to sell and Purcell agreed to purchase Blackacre, which was Homer 's residence. One of the contract provisions was that after the closing Homer had the right to remain in residence at Blackacre for up to 30 days before delivering possession to Purcell. The closing took place as scheduled. Title passed to Purcell and Homer remained in possession. Within a few days after the closing, the new house next door which was being constructed for Homer was burned to the ground, and at the end of the 30-day period Homer refused to move out of Blackacre; instead, Homer tendered to Purcell a monthly rental payment in excess of the fair rental value of Blackacre. Purcell rejected the proposal and that day brought an appropriate action to gain immediate possession of Blackacre. The contract was silent as to the consequences of Homer 's failure to give up possession within the 30-day period, and the jurisdiction in which Blackacre is located has no statute dealing directly with this situation, although the landlord-tenant law of the jurisdiction requires a landlord to give a tenant 30 days notice before a tenant may be evicted. Purcell did not give Homer any such 30-day statutory notice. Purcell's best legal argument in support of his action to gain immediate possession is that Homer is a
choices: trespasser ab initio
licensee
tenant at sufferance
tenant from month to month
reasoning_samples: Homer's initial possession of Blackacre was lawful as a result of the contract between him and Purcell. However, after the 30-day period expired, Homer's continued possession became unlawful. Since the contract was silent as to the consequences of Homer's failure to vacate, we must look to the jurisdiction's landlord-tenant law for guidance. The landlord-tenant law requires a landlord to give a tenant 30 days' notice before eviction, but this does not apply to Homer's situation because he is not a tenant in the classical sense. Instead, Homer's continued possession is akin to a tenant at sufferance, who holds possession without a lease or a valid contract. A tenant at sufferance is a type of tenant who holds possession without a lease or a valid contract, and is generally required to vacate the premises upon demand. In this case, Purcell's demand for immediate possession is reasonable, and Homer's refusal to vacate constitutes a trespass. Therefore, Homer is a tenant at sufferance, and Purcell's best legal argument is that Homer is a tenant at sufferance.

question: Which of the following is Bertha's best legal theory?
prompt: Albert engaged Bertha, an inexperienced actress, to do a small role in a new Broadway-play for a period of six months at a salary of $200 a week. Bertha turned down another role in order to accept this engagement. On the third day of the run, Bertha was hospitalized with influenza and Helen was hired to do the part. A week later, Bertha recovered, but Albert refused to accept her services for the remainder of the contract period. Bertha then brought an action against Albert for breach of contract.
choices: Her acting contract with Albert was legally severable into weekly units.
Her performance of the literal terms of the contract was physically impossible.
Her reliance on the engagement with Albert by declining another acting role created an estoppel against Albert.
Her failure to perform for one week was not a material failure so as to discharge Albert's duty to perform.
reasoning_samples: Bertha's best legal theory is that her acting contract with Albert was legally severable into weekly units. This is because the contract specified a weekly salary, indicating that each week's performance was a separate obligation. Bertha's failure to perform for one week does not necessarily mean she breached the entire contract. The doctrine of severability allows a court to determine whether a breach of a single term in a contract is material enough to discharge the entire contract. In this case, Bertha's failure to perform for one week may not be considered material, especially since she was hospitalized and unable to perform due to illness. Therefore, Albert's refusal to accept her services for the remainder of the contract period may be seen as an unjustified termination, and Bertha's best legal theory is that the contract was severable into weekly units.

question: Which of the following, if true, would adversely affect Bertha's rights in her action against Albert?
prompt: Albert engaged Bertha, an inexperienced actress, to do a small role in a new Broadway-play for a period of six months at a salary of $200 a week. Bertha turned down another role in order to accept this engagement. On the third day of the run, Bertha was hospitalized with influenza and Helen was hired to do the part. A week later, Bertha recovered, but Albert refused to accept her services for the remainder of the contract period. Bertha then brought an action against Albert for breach of contract.
choices: Albert could not find any substitute except Helen, who demanded a contract for a minimum of six months if she was to perform at all.
Helen, by general acclaim, was much better in the role than Bertha had been.
Albert had offered Bertha a position as Helen's understudy at a salary of $100 a week, which Bertha declined.
Albert had offered Bertha a secretarial position at a salary of $300 a week, which Bertha declined.
reasoning_samples: Bertha's claim for breach of contract is based on Albert's refusal to accept her services for the remainder of the contract period. However, if Albert could not find any substitute except Helen, who demanded a contract for a minimum of six months, this would indicate that Albert had a legitimate business reason for not accepting Bertha's services. This is because Bertha's contract was for six months, and if Albert could not find a suitable substitute, it would be reasonable for him to not accept Bertha's services for the remainder of the contract period. This would be a defense to Bertha's claim for breach of contract, and would adversely affect her rights in her action against Albert.

question: Park sued Dent for breach of an oral contract which Dent denied making. Weston testified that he heard Dent make the contract on July 7. Dent discredited Weston, and Park offers evidence of Weston's good reputation for truthfulness. The rehabilitation is most likely to be permitted if the discrediting evidence by Dent was testimony that
choices: Weston had been promoting highly speculative stocks
Weston had been Park's college roommate
Weston had attended a school for mentally retarded children
Weston had been out of town the whole week of July 4-10
reasoning_samples: The rehabilitation of Weston's good reputation for truthfulness is most likely to be permitted if the discrediting evidence by Dent was testimony that Weston had been promoting highly speculative stocks. This is because promoting speculative stocks can be seen as a character trait that may be relevant to his credibility as a witness. If the jury believes that Weston's promotion of speculative stocks indicates a propensity for dishonesty, then his good reputation for truthfulness may be less trustworthy. Therefore, the rehabilitation of Weston's reputation will be most relevant in this scenario, and the court is likely to permit the evidence.

question: In order to establish a breach of the standard of care owed to her by Abel and Baker, Client
prompt: Lawyers Abel and Baker are the members of the law partnership of Abel and Baker in a small town that has only one other lawyer in it. Abel and Baker do a substantial amount of personal injury work. Client was severely and permanently injured in an automobile collision when struck by an automobile driven by Motorist. Client employed the Abel and Baker firm to represent her in obtaining damages for her injuries. At the time Client employed Abel and Baker, the statute of limitations had six weeks to run on her claim. The complaint was prepared but not filed. Abel and Baker each thought chat the other would file the complaint. The statute of limitations ran on Client's claim against Motorist. Client has filed suit against Abel and Baker for negligence. That case is on trial with a jury in a court of general jurisdiction.
choices: must have a legal expert from the same locality testify that defendants' conduct was a breach
must have a legal expert from the same state testify that defendants' conduct was a breach
can rely on the application of the jurors' common knowledge as to whether there was a breach
can rely on the judge, as an expert in the law, to advise the jury whether there was a breach
reasoning_samples: To establish a breach of the standard of care owed to her by Abel and Baker, Client must prove that their conduct fell below the standard of care expected of a reasonable attorney. In a negligence action against an attorney, the standard of care is typically established through expert testimony. A legal expert from the same locality (or at least with knowledge of the local practice) is best positioned to testify as to whether Abel and Baker's conduct was a breach of the standard of care. This is because the standard of care for attorneys can vary by jurisdiction, and a local expert can provide insight into the specific practices and customs of the local bar. Options B, C, and D are incorrect because they do not provide the necessary expertise to establish the standard of care for attorneys in this jurisdiction.

question: In addition to proving that Abel and Baker were negligent, Client must establish, as a minimum, that she
prompt: Lawyers Abel and Baker are the members of the law partnership of Abel and Baker in a small town that has only one other lawyer in it. Abel and Baker do a substantial amount of personal injury work. Client was severely and permanently injured in an automobile collision when struck by an automobile driven by Motorist. Client employed the Abel and Baker firm to represent her in obtaining damages for her injuries. At the time Client employed Abel and Baker, the statute of limitations had six weeks to run on her claim. The complaint was prepared but not filed. Abel and Baker each thought chat the other would file the complaint. The statute of limitations ran on Client's claim against Motorist. Client has filed suit against Abel and Baker for negligence. That case is on trial with a jury in a court of general jurisdiction.
choices: would have, but for her lawyers' negligence, recovered from Motorist
had a good faith claim against Motorist that was lost by her lawyers' negligence
was severely and permanently injured when struck by Motorist's automobile
did not negligently contribute to the failure to have the complaint filed
reasoning_samples: To establish a claim for negligence against her lawyers, Client must show that she suffered harm as a result of their breach of duty. In this case, the harm is the loss of her claim against Motorist due to the statute of limitations running. To establish causation, Client must show that but for her lawyers' negligence, she would have recovered from Motorist. This is because the lawyers' negligence prevented the filing of the complaint, which was the necessary step to pursue her claim. Without the complaint being filed, Client's claim against Motorist was lost. Therefore, Client must establish that she would have, but for her lawyers' negligence, recovered from Motorist.

question: A state statute divides murder into degrees. First degree murder is defined as murder with premeditation and deliberation or a homicide in the commission of arson, rape, robbery, burglary or kidnapping. Second degree murder is all other murder at common law. In which of the following situations is Defendant most likely to be guilty of first degree murder?
choices: Immediately after being insulted by Robert, Defendant takes a knife and stabs and kills Robert.
Angered over having been struck by Sam, Defendant buys rat poison and puts it in Sam's coffee. Sam drinks the coffee and dies as a result.
Intending to injure Fred, Defendant lies in wait and, as Fred comes by, Defendant strikes him with a broom handle. As a result of the blow, Fred dies.
Defendant, highly intoxicated, discovers a revolver on a table. He picks it up, points it at Alice, and pulls the trigger. The gun discharges, and Alice is killed.
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, the defendant buys rat poison and puts it in Sam's coffee, intending to kill Sam. This shows deliberation and premeditation, which are key elements in first-degree murder. The defendant's actions demonstrate an intent to kill and a thoughtful, calculated approach, which aligns with the definition of first-degree murder. The actions in the other options do not demonstrate the same level of premeditation and deliberation.

question: On a camping trip in a state park, Rose discovered metal signs near a rubbish heap stating, "Natural Wildlife Area-No Hunting." She took two of the signs and used them to decorate her room at home. She is charged with violation of a state statute which provides, "Any person who appropriates to his own use property owned by the state shall be guilty of a crime and shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000, or by imprisonment for not more than five years, or by both such fine and imprisonment." At trial, Rose admits taking the signs but says she believedI they had been thrown away. In fact, the signs had not been abandoned. Rose should be found
choices: guilty, because this is a public welfare offense
guilty, because she should have inquired whether the signs were abandoned
not guilty if the jury finds she honestly believed the signs had been abandoned
not guilty unless the jury finds that the state had taken adequate steps to inform the public that the signs had not been abandoned
reasoning_samples: Rose is charged with appropriating property owned by the state, which is a crime under the statute. The fact that she believed the signs had been thrown away is irrelevant to the question of whether she 'appropriated' them. The key issue is whether she took the signs for her own use, which she did. The fact that the signs were not abandoned does not change the fact that she took them. This is a public welfare offense, which is a type of crime that is intended to protect the public interest. The statute does not require the state to prove that Rose knew the signs were not abandoned, only that she took them for her own use. Therefore, Rose should be found guilty.

question: Ted frequently visited Janet, his next-door neighbor. Janet was separated from her husband, Howard. Howard resided with his mother but jointly owned the house in which Janet resided. Late one night, Teo and Janet were sitting on the bed in Janet's bedroom drinking when Howard burst through the door and told Ted, "Get out I" When Ted refused, Howard challenged him to go outside and "fight it out." Ted again refused. Howard then pulled a knife from his pocket and lunged at Ted. Ted grabbed a lamp, struck Howard on the head, and killed him. Ted is charged with murder. On a charge of murder, Ted should be found
choices: not guilty, because Ted had as much right as Howard to be in the house
not guilty, because Howard attacked Ted with a deadly weapon
guilty, because Ted's presence in Janet's bedroom prompted Howard's attack
guilty, because Ted's failure to obey Howard's order to leave the house made him a trespasser
reasoning_samples: Ted's presence in Janet's bedroom was lawful as a guest. Howard's attack on Ted was unlawful, and Ted's use of force to defend himself was justified. The fact that Ted was a trespasser in the sense that he was not a joint owner of the house does not negate his right to be in the house as a guest. Therefore, Ted had the right to be in the house and was not guilty of murder.

question: Assume for this question only that Pete has announced his intention of erecting a fast food restaurant on the ten-acre tract and that Sarah has filed an action to enjoin Pete. If Sarah wins, it will be because
prompt: In 1970, Oscar, owner of a 100-acre tract, prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." Oscar published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to-acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. Oscar sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." Sarah was one of the original purchasers from Oscar. In 1976, Oscar sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to Max by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. Max sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to Pete. None of the deeds from Max referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes.
choices: Sarah has an equitable servitude concerning the use of the tract
Sarah, as a taxpayer, has a legal interest in the use of the tract
Sarah is a creditor beneficiary of Oscar's promise with respect to the tract
Pete is not a bona fide purchaser
reasoning_samples: The restriction on mobile homes was not contained in any of the deeds from Max, but it was contained in the deeds from Oscar to the original purchasers, including Sarah. This restriction is an equitable servitude, which is a promise that runs with the land. Equitable servitudes are created when a grantor conveys land with a restriction that limits the use of the land, and the restriction is intended to be binding on future grantees. In this case, the restriction on mobile homes was intended to be binding on future grantees, as evidenced by the fact that it was included in the deeds from Oscar to the original purchasers. Since the restriction was not contained in any of the deeds from Max, it is not a legal servitude, which would be created by a statute or a court order. Therefore, the restriction is an equitable servitude, and Sarah has a right to enforce it against Pete, who is a subsequent grantee of the land.

question: Assume for this question only that Joe, who purchased his lot from Max, has placed a mobile home on it and that Sarah brings an action against Joe to force him to remove it. The result of this action will be in favor of
prompt: In 1970, Oscar, owner of a 100-acre tract, prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." Oscar published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to-acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. Oscar sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." Sarah was one of the original purchasers from Oscar. In 1976, Oscar sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to Max by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. Max sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to Pete. None of the deeds from Max referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes.
choices: Sarah. because the restrictive covenant in her deed runs with the land
Sarah, because the presence of the mobile home may adversely affect the market value of her land
Joe, because his deed did not contain the restrictive covenant
Joe, because he is not a direct but a remote grantee of Oscar
reasoning_samples: The restrictive covenant in the deed from Oscar to Sarah is a negative easement that limits the use of her land to exclude mobile homes. To be enforceable, this type of covenant must meet the elements of a valid negative easement, including: (i) intent to create an easement, (ii) a clear and unambiguous description of the restriction, and (iii) the burden (in this case, the restriction on mobile homes) must touch and concern the land in question. In this case, the restrictive covenant in Sarah's deed has all three elements. Furthermore, the covenant must be recorded and referred to in the deeds to subsequent purchasers to be deemed to 'run with the land.' As such, the covenant in Sarah's deed is a valid and enforceable negative easement that binds all subsequent owners of the land, and Joe is bound by this covenant even though his deed does not contain it. Therefore, the result of this action will be in favor of Sarah.

question: Assume for this question only that in 1977 the school board of the district in which Happy Acres is situated has voted to erect a new school on the ten-acre tract. In an appropriate action between the school board and Pete to determine title, the result will be in favor of
prompt: In 1970, Oscar, owner of a 100-acre tract, prepared and duly recorded a subdivision plan called Happy Acres. The plan showed 90 one-acre lots and a ten-acre tract in the center that was designated "Future Public School." Oscar published and distributed a brochure promoting Happy Acres which emphasized the proximity of the lots to the school property and indicated potential tax savings "because the school district will not have to expend tax money to-acquire this property." There is no specific statute concerning the dedication of school sites. Oscar sold 50 of the lots to individual purchasers. Each deed referred to the recorded plan and also contained the following clause: "No mobile home shall be erected on any lot within Happy Acres." Sarah was one of the original purchasers from Oscar. In 1976, Oscar sold the remaining 40 lots and the ten-acre tract to Max by a deed which referred to the plan and contained the restriction relating to mobile homes. Max sold the 40 lots to individual purchasers and the ten-acre tract to Pete. None of the deeds from Max referred to the plan or contained any reference to mobile homes.
choices: Pete, because the school board has been guilty of laches
Pete, because his deed did not refer to the subdivision plan
the school board, because Pete had constructive notice of the proposed use of the tract
the school board, because there has been a dedication and acceptance of the tract
reasoning_samples: The key to this question lies in the concept of dedication and acceptance. A dedication is a voluntary transfer of land to a public entity for a public purpose. In this case, Oscar's actions in preparing and recording the subdivision plan, publishing a brochure, and including the 'Future Public School' designation on the plan, can be seen as a dedication of the ten-acre tract to the school board for the purpose of building a school. The school board's subsequent vote to erect a new school on the tract can be seen as an acceptance of the dedication. Since the school board has accepted the dedication, they have a valid claim to the land, and Pete's title is subject to this dedication. Therefore, the correct answer is D, because there has been a dedication and acceptance of the tract.

question: In an action by Quincy against Byer for $25,000, which of the following is (are) correct? I. Byer could successfully raise the Statute of Frauds as a defense because the ByerZeller agreement was to answer for the debt of another. II. Byer could successfully raise the Statute of Frauds as a defense because the ByerZeller agreement was for the sale of an interest in land.
prompt: On March 1, Zeller orally agreed to sell his land, Homestead, to Byer for $46,000 to be paid on March 31. Byer orally agreed to pay $25,000 of the purchase price to Quincy in satisfaction of a debt which Zeller said he had promised to pay Quincy. On March 10, Byer dictated the agreement to his secretary but omitted all reference to the payment of the $25,000 to Quincy. In typing the agreement, the secretary mistakenly typed in $45,000 rather than $46,000 as the purchase price. Neither Byer nor Zeller carefully read the writing before signing it on March 15. Neither noticed the error in price and neither raised any question concerning omission of the payment to Quincy.
choices: I only
II only
Both I and II
Neither I nor II
reasoning_samples: The Statute of Frauds requires that agreements for the sale of an interest in land be in writing and signed by the party to be charged. However, the Statute of Frauds does not apply to promises to answer for the debt of another. In this case, Byer orally agreed to pay $25,000 to Quincy in satisfaction of a debt which Zeller said he had promised to pay Quincy. This is a promise to answer for the debt of another, which is not subject to the Statute of Frauds. Therefore, option I is incorrect. Additionally, the Statute of Frauds does apply to agreements for the sale of an interest in land, but the agreement between Byer and Zeller was not fully written down until March 15, and the writing did not accurately reflect the oral agreement. However, Byer and Zeller both signed the writing without noticing the error, which may be considered a ratification of the writing. Therefore, option II is also incorrect.

question: Which of the following would be most important deciding an action by Quincy against Byer for $25,000 ?
prompt: On March 1, Zeller orally agreed to sell his land, Homestead, to Byer for $46,000 to be paid on March 31. Byer orally agreed to pay $25,000 of the purchase price to Quincy in satisfaction of a debt which Zeller said he had promised to pay Quincy. On March 10, Byer dictated the agreement to his secretary but omitted all reference to the payment of the $25,000 to Quincy. In typing the agreement, the secretary mistakenly typed in $45,000 rather than $46,000 as the purchase price. Neither Byer nor Zeller carefully read the writing before signing it on March 15. Neither noticed the error in price and neither raised any question concerning omission of the payment to Quincy.
choices: Whether the Byer-Zeller agreement was completely integrated
Whether Byer was negligent in not having carefully read the written agreement
Whether Zeller was negligent in not having carefully read the written agreement
Whether Quincy was a party to the contract
reasoning_samples: The most important factor in deciding an action by Quincy against Byer for $25,000 is whether the Byer-Zeller agreement was completely integrated. If the Byer-Zeller agreement is found to be completely integrated, then any prior oral agreements, including the one to pay $25,000 to Quincy, would be merged into the written agreement and would be superseded by the written terms. Since the written agreement does not mention the payment to Quincy, this would likely result in the oral agreement being unenforceable. Therefore, determining whether the Byer-Zeller agreement is completely integrated is crucial in deciding Quincy's action against Byer.

question: In an action by Quincy against Byer for $25,000, which of the following, if proved, would best serve Byer as a defense?
prompt: On March 1, Zeller orally agreed to sell his land, Homestead, to Byer for $46,000 to be paid on March 31. Byer orally agreed to pay $25,000 of the purchase price to Quincy in satisfaction of a debt which Zeller said he had promised to pay Quincy. On March 10, Byer dictated the agreement to his secretary but omitted all reference to the payment of the $25,000 to Quincy. In typing the agreement, the secretary mistakenly typed in $45,000 rather than $46,000 as the purchase price. Neither Byer nor Zeller carefully read the writing before signing it on March 15. Neither noticed the error in price and neither raised any question concerning omission of the payment to Quincy.
choices: There was no consideration to Support Zeller's antecedent promise to pay Quincy the $25,000
On March 5, before Quincy was aware of the oral agreement between Zeller and Byer, Zeller agreed with Byer not to pay any part of the purchase price to Quincy.
Whatever action Quincy may have had against Zeller was barred by the statute of limitations prior to March 1.
Before he instituted his action against Byer, Quincy had not notified either Byer or Zeller that he had accepted the Byer-Zeller arrangement for paying Quincy.
reasoning_samples: The oral agreement between Zeller and Byer on March 1 is an enforceable contract. However, for Byer to be obligated to pay Quincy $25,000, there must be consideration to support Zeller's antecedent promise to pay Quincy. In this case, the consideration is the promise by Byer to pay $46,000 for the land. If Byer's promise to pay $46,000 is not supported by consideration, then Zeller's promise to pay Quincy $25,000 is also not supported by consideration. Therefore, if proved, option A would best serve Byer as a defense, as it would render the entire agreement between Zeller and Byer unenforceable, and thus Byer would not be obligated to pay Quincy $25,000.

question: If Byer refused to pay more than $45,000 for Homestead, in an action by Zeller against Byer for an additional $1,000, it would be to Zeller's advantage to try to prove that
prompt: On March 1, Zeller orally agreed to sell his land, Homestead, to Byer for $46,000 to be paid on March 31. Byer orally agreed to pay $25,000 of the purchase price to Quincy in satisfaction of a debt which Zeller said he had promised to pay Quincy. On March 10, Byer dictated the agreement to his secretary but omitted all reference to the payment of the $25,000 to Quincy. In typing the agreement, the secretary mistakenly typed in $45,000 rather than $46,000 as the purchase price. Neither Byer nor Zeller carefully read the writing before signing it on March 15. Neither noticed the error in price and neither raised any question concerning omission of the payment to Quincy.
choices: the writing was intended only as a sham
the writing was only a partial integration
there was a mistake in integration
there was a misunderstanding between Zeller and Byer concerning the purchase price
reasoning_samples: To prove that there was a mistake in integration would be to Zeller's advantage because it would allow him to introduce parol evidence to correct the mistake in the writing. The writing was intended to be a complete and final expression of the agreement between Zeller and Byer, but due to the secretary's error, it incorrectly stated the purchase price as $45,000 instead of $46,000. If Zeller can prove that there was a mistake in integration, he can introduce extrinsic evidence to show that the parties intended for the purchase price to be $46,000, not $45,000. This would allow him to recover the additional $1,000 that Byer owes him.

question: The theory on which Driver is most likely to prevail against House is that House is
prompt: House owns his home in City. On the lawn in front of his home and within five feet of the public sidewalk, there was a large tree. The roots of the tree caused the sidewalk to buckle severely and become dangerous. An ordinance of City requires adjacent landowners to keep sidewalks in safe condition. House engaged Contractor to repair the sidewalk, leaving it to Contractor to decide how the repair should be made. Contractor dug up the sidewalk, cut back the roots of the tree, and laid a new sidewalk. Two days after House had paid Contractor the agreed price of the repair, the tree fell over onto the street and damaged a parked car belonging to Driver. Driver has asserted claims against House and Contractor, and both defendants admit that cutting the roots caused the tree to fall.
choices: strictly liable, because the tree was on his property
liable for Contractor's negligence if, to House's knowledge, Contractor was engaged in a hazardous activity
liable, because he assumed responsibility when he paid Contractor for the repair
liable on the basis of respondeat superior
reasoning_samples: Driver is most likely to prevail against House on the theory of strict liability because the tree was on House's property and its roots caused damage to the sidewalk. Strict liability applies to landowners for injuries caused by a condition on their property, even if the landowner was not negligent. The fact that House hired a contractor to repair the sidewalk does not change the fact that the tree was on his property and its roots caused the damage. House's payment to the contractor does not imply that he assumed responsibility for the contractor's actions, and respondeat superior does not apply because the contractor was not House's employee. Therefore, the best answer is A.

question: In the claim of Driver against Contractor, the best defense of Contractor is that
prompt: House owns his home in City. On the lawn in front of his home and within five feet of the public sidewalk, there was a large tree. The roots of the tree caused the sidewalk to buckle severely and become dangerous. An ordinance of City requires adjacent landowners to keep sidewalks in safe condition. House engaged Contractor to repair the sidewalk, leaving it to Contractor to decide how the repair should be made. Contractor dug up the sidewalk, cut back the roots of the tree, and laid a new sidewalk. Two days after House had paid Contractor the agreed price of the repair, the tree fell over onto the street and damaged a parked car belonging to Driver. Driver has asserted claims against House and Contractor, and both defendants admit that cutting the roots caused the tree to fall.
choices: the tree was on the property of House
he repaired the sidewalk at the direction of House
he could not reasonably foresee that the tree would fall
he was relieved of liability when House paid for the repair
reasoning_samples: Contractor's best defense is that he could not reasonably foresee that the tree would fall. This is because Contractor was hired by House to repair the sidewalk, and the ordinance only required adjacent landowners to keep sidewalks in safe condition. Contractor was not hired to ensure the structural integrity of the tree. Therefore, Contractor should not be held liable for the unforeseen consequences of cutting the tree's roots. This defense is based on the principle of proximate cause, which holds that a defendant is only liable for damages that are a direct and foreseeable result of their actions.

question: If Driver recovers a judgment against House, does House have any recourse against Contractor?
prompt: House owns his home in City. On the lawn in front of his home and within five feet of the public sidewalk, there was a large tree. The roots of the tree caused the sidewalk to buckle severely and become dangerous. An ordinance of City requires adjacent landowners to keep sidewalks in safe condition. House engaged Contractor to repair the sidewalk, leaving it to Contractor to decide how the repair should be made. Contractor dug up the sidewalk, cut back the roots of the tree, and laid a new sidewalk. Two days after House had paid Contractor the agreed price of the repair, the tree fell over onto the street and damaged a parked car belonging to Driver. Driver has asserted claims against House and Contractor, and both defendants admit that cutting the roots caused the tree to fall.
choices: No, if payment by House was an acceptance of the work.
No, because House selected Contractor to do the work.
Yes, if the judgment against House was based on vicarious liability.
Yes, because House's conduct was not a factual cause of the harm.
reasoning_samples: House engaged Contractor to repair the sidewalk, leaving it to Contractor to decide how the repair should be made. This indicates that House did not accept the work until it was completed, and thus, payment by House was not an acceptance of the work. Since House did not accept the work, he cannot be held liable for any defects in the work. Therefore, if Driver recovers a judgment against House, House has no recourse against Contractor because House's payment was not an acceptance of the work.

question: The State of Rio Grande entered into a contract with Roads, Inc., for construction of a four-lane turnpike. Prior to commencement of construction, the legislature, in order to provide funds for parks, repealed the statute authorizing the turnpike and cancelled the agreement with Roads, Inc. Roads, Inc., sued the state to enforce its original agreement. In ruling on this case, a court should hold that the state statute cancelling the agreement is
choices: valid, because constitutionally the sovereign is not liable except with its own consent
valid, because the legislature is vested with constitutional authority to repeal laws it has enacted
invalid, because a state is equitably estopped to disclaim a valid bid once accepted by it
invalid because of the constitutional prohibition against impairment of contracts
reasoning_samples: The state's action of repealing the statute and cancelling the agreement with Roads, Inc. is a legislative act, which the state legislature has the constitutional authority to do. The state has not impaired any contractual obligation, as there was no contract in place. The state can repeal its own laws, and in this case, it has not breached any contract with Roads, Inc. The state's action is a sovereign act, and as such, it is not subject to the same limitations as private actors. Therefore, the state's action is valid, and the correct answer is B.

question: The strongest constitutional basis for the enactment of a federal statute requiring colleges and universities receiving federal funds to offer student aid solely on the basis of need is the
choices: police power
war and defense power
power to tax and spend for the general welfare
power to enforce the privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
reasoning_samples: The power to tax and spend for the general welfare (Article I, Section 8, Clause 1) is the strongest constitutional basis for the enactment of a federal statute requiring colleges and universities receiving federal funds to offer student aid solely on the basis of need. This is because the statute can be seen as a condition placed upon the universities for receiving federal funds, which is within Congress's power to tax and spend for the general welfare. The government is essentially giving its own money to the universities, and Congress can condition the receipt of that money on certain requirements. Moreover, this power is broad enough to encompass a wide range of social welfare programs, including education and student aid. In comparison, the other options (police power, war and defense power, and power to enforce the privileges and immunities clause) do not provide a strong constitutional basis for such a statute.

question: Peterson asked his attorney to secure an injunction against the Water District and its proposed entry upon his property. The best advice that the attorney can give is that Peterson's attempt to secure injunctive relief will be likely to
prompt: in 1930, Owens, the owner in fee simple of Barrenacres, a large, undeveloped tract of land, granted an easement to the Water District "to install, inspect, repair, maintain, and replace pipes" within a properly delineated strip of land twenty feet wide across Barrenacres. The easement permitted the Water District to enter Barrenacres for only the stated purposes. The Water District promptly and properly recorded the deed. In 1931, the Water District installed a water main which crossed Barrenacres within the described strip: the Water District has not since entered Barrenacres. In 1935, Owens sold Barrenacres to Peterson, but the deed, which was promptly and properly recorded, failed to refer to the Water District easement. Peterson built his home on Barrenacres in 1935, and since that time he has planted and maintained, at great expense in money, time, and effort, a formal garden area which covers, among other areas, the surfac- of the twenty-foot easement strip. In 1976, the Water District proposed to excavate the entire length of its main in order to inspect, repair, and replace the main, to the extent necessary. At a public meeting, at which Peterson was present, the Water District announced its plans and declared its intent to do as little damage as possible to any property involved. Peterson objected to the Water District plans.
choices: succeed, because Peterson's deed from Owens did not mention the easement
succeed, because more than forty years have passed since the Water District last entered Barrenacres
fail, because the Water District's plan is within its rights
fail, because the Water District's plan is fair and equitable
reasoning_samples: The Water District's easement granted in 1930 specifically permits the installation, inspection, repair, maintenance, and replacement of pipes within the twenty-foot strip of land across Barrenacres. The Water District's proposed plan to excavate the entire length of its main in order to inspect, repair, and replace the main is within the scope of the easement granted. Therefore, the Water District's plan is within its rights, and Peterson's attempt to secure injunctive relief will likely fail.

question: Assume that Peterson reserved his rights and after the Water District completed its work sued for the $5,000 in damages he suffered by reason of the Water District entry. Peterson's attempt to secure damages probably will
prompt: in 1930, Owens, the owner in fee simple of Barrenacres, a large, undeveloped tract of land, granted an easement to the Water District "to install, inspect, repair, maintain, and replace pipes" within a properly delineated strip of land twenty feet wide across Barrenacres. The easement permitted the Water District to enter Barrenacres for only the stated purposes. The Water District promptly and properly recorded the deed. In 1931, the Water District installed a water main which crossed Barrenacres within the described strip: the Water District has not since entered Barrenacres. In 1935, Owens sold Barrenacres to Peterson, but the deed, which was promptly and properly recorded, failed to refer to the Water District easement. Peterson built his home on Barrenacres in 1935, and since that time he has planted and maintained, at great expense in money, time, and effort, a formal garden area which covers, among other areas, the surfac- of the twenty-foot easement strip. In 1976, the Water District proposed to excavate the entire length of its main in order to inspect, repair, and replace the main, to the extent necessary. At a public meeting, at which Peterson was present, the Water District announced its plans and declared its intent to do as little damage as possible to any property involved. Peterson objected to the Water District plans.
choices: succeed, because his deed from Owens did not mention the easement
succeed, because of an implied obligation imposed on the Water District to restore the surface to its condition prior to entry
fail, because of the public interest in maintaining a continuous water supply
fail, because the Water District acted within its rights
reasoning_samples: Peterson's claim for damages is based on the Water District's entry onto his property to inspect, repair, and replace the water main. The easement granted by Owens to the Water District specifically permitted the Water District to enter Barrenacres for these purposes. However, the deed from Owens to Peterson did not mention the easement, which means Peterson did not have notice of the easement. As a result, Peterson's rights as a landowner were not affected by the easement, and he is entitled to compensation for the damages caused by the Water District's entry. Therefore, Peterson's attempt to secure damages will probably succeed because his deed from Owens did not mention the easement.

question: In 1960 Omar, the owner in fee simple absolute, conveyed Stoneacre, a five-acre tract of land. The relevant, operative words of the deed conveyed to "Church [a duly organized religious body having power to hold property] for the life of my son, Carl, and from and after the death of my said son, Carl, to all of my grandchildren and their heirs and assigns In equal shares; provided, Church shall use the premises for church purposes only." In an existing building on Stoneacre, Church immediately began to conduct religious services and other activities normally associated with a church. In 1975, Church granted to Darin a right to remove sand and gravel from a one-half acre portion of Stoneacre upon the payment of royalty. Darin has regularly removed sand and gravel since 1975 and paid royalty to Church. Church has continued ro conduct religious services and other church activities on Stoneacre. All four of the living grandchildren of Omar, joined by a guardian ad litem to represent unborn grandchildren, instituted suit against Church and Darin seeking damages for the removal of sand and gravel and an injunction preventing further acts of removal. There is no applicable statute. Which of the following best describes the likely disposition of this lawsuit?
choices: The plaintiffs should succeed, because the interest of Church terminated with the first removal of sand and gravel.
Church and Darin should be enjoined, and damages should be recovered but impounded for future distribution.
The injunction should be granted, but damages should be denied, because Omar and Carl are not parties to the action.
Damages should be awarded, but the Injunction should be denied.
reasoning_samples: The interest conveyed to Church was a life estate in Carl, followed by a vested remainder in the grandchildren. The conveyance to Church was subject to the condition that the premises be used for church purposes only. The grant to Darin of a right to remove sand and gravel was a permissive use, which did not terminate Church's interest.
