In this case, Player's picture was taken without his knowledge or consent, and it was used for commercial purposes without his permission. This meets the first three elements of the tort. However, the fourth element requires that the publicity be offensive to a reasonable person. While Player may not have been offended by the picture itself, the fact that it was used to suggest that he endorsed Shoe Store and 'Jumpers' shoes without his permission may be considered offensive. Therefore, the correct answer is B, because Shoe Store, without Player's permission, used Player's picture for profit.

question: Landover, the owner in fee simple of Highacre, an apartment house property, entered into an enforceable written agreement with VanMeer to sell Highacre to VanMeer. The agreement provided that a good and marketable title was to be conveyed free and clear of all encumbrances. However, the agreement was silent as to the risk of fire prior to the closing, and there is no applicable statute in the state where the land is located. The premises were not insured. The day before the scheduled closing date, Highacre was wholly destroyed by fire. When VanMeer refused to close, Landover brought an action for specific performance. If Landover prevails, the most likely reason will be that
choices: the failure of VanMeer to insure his interest as the purchaser of Highacre precludes any relief for him
the remedy at law is inadequate in actions concerning real estate contracts and either party is entitled to specific performance
equity does not permit consideration of surrounding circumstances in actions concerning real estate contracts
the doctrine of equitable conversion applies
reasoning_samples: The doctrine of equitable conversion applies in this scenario because it converts the risk of loss from the seller to the buyer upon the execution of the contract. Since the contract was silent as to the risk of fire prior to the closing, and there is no applicable statute in the state where the land is located, the risk of loss falls on the buyer, VanMeer. Therefore, when Highacre was destroyed by fire the day before the scheduled closing date, VanMeer is responsible for the loss, and Landover is entitled to specific performance.

question: If the question is raised in an action against the insurance company, how is the court likely to construe the clause dealing with the truthfulness of statements in the application?
prompt: In the application for a life insurance policy, Mary answered in the negative the question, "Have you ever had any heart disease?" Both the application and the insurance policy which was issued provided: "Applicant warrants the truthfulness of the statements made in the application and they are made conditions to the cont ract of insurance." Unknown to Mary, she had had a heart disease at a very early age. The policy provided that the proceeds were not to be paid over to the named beneficiary, Mary's daughter, Joan, "until she reaches the age of 21." No contingent beneficiary was named in the policy. Mary was killed in an automobile accident two months after the policy was issued. Joan died one month later at the age of 19 from injuries incurred in the same accident.
choices: The clause is a condition, and because the condition was not met, the company will not be liable.
The clause is a condition, but it will be interpreted to mean, "truthfulness to the best of my knowledge."
The clause is not a condition, and therefore the company may be liable even though Mary's statement was not true.
The clause is not a condition but is a promise, and therefore the company will have a cause of action against Mary 's estate for any losses it suffered because of Mary 's misstatement.
reasoning_samples: The clause dealing with the truthfulness of statements in the application is a condition precedent to the contract of insurance. This means that the truthfulness of the statements must be met before the insurance company is liable. In this case, Mary's statement was not true, and therefore the condition was not met. The fact that the policy was issued does not mean that the condition was waived, especially since the policy explicitly states that the applicant warrants the truthfulness of the statements made in the application. The clause is not ambiguous and does not suggest that the truthfulness of the statements is only required to the best of the applicant's knowledge. Therefore, the court is likely to construe the clause as a condition, and because the condition was not met, the company will not be liable.

question: If no objection is made concerning Mary's misstatement in the application, how is the court most likely to construe the clause dealing with the payment of the proceeds to Joan?
prompt: In the application for a life insurance policy, Mary answered in the negative the question, "Have you ever had any heart disease?" Both the application and the insurance policy which was issued provided: "Applicant warrants the truthfulness of the statements made in the application and they are made conditions to the cont ract of insurance." Unknown to Mary, she had had a heart disease at a very early age. The policy provided that the proceeds were not to be paid over to the named beneficiary, Mary's daughter, Joan, "until she reaches the age of 21." No contingent beneficiary was named in the policy. Mary was killed in an automobile accident two months after the policy was issued. Joan died one month later at the age of 19 from injuries incurred in the same accident.
choices: Joan's reaching the age of 21 is a constructive condition concurrent.
Joan's reaching the age of 21 is a condition precedent to the insurance company's duty to pay anyone.
Joan's reaching the age of 21 has legal significance only with respect to the time of payment.
Joan's reaching the age of 21 has no legal significance.
reasoning_samples: The court is most likely to construe the clause dealing with the payment of the proceeds to Joan as a constructive condition concurrent because the policy language does not indicate that the condition is a condition precedent. The phrase 'until she reaches the age of 21' suggests that the condition is related to the timing of the payment, rather than a requirement that must be met before the insurance company has a duty to pay. Furthermore, the policy does not provide for an alternative beneficiary in the event that Joan does not reach the age of 21, which suggests that the condition is intended to be concurrent rather than precedent. Therefore, the court is likely to interpret the clause as requiring the insurance company to pay the proceeds to Joan as soon as she is eligible, rather than withholding payment until she reaches the age of 21.

question: At Defendant's trial for the murder of the watchman, the court should in substance charge the jury on the issue of the defense of intoxication that
prompt: Defendant became intoxicated at a bar. He got into his car and drove away. Within a few blocks, craving another drink, he stopped ails car in the middle of the street, picked up a brick, and broke the display window of a liquor store. As he was reaching for a bottle, the night watchman arrived. Startled, Defendant turned, struck the watchman on the head with the bottle, killing him. Only vaguely aware of what was happening, Defendant returned to his car, consumed more liquor, and then drove off at a high speed. He ran a red light and struck and killed a pedestrian who was crossing the street. Relevant statutes define burglary to include "breaking and entering a building not used as a dwelling with the intent to commit a crime therein." Manslaughter is defined as the "killing of a human being in a criminally reckless manner." Criminal recklessness is "consciously disregarding a substantial and unjustifiable risk resulting from the actor's conduct." Murder is defined as "the premeditated and intentional killing of another or the killing of another in the commission of committing rape, robbery, burglary, or arson." Another statute provides that intoxication is not a defense to crime unless it negates an element of the offense. Defendant was charged with the murder of the watchman and manslaughter in the death of the pedestrian. Assume that he is tried separately on each charge.
choices: intoxication is a defense to the underlying crime of burglary if Defendant, due to drunkenness, did not form an intent to commit a crime within the building, in which case there can be no conviction for murder unless Defendant intentionally and with premeditation killed the watchman
voluntary intoxication is no defense to the crime of murder
Defendant is guilty of murder despite his intoxication only if the state proves beyond a reasonable doubt that the killing of the watchman was premeditated and intentional
voluntary intoxication is a defense to the crime of murder if Defendant would not have killed the watchman but for his intoxication
reasoning_samples: To determine the correct answer, we must first understand the relationship between burglary and murder. The statute defines burglary as breaking and entering a building not used as a dwelling with the intent to commit a crime therein. Since Defendant's intoxication may negate the intent element of burglary, it is crucial to consider how this affects the murder charge. Murder is defined as the premeditated and intentional killing of another or the killing of another in the commission of committing burglary. If Defendant did not form the intent to commit a crime within the building due to his intoxication, then he cannot be convicted of burglary. Consequently, he cannot be convicted of murder in the commission of burglary unless the killing was intentional and premeditated. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question: At Defendant's trial on the charge of manslaughter in the death of the pedestrian, his best argument would be that
prompt: Defendant became intoxicated at a bar. He got into his car and drove away. Within a few blocks, craving another drink, he stopped ails car in the middle of the street, picked up a brick, and broke the display window of a liquor store. As he was reaching for a bottle, the night watchman arrived. Startled, Defendant turned, struck the watchman on the head with the bottle, killing him. Only vaguely aware of what was happening, Defendant returned to his car, consumed more liquor, and then drove off at a high speed. He ran a red light and struck and killed a pedestrian who was crossing the street. Relevant statutes define burglary to include "breaking and entering a building not used as a dwelling with the intent to commit a crime therein." Manslaughter is defined as the "killing of a human being in a criminally reckless manner." Criminal recklessness is "consciously disregarding a substantial and unjustifiable risk resulting from the actor's conduct." Murder is defined as "the premeditated and intentional killing of another or the killing of another in the commission of committing rape, robbery, burglary, or arson." Another statute provides that intoxication is not a defense to crime unless it negates an element of the offense. Defendant was charged with the murder of the watchman and manslaughter in the death of the pedestrian. Assume that he is tried separately on each charge.
choices: he was too intoxicated to realize he was creating a substantial and unjustifiable risking the manner in which he was operating his car
when he got in the car his acts were not volun. tary because he was too intoxicated to know where he was or what he was doing
the pedestrian was contributorily negligent in failing to see Defendant's car approaching
he was too intoxicated to form any intent to voluntarily operate the automobile
reasoning_samples: The defendant's best argument for the manslaughter charge would be that he was too intoxicated to realize he was creating a substantial and unjustifiable risk. This is because the statute defines manslaughter as the 'killing of a human being in a criminally reckless manner,' which is 'consciously disregarding a substantial and unjustifiable risk resulting from the actor's conduct.' If the defendant was too intoxicated to be aware of the risk, he cannot be said to have consciously disregarded it. This argument is focused on the mens rea element of the crime, which is the mental state required for the crime to be committed. The defendant's intoxication may not be a complete defense, but it could negate the element of criminal recklessness, making it the best argument for the manslaughter charge.

question: The state's best argument to counter Defendant's argument in Question 157 on the intoxication issue in the manslaughter death of the pedestrian is that
prompt: Defendant became intoxicated at a bar. He got into his car and drove away. Within a few blocks, craving another drink, he stopped ails car in the middle of the street, picked up a brick, and broke the display window of a liquor store. As he was reaching for a bottle, the night watchman arrived. Startled, Defendant turned, struck the watchman on the head with the bottle, killing him. Only vaguely aware of what was happening, Defendant returned to his car, consumed more liquor, and then drove off at a high speed. He ran a red light and struck and killed a pedestrian who was crossing the street. Relevant statutes define burglary to include "breaking and entering a building not used as a dwelling with the intent to commit a crime therein." Manslaughter is defined as the "killing of a human being in a criminally reckless manner." Criminal recklessness is "consciously disregarding a substantial and unjustifiable risk resulting from the actor's conduct." Murder is defined as "the premeditated and intentional killing of another or the killing of another in the commission of committing rape, robbery, burglary, or arson." Another statute provides that intoxication is not a defense to crime unless it negates an element of the offense. Defendant was charged with the murder of the watchman and manslaughter in the death of the pedestrian. Assume that he is tried separately on each charge.
choices: intoxication is no defense to the crime charged, because manslaughter is historically a general intent crime
intoxication is a defense only to a specific intent crime, and no specific intent is involved in the definition of the crime of manslaughter
conscious risk-taking refers to Defendant's entire course of conduct, including drinking with the knowledge that he might become intoxicated and seriously injure or kill someone while driving

whether Defendant was intoxicated or not is not the crucial issue here; the real issue is whether the manner in which Defendant was operating his car can be characterized under the facts as criminally reckless
reasoning_samples: The state may argue that intoxication is no defense to the crime charged, because manslaughter is historically a general intent crime. In this case, the defendant's conduct was criminally reckless as he consciously disregarded a substantial and unjustifiable risk resulting from his driving. The fact that he was intoxicated does not negate the general intent to commit the crime. The defendant's argument that he was not in control of his actions because of intoxication may not be sufficient to negate the general intent element of manslaughter. The prosecution can argue that the defendant's actions were still reckless and intentional and therefore, not excused by his intoxication. This argument is supported by the fact that the defendant did not act with the intent to kill but rather with the intent to cause serious harm by driving while intoxicated, which is a general intent crime.

question: If Johnson's claim is based on negligence, is the defense of assumption of the risk applicable?
prompt: Johnson wanted to purchase a used motor vehicle. The used car lot of Car Company, in a remote section away from town, was enclosed by a ten-foot chain link fence. While Johnson and Sales Representative, an employee of Car Company, were in the used car lot looking at cars, a security guard locked the gate at 1:30 p. i., because it was Saturday and the lot was supposed to be closed after 1:00 p. m. Saturday until Monday morning. At 1:45 p. m., Johnson and Sales Representative discovered they were locked in. There was no traffic in the vicinity and no way in which help could be summoned. After two hours, Johnson began to panic at the prospect of remaining undiscovered and without food and water until Monday morning. Sales Representative decided to wait in a car until help should come. Johnson tried to climb over the fence and, in doing so, fell and was injured. Johnson asserts a claim against Car Company for damages for his injuries.
choices: Yes, if a reasonable person would have recognized that there was some risk of falling while climbing the fence.
Yes, because Sales Representative, as Car Company's agent, waited for help.
No, if it appeared that there was no other practicable way of getting out of the lot before Monday.
No, because Johnson was confined as the result of a volitional act.
reasoning_samples: To determine if the defense of assumption of the risk is applicable, we must first establish whether Johnson voluntarily assumed the risk of injury. In this scenario, Johnson voluntarily climbed over the fence, which is a volitional act. However, the key factor is whether a reasonable person would have recognized the risk of falling while climbing the fence. If a reasonable person would have recognized this risk, then Johnson assumed the risk by climbing the fence. Therefore, the defense of assumption of the risk is applicable if a reasonable person would have recognized the risk of falling while climbing the fence.

question: If Johnson's claim is based on false imprisonment, will Johnson prevail?
prompt: Johnson wanted to purchase a used motor vehicle. The used car lot of Car Company, in a remote section away from town, was enclosed by a ten-foot chain link fence. While Johnson and Sales Representative, an employee of Car Company, were in the used car lot looking at cars, a security guard locked the gate at 1:30 p. i., because it was Saturday and the lot was supposed to be closed after 1:00 p. m. Saturday until Monday morning. At 1:45 p. m., Johnson and Sales Representative discovered they were locked in. There was no traffic in the vicinity and no way in which help could be summoned. After two hours, Johnson began to panic at the prospect of remaining undiscovered and without food and water until Monday morning. Sales Representative decided to wait in a car until help should come. Johnson tried to climb over the fence and, in doing so, fell and was injured. Johnson asserts a claim against Car Company for damages for his injuries.
choices: Yes, because he was confined against his will.
Yes, because he was harmed as a result of his confinement.
No, unless the security guard was negligent in locking the gate.
No, unless the security guard knew that someone was in the lot at the time the guard locked the gate.
reasoning_samples: To determine if Johnson will prevail on his false imprisonment claim, we must first establish the elements of false imprisonment. False imprisonment is the unlawful restraint of a person against their will. In this scenario, Johnson was confined against his will when the security guard locked the gate at 1:30 p.m. and Johnson and the Sales Representative were unable to leave the used car lot. The fact that Johnson was harmed as a result of his confinement (choice B) is not a necessary element of false imprisonment, and negligence on the part of the security guard (choice C) is not a requirement for false imprisonment. Furthermore, the security guard's knowledge of Johnson's presence at the time the gate was locked (choice D) is not a necessary element of false imprisonment. Therefore, the key factor in determining whether Johnson will prevail on his false imprisonment claim is whether he was confined against his will, which is established by choice A.

question: If the court refuses the injunction, it will be because
prompt: Albert, the owner of a house and lot, leased the same to Barnes for a term of five years. In addition to the house, there was also an unattached, two-car brick garage located on the lot. Barnes earned his living as an employee in a local grocery store, but his hobby consisted of wood carving and the making of small furniture. Barnes installed a work bench, electric lights, and a radiator in the garage. He also laid pipes connecting the radiator with the heating plant inside the house. Thereafter Albert mortgaged the premises to Good Bank to secure a loan. Barnes was not given notice of the mortgage, but the mortgage was recorded. Still later, Albert defaulted on his mortgage payments, and Good Bank began foreclosure proceedings, as it was entitled to do under the terms of the mortgage. By this time Barnes's lease was almost ended. Barnes began the removal of the equipment he had installed in the garage. Good Bank brought an action to enjoin the removal of the equipment mentioned above. Both Barnes and Albert were named as defendants.
choices: Barnes was without notice of the mortgage
the circumstances reveal that the equipment was installed for Barnes's exclusive benefit
in the absence of a contrary agreement, a residential tenant is entitled to remove any personal property he voluntarily brings upon the premises
the Statute of Frauds precludes the Bank from claiming any interest In the equipment
reasoning_samples: The court will refuse the injunction because the circumstances reveal that the equipment was installed for Barnes's exclusive benefit. Barnes installed the equipment in the garage for his own wood carving and furniture making hobby, which is unrelated to the use of the house as a residence. This suggests that the equipment is Barnes's personal property, and he is entitled to remove it upon the expiration of his lease. The fact that Barnes was not given notice of the mortgage does not affect his right to remove his personal property. The absence of a contrary agreement between Albert and Barnes does not apply because the equipment was installed for Barnes's exclusive benefit, not as part of the lease agreement. The Statute of Frauds is not relevant to this situation because it deals with the creation of interests in land, not the removal of personal property.

question: If the equipment concerned had been installed by Albert, but the facts were otherwise unchanged, the effect on Good Bank's prayer for an injunction would be that the
prompt: Albert, the owner of a house and lot, leased the same to Barnes for a term of five years. In addition to the house, there was also an unattached, two-car brick garage located on the lot. Barnes earned his living as an employee in a local grocery store, but his hobby consisted of wood carving and the making of small furniture. Barnes installed a work bench, electric lights, and a radiator in the garage. He also laid pipes connecting the radiator with the heating plant inside the house. Thereafter Albert mortgaged the premises to Good Bank to secure a loan. Barnes was not given notice of the mortgage, but the mortgage was recorded. Still later, Albert defaulted on his mortgage payments, and Good Bank began foreclosure proceedings, as it was entitled to do under the terms of the mortgage. By this time Barnes's lease was almost ended. Barnes began the removal of the equipment he had installed in the garage. Good Bank brought an action to enjoin the removal of the equipment mentioned above. Both Barnes and Albert were named as defendants.
choices: likelihood of Good Bank's succeeding would be improved
likelihood of Good Bank's succeeding would be lessened
likelihood of Good Bank's succeeding would be unaffected
outcome of the litigation would depend upon whether or not the mortgage expressly mentioned personal property located on the premises
reasoning_samples: If the equipment had been installed by Albert, it would be considered part of the real property, as it is affixed to the land. As such, it would be subject to the mortgage and Good Bank's lien. Therefore, the likelihood of Good Bank's succeeding in its prayer for an injunction would be improved, as it would have a stronger claim to the equipment. This is because the mortgage would take precedence over Barnes's leasehold interest, and Good Bank would be able to assert its rights as a secured creditor.

question: If charged with criminal assault, Edward should be found
prompt: Statutes in the jurisdiction define criminal assault as "an attempt to commit a criminal battery" and criminal battery as "causing an offensive touching." As Edward was walking down the street, a gust of wind blew his hat off. Edward reached out, trying to grab his hat, and narrowly missed striking Margaret in the face with his hand. Margaret, fearful of being struck by Edward, pushed Edward away.
choices: guilty, because he caused Margaret to be in apprehension of an offensive touching
guilty, because he should have realized he might strike someone by reaching out
not guilty, because he did not intend to hit Margaret
not guilty, because he did not hit Margaret
reasoning_samples: To determine Edward's guilt, it's essential to understand the definition of criminal assault in this jurisdiction. The statute defines assault as an attempt to commit a criminal battery. Since Edward's attempt to grab his hat resulted in an attempt to cause an offensive touching (striking Margaret in the face), and his actions caused Margaret to be in apprehension of this touching, Edward's actions meet the definition of assault. The question of whether Edward intended to hit Margaret is irrelevant as the attempt to commit a battery is sufficient for the crime of assault. Therefore, Edward should be found guilty because he caused Margaret to be in apprehension of an offensive touching.

question: If charged with criminal battery, Margaret should be found
prompt: Statutes in the jurisdiction define criminal assault as "an attempt to commit a criminal battery" and criminal battery as "causing an offensive touching." As Edward was walking down the street, a gust of wind blew his hat off. Edward reached out, trying to grab his hat, and narrowly missed striking Margaret in the face with his hand. Margaret, fearful of being struck by Edward, pushed Edward away.
choices: guilty, because she intentionally pushed Edward
guilty, because she caused the touching of Edward whether she meant to do so or not
not guilty, because a push is not an offensive touching
not guilty, because she was justified in pushing Edward
reasoning_samples: Margaret's actions constitute a criminal battery as she caused an offensive touching of Edward. Although the statutes define battery as 'causing an offensive touching,' they do not specify that the touching must be intentional. In this scenario, Margaret's push resulted in Edward being touched, even if it was unintentional. The fact that she was fearful and pushed Edward away does not negate the fact that she caused the touching. Therefore, Margaret should be found guilty of criminal battery.

question: Police were concerned about an increase in marijuana traffic in Defendant's neighborhood. One night, Police Officers, accompanied by dogs trained to sniff out marijuana, went into the back yard of Defendant's house and onto his porch. Defendant and his friend were inside having dinner The dogs acted as if they smelled marijuana. Police Officers knocked on the back door. Defendant answered the door and let them in. Defendant was immediately placed under arrest. After a brief search, Police Officers confiscated a large quantity of marijuana which they found in Defendant's linen closet. Defendant's motion to prevent introduction of the marijuana into evidence will most probably be
choices: denied, because the search was incident to a valid arrest
denied, because Defendant permitted Police Officers to enter his house
granted, because under the circumstances the police activity violated Defendant's reasonable expectations of privacy
granted, because this kind of detection by trained dogs has not been scientifically verified and cannot be the basis for probable cause
reasoning_samples: The police officers had a valid reason to arrest Defendant, as the trained dogs indicated the presence of marijuana. Once Defendant was under arrest, the police officers were entitled to conduct a search incident to the arrest. This search is allowed under the Fourth Amendment, as it is a reasonable search that is necessary to ensure officer safety and prevent the destruction of evidence. The fact that Defendant permitted the police officers to enter his house does not negate the validity of the arrest or the search incident to it. Therefore, Defendant's motion to prevent the introduction of the marijuana into evidence will most probably be denied.

question: In his case in chief, Drew called as his first witness Wilma to testify to Drew's reputation in his community as "a peaceable man." The testimony is
prompt: Drew was tried for the July 21 murder of Victor.
choices: admissible as tending to prove Drew is believable
admissible as tending to prove Drew is innocent
inadmissible, because Drew has not testified
inadmissible, because reputation is not a proper way to prove character
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, Drew is attempting to introduce evidence of his character trait of being a 'peaceable man' through the testimony of Wilma. This is a relevant character trait because it is directly related to the crime of murder. Under Federal Rule of Evidence 404(a)(2), character evidence is admissible to prove the character of a person in a criminal case. Furthermore, under Rule 405, specific instances of conduct can be used to prove character, but in this case, Drew is using reputation evidence to prove his character. The key point is that reputation evidence is admissible to prove character when it is relevant to the crime charged. In this case, the testimony of Wilma is admissible to prove that Drew is believable, as a peaceable man is more likely to be believable and less likely to commit a violent crime like murder. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

question: Drew called William to testify that on July 20 Drew said that he was about to leave that day to visit relatives in a distant state. The testimony Is
prompt: Drew was tried for the July 21 murder of Victor.
choices: admissible, because it is a declaration of present mental state
admissible, because it is not hearsay
inadmissible, because it is irrelevant
inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any exception
reasoning_samples: The testimony is a statement by Drew about his future plans to visit relatives in a distant state. This is a declaration of Drew's present mental state, which is relevant to his whereabouts on July 20. Since Drew is unavailable to testify (he is presumably a defendant in the murder trial), his prior statement is admissible under the present sense impression exception to the hearsay rule. This exception allows for the admission of statements that describe or explain an event or condition made while the declarant was perceiving the event or condition, or immediately thereafter. In this case, Drew's statement about his plans to visit relatives is a declaration of his present mental state, which is relevant to his whereabouts on July 20 and, by extension, his whereabouts on July 21 when the murder occurred.

question: Drew called Wilson to testify to alibi. On cross-examination of Wilson, the prosecutor asked, "Isn't it a fact that you are Drew's first cousin?" The question is
prompt: Drew was tried for the July 21 murder of Victor.
choices: proper, because it goes to bias
proper, because a relative is not competent to give reputation testimony
improper, because the question goes beyond the scope of direct examination
improper, because the evidence being sought is irrelevant
reasoning_samples: The prosecutor's question is proper because it goes to bias. Under Federal Rule of Evidence 605, a relative of the defendant is competent to testify, but the jury may still consider the relationship when evaluating the witness's credibility. The question is relevant to show that Wilson may have a bias in favor of Drew due to their familial relationship, which could impact the weight of his testimony. This is a permissible line of questioning under the rules of evidence.

question: Drew called Warren to testify to alibi. On cross-examination of Warren, the prosecutor asked, "Weren't you on the jury that acquitted Drew of another criminal charge?" The best reason for sustaining an objection to this question is that
prompt: Drew was tried for the July 21 murder of Victor.
choices: the question goes beyond the scope of direct examination
the probative value of the answer would be outweighed by its tendency to mislead
the question is leading
prior jury service in a case involving a party renders the fitness incompetent
reasoning_samples: The question is best answered by choice D because the prosecutor's question is attempting to impeach Warren's testimony by suggesting that his prior jury service in a case involving Drew renders him unfit to testify. However, the correct rule is that prior jury service in a case involving a party does not render a witness incompetent. The correct rule is that a witness is incompetent if they have served on a jury in a case in which they were a party or a material witness. Since Warren was not a party or a material witness in the prior case, his prior jury service does not render him incompetent. Therefore, the objection should be sustained because the question is attempting to elicit an irrelevant and misleading response.

question: Re-direct examination of a witness must be permitted in which of the following circumstances?
choices: To reply to any matter raised in crossexamination
only to reply to significant new matter raised in cross-examination
Only to reiterate the essential elements of the case
Only to supply significant information inadvertently omitted on direct examination
reasoning_samples: Re-direct examination is a tool used by the prosecution to allow the witness to clarify or respond to any matter raised during cross-examination. This is a fundamental principle of the adversarial system, as it allows the prosecution to address any potential weaknesses or inconsistencies raised by the defense. Option A is the correct answer because it accurately reflects the purpose and scope of re-direct examination. Options B, C, and D are incorrect because they impose unnecessary limitations on the scope of re-direct examination. While it is true that re-direct examination may be used to address significant new matter raised in cross-examination, it is not limited to such circumstances. Similarly, re-direct examination is not solely for the purpose of reiterating the essential elements of the case or supplying significant information inadvertently omitted on direct examination. In fact, re-direct examination can be used for a wide range of purposes, including addressing any matter raised in cross-examination, regardless of its significance or relevance.

question: On March 1, Mechanic agreed to repair Ohner's machine for $5,000, to be paid on completion of the work. On March 15, before the work was completed, Mechanic sent a letter to Ohner with a copy to Jones, telling Ohner to pay the $5,000 to Jones, who was one of Mechanic's creditors, Mechanic then completed the work. Which of the following, if true, would best serve Ohner as a defense in an action brought against him by Jones for $5,000 ?
choices: Jones was incapable of performing Mechanic's work.
Mechanic had not performed his work in a workmanlike manner.
On March 1, Mechanic had promised Ohner that he would not assign the contract.
Jones was not the intended beneficiary of the Ohner-Mechanic contract.
reasoning_samples: Ohner's best defense would be that Mechanic had promised not to assign the contract on March 1. This would be a breach of contract by Mechanic, and Ohner would not be liable to pay Jones. This defense is based on the theory of promissory estoppel, which holds that a party who makes a promise that induces reliance in another party cannot go back on that promise. In this case, Mechanic's promise not to assign the contract induced Ohner's reliance, and Mechanic's subsequent assignment of the contract to Jones would be a breach of that promise. Therefore, Ohner would not be liable to pay Jones.

question: Assume for this question only that BCD's termination of John's employment was not wrongful. If John, after demand and refusal, sues BCD for the Bobb sale commission, which of the following is the most likely result?
prompt: BCD, a manufacturer of computers, pays its salespeople a salary of $1,000 per month and a commission of 5% on billings actually rendered for machines that they sell. BCD salespeople are employed at will under written agreements which provide that in order to receive a commission the salesperson must be in the employment of the company when the bill is sent to the customer. In 1976, John, a salesperson for BCD, worked for eight months to get an order from Bobb Corporation for a large $750,000 computer. He consulted extensively with Bobb's top executives and worked with its operating personnel to dt.velop detailed specifications for the new equipment. He also promised Bobb, with BCD's knowledge and approval, to assist Bobb for six months after installation in making the equipment work. On January 1, 1977, Bobb signed an order, and on March 1 the computer was installed. On March 15, BCD fired John on the stated ground that he had failed to meet his 1975 and 1976 sales quotas. John thought that BCD was correct in this statement. Another salesperson, Franklin, was thereupon assigned to service the Bobb account. On March 31, BCD billed Bobb for the computer.
choices: John will win, because he had procured the sale of the computer.
John will win, because he had promised Bobb to assist in making the equipment work.
BCD will win, because Franklin is entitled to the commission on a quantum meruit basis.
BCD will win, because John was not employed as a BCD salesperson when Bobb was billed for the computer.
reasoning_samples: This question requires an analysis of the terms of John's employment contract and their application to the facts of the case. The contract states that to receive a commission, the salesperson must be in the employment of the company when the bill is sent to the customer. In this case, the bill was sent on March 31, 1977, but John was fired on March 15, 1977. Since John was no longer employed when the bill was sent, he is not entitled to the commission under the terms of the contract. Therefore, option D is the most likely result. Options A and B are incorrect because they rely on facts that are not relevant to John's entitlement to the commission. Option C is also incorrect because it misinterprets the concept of quantum meruit, which is a doctrine that allows a party to recover for services rendered when there is no express contract, but it is not relevant to the facts of this case.

question: Assume for this question only that BCD's termination of John's employment was not wrongful. If John sues BCD for the reasonable value of his services, which of the following is the most likely result?
prompt: BCD, a manufacturer of computers, pays its salespeople a salary of $1,000 per month and a commission of 5% on billings actually rendered for machines that they sell. BCD salespeople are employed at will under written agreements which provide that in order to receive a commission the salesperson must be in the employment of the company when the bill is sent to the customer. In 1976, John, a salesperson for BCD, worked for eight months to get an order from Bobb Corporation for a large $750,000 computer. He consulted extensively with Bobb's top executives and worked with its operating personnel to dt.velop detailed specifications for the new equipment. He also promised Bobb, with BCD's knowledge and approval, to assist Bobb for six months after installation in making the equipment work. On January 1, 1977, Bobb signed an order, and on March 1 the computer was installed. On March 15, BCD fired John on the stated ground that he had failed to meet his 1975 and 1976 sales quotas. John thought that BCD was correct in this statement. Another salesperson, Franklin, was thereupon assigned to service the Bobb account. On March 31, BCD billed Bobb for the computer.
choices: John will win, because BCD benefited as a result of John' services.
John will win, because BCD made an impliedin-fact promise to pay a reasonable commission for services that result in sales.
John will lose, because there is an express contractual provision pre-empting the subject of compensation for his services.
John will lose, because he cannot perform his agreement to assist the customer for six months.
reasoning_samples: John's claim for the reasonable value of his services is based on a theory of quantum meruit, which is a doctrine that allows a plaintiff to recover the reasonable value of services rendered where there is no express contract governing the compensation for those services. In this case, the express contract between John and BCD provides for a commission only if John is employed by BCD when the bill is sent to the customer. However, this provision does not address the situation where John's services result in a sale, but he is no longer employed by BCD when the bill is sent. Therefore, the express contract does not preclude John's claim for the reasonable value of his services. BCD benefited from John's services, and it would be unjust for BCD to retain the benefit of those services without paying John for them. Therefore, John will likely win his claim for the reasonable value of his services.

question: Which of the following additional facts, if shown by the evidence, would support a claim by John against BCD ? 1. BCD terminated John because Franklin is the son of the company's president, who wanted his son to have the commission instead of John. II. BCD and John were mistaken; John had in fact exceeded his sales quotas for 1975 and 1976. III. John had worked for BCD as a salesperson for 20 years.
prompt: BCD, a manufacturer of computers, pays its salespeople a salary of $1,000 per month and a commission of 5% on billings actually rendered for machines that they sell. BCD salespeople are employed at will under written agreements which provide that in order to receive a commission the salesperson must be in the employment of the company when the bill is sent to the customer. In 1976, John, a salesperson for BCD, worked for eight months to get an order from Bobb Corporation for a large $750,000 computer. He consulted extensively with Bobb's top executives and worked with its operating personnel to dt.velop detailed specifications for the new equipment. He also promised Bobb, with BCD's knowledge and approval, to assist Bobb for six months after installation in making the equipment work. On January 1, 1977, Bobb signed an order, and on March 1 the computer was installed. On March 15, BCD fired John on the stated ground that he had failed to meet his 1975 and 1976 sales quotas. John thought that BCD was correct in this statement. Another salesperson, Franklin, was thereupon assigned to service the Bobb account. On March 31, BCD billed Bobb for the computer.
choices: I only
II only
I and II only
I, II, and III
reasoning_samples: To support a claim by John against BCD, we need to consider the terms of the employment agreement and the circumstances surrounding John's termination. The agreement states that John must be in the employment of BCD when the bill is sent to the customer to receive a commission. However, the agreement does not specify that John must be employed at the time of sale or installation. In this case, John was terminated after the computer was installed, but before the bill was sent to Bobb. If BCD terminated John because Franklin is the son of the company's president, who wanted his son to have the commission instead of John, this would suggest that BCD's termination of John was motivated by an improper reason, specifically favoritism. This would support John's claim that BCD's termination was wrongful and that he is entitled to the commission. Facts II and III are irrelevant to the issue of whether John is entitled to the commission, as they do not address the terms of the employment agreement or the circumstances surrounding John's termination.

question: If plaintiffs assert a claim based on public nuisance, plaintiffs will
prompt: In 1940, Cattle Company paid $30,000 for a 150-acre tract of agricultural land well suited for a cattle feed lot. The tract was ten miles from the city of Metropolis, then a community of 50,000 people, and five miles from the nearest home. By 1976, the city limits extended to Cattle Company's feed lot, and the city had a population of 350,000. About 10,000 people lived within three miles of the cattle feeding operation. The Cattle Company land is outside the city limits and no zoning ordinance applies. The Cattle Company land is now worth $300,000, and $25,000 has been invested in buildings and pens. Cattle Company, conscious of its obligations to its neighbors, uses the best and most sanitary feed lot procedures, including chemical sprays, to keep down flies and odors and frequently removes manure. Despite these measures, residents of Metropolis complain of flies and odors. An action has been filed by five individual homeowners who live within half a mile of the Cattle Company feed lot. The plaintiffs' homes are valued currently at $25,000 to $40,000 each. Flies in the area are five to ten times more numerous than in other parts of Metropolis, and extremely obnoxious odors are frequently carried by the wind to the plaintiffs' homes. The flies and odors are a substantial health hazard.
choices: prevail if plaintiffs sustained harm different from that suffered by the public at large
prevail if Cattle Company's acts interfered with any person's enjoyment of his property
not prevail, because only the state may bring an action based on public nuisance
not prevail, because plaintiffs came to the nuisance
reasoning_samples: A public nuisance is a condition or activity that substantially interferes with the health, safety, or welfare of the public. In this case, the plaintiffs are asserting a claim based on public nuisance, but they are not suing on behalf of the public at large. Instead, they are suing because they have individually suffered harm from the flies and odors. To prevail on a public nuisance claim, the plaintiffs must show that they have suffered harm different from that suffered by the public at large. This is because public nuisance is typically a claim brought by the state or local government to abate a condition or activity that affects the public as a whole. If the plaintiffs can show that they have suffered unique harm, such as damage to their property or health effects that are not experienced by the general public, they may be able to prevail on their public nuisance claim. Therefore, option A is the best answer.

question: If plaintiffs assert a claim based on private nuisance, plaintiffs will
prompt: In 1940, Cattle Company paid $30,000 for a 150-acre tract of agricultural land well suited for a cattle feed lot. The tract was ten miles from the city of Metropolis, then a community of 50,000 people, and five miles from the nearest home. By 1976, the city limits extended to Cattle Company's feed lot, and the city had a population of 350,000. About 10,000 people lived within three miles of the cattle feeding operation. The Cattle Company land is outside the city limits and no zoning ordinance applies. The Cattle Company land is now worth $300,000, and $25,000 has been invested in buildings and pens. Cattle Company, conscious of its obligations to its neighbors, uses the best and most sanitary feed lot procedures, including chemical sprays, to keep down flies and odors and frequently removes manure. Despite these measures, residents of Metropolis complain of flies and odors. An action has been filed by five individual homeowners who live within half a mile of the Cattle Company feed lot. The plaintiffs' homes are valued currently at $25,000 to $40,000 each. Flies in the area are five to ten times more numerous than in other parts of Metropolis, and extremely obnoxious odors are frequently carried by the wind to the plaintiffs' homes. The flies and odors are a substantial health hazard.
choices: prevail, because Cattle Company's activity unreasonably interfered with plaintiffs' use and enjoyment of their property
prevail, because Cattle Company's activity constitutes an inverse condemnation of their property
not prevail, because Cattle Company had operated the feed lot for more than 25 years
not prevail, because Cattle Company uses the most reasonable procedures to keep down flies and odors
reasoning_samples: To determine if the plaintiffs will prevail on their claim of private nuisance, we must consider the elements of a private nuisance claim. A private nuisance is a substantial, unreasonable interference with the use or enjoyment of one's property. In this case, the plaintiffs have alleged that the flies and odors from the Cattle Company's feed lot are a substantial health hazard and are interfering with their use and enjoyment of their property. The fact that the Cattle Company has taken reasonable measures to mitigate the problem, such as using chemical sprays and frequently removing manure, is relevant to the reasonableness of the interference, but it does not necessarily mean that the interference is reasonable. The key issue is whether the interference is substantial and unreasonable. Given the facts, it appears that the interference is substantial, as the flies and odors are a health hazard and are affecting the plaintiffs' use and enjoyment of their property. Therefore, the plaintiffs will prevail on their claim of private nuisance because the Cattle Company's activity unreasonably interfered with their use and enjoyment of their property.

question: Alan, who was already married, went through a marriage ceremony with Betty and committed bigamy. Carl, his friend, who did not know of Alan's previous marriage, had encouraged Alan to marry Betty and was best man at the ceremony, If Carl is charged with being an accessory to bigamy, he should be found
choices: not guilty, because his encouragement and assistance was not the legal cause of the crime
not guilty, because he did not have the mental state required for aiding and abetting
guilty, because he encouraged Alan, and his mistake as to the existence of a prior marriage is no defense to a charge of bigamy
guilty, because he was present when the crime occurred and is thus a principal in the second degree
reasoning_samples: To be found guilty of being an accessory to bigamy, Carl must have had the mental state required for aiding and abetting. This requires that Carl knowingly or recklessly assisted Alan in committing the crime. In this case, Carl did not know of Alan's previous marriage, and therefore did not have the necessary mental state to be found guilty of aiding and abetting. His mistake as to the existence of a prior marriage is a defense to a charge of being an accessory to bigamy.

question: Defendant was charged with murder. His principal defense was that he had killed in hot blood and should be guilty only of manslaughter. The judge instructed the jury that the state must prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt, that the killing was presumed to be murder, and that the charge could bereduced to manslaughter, and Defendant accordingly found guilty of this lesser offense, if Defendant showed by a fair preponderance of the evidence that the killing was committed in the heat of passion on sudden provocation. Defendant was convicted of murder. On appeal, he seeks a new trial and claims error in the judge's instructions to the jury. Defendant's conviction will most probably be
choices: affirmed, because the judge carefully advised the jury of the state's obligation to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt
affirmed, because Defendant's burden to show hot blood was not one of ultimate persuasion but only one of producing evidence to rebut a legitimate presumption
reversed, because the instruction put a burden on Defendant which denied him due process of law
reversed, because presumptions have a highly prejudicial effect and thus cannot be used on behalf of the state in a criminal case
reasoning_samples: The judge's instruction did not place a burden on the defendant to prove the existence of 'hot blood' by a preponderance of the evidence. Instead, it merely stated that the defendant could rebut the presumption of murder by showing that the killing was committed in the heat of passion on sudden provocation. This is a correct statement of the law, as the defendant's burden is not one of ultimate persuasion, but rather one of producing evidence to rebut a legitimate presumption. The instruction did not shift the burden of proof to the defendant, and thus did not deny him due process of law.

question: Darlene was arrested on a murder charge. She was given Miranda warnings and refused to talk further with the police. At trial, she testified in her own defense. She recounted in some detail her whereabouts on the day of the ci ime and explained why she could not have committed the crime. On cross-examination and over defense objection, the prosecution emphasized the fact that she did not tell the police this story following her arrest. The prosecution thereby suggested that her testimony was false. Defendant was convicted. On appeal, she claims error in the prosecutor's cross-examination. Her conviction will most probably be
choices: affirmed, because defendant's silence at time of arrest is tantamount to a prior inconsistent statement, giving rise to an inference that the story was fabricated
affirmed, because defendant's silence was not used as direct evidence but only for impeachment, a purpose consistent with legitimate cross-examination
reversed, because post-arrest silence constituted defendant's exercise of her Miranda rights and use of that silence against her at trial violated due process
reversed, because to require the defense to acquaint the prosecution with defendant's testimony prior to trial would constitute unconstitutional pre-trial discovery
reasoning_samples: The correct answer is A because the defendant's silence at the time of arrest can be considered a prior inconsistent statement. When the defendant testified at trial, she provided a detailed account of her whereabouts, which contradicts her initial silence at the time of arrest. This inconsistency can be used to impeach her testimony, raising an inference that her story was fabricated. The prosecution's cross-examination was permissible under the rules of evidence because it aimed to challenge the defendant's credibility, which is a legitimate purpose of cross-examination. The court has recognized this principle in various cases, including Harris v. New York (1971), where the Supreme Court held that a defendant's post-Miranda silence can be used to impeach their testimony.

question: Alice was held up at the point of a gun, an unusual revolver with a red-painted barrel, while she was clerking in a neighborhood grocery store. Dennis is charged with armed robbery of Alice. The prosecutor calls Winthrop to testify that, a week after the robbery of Alice, he was robbed by Dennis with a pistol that had red paint on the barrel. Winthrop's testimony is
choices: admissible as establishing an identifying circumstance
admissible as showing that Dennis was willing to commit robbery
inadmissible, because it is improper character evidence
inadmissible, because its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice
reasoning_samples: The testimony of Winthrop is admissible as establishing an identifying circumstance because it provides a unique characteristic of Dennis' gun, the red-painted barrel, which can be used to identify the gun used in the robbery of Alice. This type of evidence is considered relevant and probative, as it provides a distinctive feature that can help establish the identity of the gun. Therefore, Winthrop's testimony is admissible for this purpose, making option A the correct answer.

question: Maria is the owner and possessor of Goodacre, on which there is a lumber yard. Maria conveyed to Reliable Electric Company the right to construct and use an overhead electric line across Goodacre to serve other properties. The conveyance was in writing, but the writing made no provision concerning the responsibility for repair or maintenance of the line. Reliable installed the poles and erected the electric line in a proper and workmanlike manner. Neither Maria nor Reliable took any steps toward the maintenance or repair of the line after it was built. Neither party complained to the ocher about any failure to repair. Because of the failure to repair or properly maintain the line, it fell to the ground during a storm. In doing so, it caused a fire in the lumber yard and did considerable damage. Maria sued Reliable Electric Company to recover for damages to the lumber yard. The decision should be for
choices: Maria, because the owner of an easement has a duty to so maintain the easement as to avoid unreasonable interference with the use of the servient tenement by its lawful possessor
Maria, because the owner of an easement is absolutely liable for any damage caused to the servient tenement by the exercise of the easement
Reliable Electric Company, because the possessor of the servient tenement has a duty to give the easement holder notice of defective conditions
Reliable Electric Company, because an easement holder's right to repair is a right for his own benefit, and is therefore inconsistent with any duty to repair for the benefit of another
reasoning_samples: Maria, as the owner and possessor of the servient tenement (Goodacre), has a duty to maintain the easement in a way that does not unreasonably interfere with her own use of the property. This duty is implied by the nature of an easement, which is a non-possessory interest in land that allows one party to use another's property for a specific purpose. In this case, the easement was created for the benefit of Reliable Electric Company, but Maria's duty to maintain the easement is not limited to benefiting Reliable. Rather, it is a broader duty to ensure that the easement does not cause unreasonable harm to her own property. Since Maria failed to maintain the easement and it caused damage to her lumber yard, she is liable for the damages. Option A is the best answer because it accurately reflects the duty of a servient estate owner to maintain an easement in a way that does not unreasonably interfere with their own use of the property.

question: Seth owned a vacant lot known as Richacre. Seth entered into a written contract with Bob to build a house of stated specifications on Richacre and to sell the house and lot to Bob. The contract provided for an "inside date" of April 1, 1977, and an "outside date" of May 1, 1977, for completion of the house and delivery of a deed. Neither party tendered performance on the dates stated. On May 3, 1977, Bob notified Seth in writing of Bob's election to cancel the contract because of Seth's failure to deliver title by May 1. On May 12, Seth notified Bob that some unanticipated construction difficulties had been encountered but that Seth was entitled to a reasonable time to complete in any event. The notification also included a promise that Seth would be ready to perform by May 29 and that he was setting that date as an adjourned closing date. Seth obtained a certificate of occupancy and appropriate documents of title, and he tendered performance on May 29. Bob refused. Seth brought an action to recover damages for breach of contract. The decision in the case will most likely be determined by whether
choices: Seth acted with due diligence in completing the house
Bob can prove actual "undue hardship" caused by the delay
the expressions "inside date" and "outside date" are construed to make time of the essence
there Is a showing of good faith in Bob's efforts to terminate the contract
reasoning_samples: The key to this question lies in the interpretation of the contract's time provisions. The contract specifies an 'inside date' and an 'outside date' for completion of the house and delivery of a deed. The fact that neither party tendered performance on these dates suggests that time may be of the essence. If the court construes the expressions 'inside date' and 'outside date' to make time of the essence, then Bob's failure to accept the tender of performance on May 29 would be a breach of contract. In this scenario, Seth's action to recover damages for breach of contract would likely succeed. The other options are less relevant to the outcome of the case. Option A focuses on Seth's diligence, which, while important, is not the primary issue. Option B requires Bob to prove actual 'undue hardship,' which is not a necessary condition for Bob's breach. Option D, while relevant to the termination of the contract, is not the most critical factor in determining the outcome of the case.

question: Metterly, the owner in fee simple of Brownacre by quitclaim deed conveyed Brownacre to her daughter, Doris, who paid no consideration for the conveyance. The deed was never recorded. About a year after the delivery of the deed, Metterly decided that this gift had been ill-advised, She requested that Doris destroy the deed, which Doris dutifully and voluntarily did. Within the month following the destruction of the deed, Metterly and Doris were killed in a common disaster. Each of the successors in interest claimed title to Brownacre. In an appropriate action to determine the title to Brownacre, the probable outcome will be that
choices: Metterly was the owner of Brownacre, because Doris was a donee and therefore could not acquire title by quitclaim deed
Metterly was the owner of Brownacre, because title to Brownacre reverted to her upon the voluntary destruction of the deed by Doris
Doris was the owner of Brownacre, because her destruction of the deed to Brownacre was under the undue influence of Metterly
Doris was the owner of Brownacre, because the deed was merely evidence of her title, and its destruction was insufficient to cause title to pass back to Metterly
reasoning_samples: The destruction of the deed by Doris was insufficient to cause title to pass back to Metterly because a quitclaim deed is a type of deed that conveys whatever interest the grantor has in the property. Since Metterly was the owner in fee simple of Brownacre, she had the entire interest in the property. When she conveyed it to Doris, she conveyed her entire interest, leaving her with no interest to pass back to her. The destruction of the deed was merely the destruction of evidence of the conveyance, and did not affect the underlying ownership of the property. Therefore, Doris remains the owner of Brownacre.

question: If Motorist asserts a claim against Cross, Motorist will
prompt: Motorist arranged to borrow his friend Owner's car to drive for one day while Motorist's car was being repaired. Owner knew that the brakes on his car were faulty and might fail in an emergency. Owner forgot to tell Motorist about the brakes when Motorist picked up the car, but Owner did telephone Spouse, Motorist's wife, and told her about them. Spouse, however, forgot to tell Motorist. Motorist was driving Owner's car at a reasonable rate of speed and within the posted speed limit, with Spouse as passenger. Another car, driven by Cross, crossed in front of Motorist at an intersection and in violation of the traffic signal. Motorist tried to stop, but the brakes failed, and the two cars collided. If the brakes had been in proper working order, Motorist could have stopped in time to avoid the collision. Motorist and Spouse were injured.
choices: recover the full amount of his damages, because Motorist himself was not at fault
recover only a proportion of his damages, because Spouse was also at fault
not recover, because Spouse was negligent and a wife's negligence is imputed to her husband
not recover, because the failure of the brakes was the immediate cause of the collision
reasoning_samples: Motorist will recover the full amount of his damages. This is because Motorist himself was not at fault in the accident. The failure of the brakes was the immediate cause of the collision; however, Motorist's actions were reasonable given the circumstances. The negligence of Cross, who violated the traffic signal, was the proximate cause of the injury. Motorist's reliance on Spouse, who was also injured, to inform him about the faulty brakes does not make him liable for Spouse's negligence, as the issue is the immediate and proximate cause of the accident. Thus, Motorist's lack of knowledge about the faulty brakes does not make him contributorily negligent. Therefore, he will recover the full amount of his damages from Cross.

question: If the jurisdiction has adopted "pure" comparative negligence and Spouse asserts a claim against Cross, Spouse will
prompt: Motorist arranged to borrow his friend Owner's car to drive for one day while Motorist's car was being repaired. Owner knew that the brakes on his car were faulty and might fail in an emergency. Owner forgot to tell Motorist about the brakes when Motorist picked up the car, but Owner did telephone Spouse, Motorist's wife, and told her about them. Spouse, however, forgot to tell Motorist. Motorist was driving Owner's car at a reasonable rate of speed and within the posted speed limit, with Spouse as passenger. Another car, driven by Cross, crossed in front of Motorist at an intersection and in violation of the traffic signal. Motorist tried to stop, but the brakes failed, and the two cars collided. If the brakes had been in proper working order, Motorist could have stopped in time to avoid the collision. Motorist and Spouse were injured.
choices: recover in full for her injuries, because Motorist, who was driving the car in which she was riding, was not himself at fault
recover a proportion of her damages based on the respective degrees of her negligence and that of Cross
not recover, because but for the failure of the brakes the collision would not have occurred
not recover, because she was negligent and her negligence continued until the moment of impact
reasoning_samples: In a pure comparative negligence jurisdiction, a plaintiff's recovery is reduced by their percentage of fault, but they are still entitled to recover some damages. Since Spouse was not driving the car and did not have control over the brakes, she cannot be held negligent for the failure of the brakes. Therefore, she is not contributorily negligent and her recovery will not be reduced by any percentage of fault. Option A is the best answer because it accurately reflects the application of pure comparative negligence to the facts of this case.

question: If Motorist asserts a claim against Owner, will Motorist prevail?
prompt: Motorist arranged to borrow his friend Owner's car to drive for one day while Motorist's car was being repaired. Owner knew that the brakes on his car were faulty and might fail in an emergency. Owner forgot to tell Motorist about the brakes when Motorist picked up the car, but Owner did telephone Spouse, Motorist's wife, and told her about them. Spouse, however, forgot to tell Motorist. Motorist was driving Owner's car at a reasonable rate of speed and within the posted speed limit, with Spouse as passenger. Another car, driven by Cross, crossed in front of Motorist at an intersection and in violation of the traffic signal. Motorist tried to stop, but the brakes failed, and the two cars collided. If the brakes had been in proper working order, Motorist could have stopped in time to avoid the collision. Motorist and Spouse were injured.
choices: Yes, in negligence, because Owner knew the brakes were faulty and failed to tell Motorist.
Yes, in strict liability in tort, because the car was defective and Owner lent it to Motorist.
No, because Owner was a gratuitous lender, and thus his duty of care was slight.
No, because the failure of Spouse to tell Motorist about the brakes was the cause in fact of Motorist's harm.
reasoning_samples: Motorist's claim against Owner will likely prevail under negligence because Owner owed a duty of care to Motorist, and it is reasonable to expect him to inform Motorist of a known defect in the vehicle. Owner's failure to disclose the faulty brakes was a breach of this duty, which led to Motorist's injuries. The fact that Owner's wife, Spouse, was also informed about the brakes does not negate Owner's responsibility as Motorist's knowledge about the brakes was not provided. Furthermore, Owner's action of telling Spouse, but not Motorist, cannot be seen as a reasonable exercise of his duty of care as a vehicle owner.

question: In which of the following situations is Defendant most likely to be guilty of larceny?
choices: Defendant took Sue's television set, with the intention of returning it the next day. However, he dropped it and damaged it beyond repair.
Defendant went into Tom's house and took $100 in the belief that Tom had damaged Defendant's car to that amount.
Mistakenly believing that larceny does not include the taking of a dog, Defendant took his neighbor's dog and sold it.
Unreasonably mistaking George's car for his own, Defendant got into George's car in a parking lot and drove it home.
reasoning_samples: In option A, Defendant took Sue's television set with the intention of returning it the next day. Since he did not intend to permanently deprive Sue of the property, it would seem like he is not guilty of larceny. However, the question states that he 'dropped it and damaged it beyond repair.' This indicates a change in circumstances. The original intention was to return the TV, but now it's impossible to do so. This situation satisfies the elements of larceny, as Defendant has taken property with the intention of permanently depriving the owner, and the circumstances have changed to make that intention a reality. In contrast, options B, C, and D either lack the intention to deprive the owner, involve a mistaken belief, or lack the element of taking property with the intention of permanently depriving the owner.

question: Acting on an anonymous telephone call, police went to Desmond's apartment, knocked on the door, and demanded to search it for narcotics. When Desmond refused, the police forced the door open and placed him under arrest. As they were removing him from the apartment, Desmond offered to give the officers "valuable information" in exchange for his release. Before he could say anything else, Desmond was given Miranda warnings by the police. Thereafter he told the police that he had stored some heroin in his friend's apartment and that he and his friend had been going to sell it. The heroin was recovered, and Desmond was prosecuted for conspiracy to sell narcotics and for possession of narcotics. At his trial, Desmond moved to suppress his statements. Which of the following is Desmond's best argument in support of the motion to suppress?
choices: Desmond is entitled to know the identity of his accuser, and the state cannot supply this information.
The police should have given Desmond Miranda warnings prior to entry into the apartment, and the warnings were ineffectual once Desmond offered to give the police information.
Desmond was intimidated by the forced entry into the apartment, and since the statements were involuntary and coerced, their use against him would violate due process of law.

The statements were fruits of an unlawful arrest, and though the Miranda warnings may have been sufficient to protect his right against self-incrimination, they were not sufficient to purge the taint of the illegal arrest.
reasoning_samples: Desmond's best argument in support of the motion to suppress is that the police should have given him Miranda warnings prior to entry into the apartment, and the warnings were ineffectual once Desmond offered to give the police information. This is because the police's forced entry into the apartment was a custodial interrogation, which triggers the requirement for Miranda warnings. Since the police did not provide Miranda warnings prior to the entry, Desmond's statements made after the entry should be suppressed. Additionally, even if Miranda warnings were given after Desmond offered to give the police information, the warnings were ineffectual because they were given after Desmond had already been subjected to the coercive effects of the police's forced entry into the apartment.

question: Which of the following is the strongest constitutional argument supporting Kane?
prompt: Kane, a member of the legislature of State, is prosecuted in federal court for a violation of the Federal Securities Act arising out of the activities of a state-owned corporation. Kane's defense includes a claim that the alleged wrongful acts were committed in the course of legislative business and are immune from scrutiny.
choices: Because of doctrines of federalism, federal law generally cannot be applied to state legislators acting in the course of their official duties.
State legislators enjoy the protection of the speech and debate clause of the United States Constitution.
A federal court must follow state law respecting the scope of legislative immunity.
To apply the Federal Securities Act to state legislators would violate the due process clause.
reasoning_samples: The strongest constitutional argument supporting Kane is rooted in the principles of federalism. The Supremacy Clause (Article VI, Clause 2) establishes that federal law is the supreme law of the land, but it does not necessarily imply that federal law can be applied to state legislators acting in the course of their official duties. The Eleventh Amendment and the principles of federalism suggest that federal courts should be cautious when applying federal law to state officials. In particular, the Supreme Court has held that federal courts should not interfere with the internal operations of state governments, as seen in cases such as Fitzpatrick v. Bitzer (1976). Therefore, option A is the strongest constitutional argument supporting Kane, as it highlights the limitations of federal authority over state officials acting in their official capacities.

question: Which of the following is the strongest argument against Kane's constitutional defense?
prompt: Kane, a member of the legislature of State, is prosecuted in federal court for a violation of the Federal Securities Act arising out of the activities of a state-owned corporation. Kane's defense includes a claim that the alleged wrongful acts were committed in the course of legislative business and are immune from scrutiny.
choices: Congress has plenary power under the commerce clause.
Congress may impose liability on state legislators as a means of guaranteeing a republican form of government.
Congress does not significantly interfere with state government by applying this law to state legislators.
Congress may impose liability on state legislators by virtue of the necessary and proper clause.
reasoning_samples: The strongest argument against Kane's constitutional defense is that Congress may impose liability on state legislators as a means of guaranteeing a republican form of government. This argument is based on the idea that the federal government has a responsibility to ensure that state governments function in a manner consistent with the principles of a republican form of government. By holding state legislators accountable for their actions under the Federal Securities Act, Congress is able to ensure that state governments are transparent and accountable to their citizens. This argument is particularly strong because it is grounded in the idea that the federal government has a constitutional duty to protect the rights of citizens and ensure that state governments function in a manner that is consistent with the principles of a republican form of government.

question: The description of 44 Main Street was
prompt: By way of a gift, Pat executed a deed naming his daughter, Marian, as grantee. The deed contained descriptions as follows: (1) All of my land and dwelling known as 44 Main Street, Midtown, United States, being one acre. (2) All that part of my farm, being a square with 200foot sides, the southeast corner of which is in the north line of my neighbor, Julia Brown. The deed contained covenants of general warranty, quiet enjoyment, and right to convey. Pat handed the deed to Marian who immediately returned it to her father for safekeeping. Her father kept it in his safe deposit box. The deed was not recorded. The property at 44 Main Street covered 7/8 of an acre of land, had a dwelling and a garage situate thereon, and was subject to a right of way, described in prior deeds, in favor of Jack, a neighbor. Pat owned no other land on Main Street. Jack had not used the right of way for ten years and it was not visible on inspection of the property.
choices: sufficient, because the discrepancy in area is not fatal
not sufficient, because it contained no metes and bounds
Not sufficient, because the acreage given was not correct
Not sufficient, because a deed purporting to convey more than a grantor owns is void ab initio
reasoning_samples: The description of 44 Main Street is sufficient because it provides a clear and identifiable location of the property. Although the acreage given in the deed (one acre) is different from the actual acreage (7/8 of an acre), this discrepancy is not fatal to the description. The description also includes the location of the property (44 Main Street, Midtown, United States) and a physical description of the property (dwelling and garage). The fact that the property is subject to a right of way in favor of Jack, a neighbor, does not affect the sufficiency of the description. Therefore, option A is the best answer because it recognizes that the discrepancy in area is not fatal to the description.

question: The description of part of Pat's farm
prompt: By way of a gift, Pat executed a deed naming his daughter, Marian, as grantee. The deed contained descriptions as follows: (1) All of my land and dwelling known as 44 Main Street, Midtown, United States, being one acre. (2) All that part of my farm, being a square with 200foot sides, the southeast corner of which is in the north line of my neighbor, Julia Brown. The deed contained covenants of general warranty, quiet enjoyment, and right to convey. Pat handed the deed to Marian who immediately returned it to her father for safekeeping. Her father kept it in his safe deposit box. The deed was not recorded. The property at 44 Main Street covered 7/8 of an acre of land, had a dwelling and a garage situate thereon, and was subject to a right of way, described in prior deeds, in favor of Jack, a neighbor. Pat owned no other land on Main Street. Jack had not used the right of way for ten years and it was not visible on inspection of the property.
choices: is sufficient if consideration has been paid
is sufficient because no ambiguity therein appears on the face of the deed
