In the course of the remodeling job, one of Glass's employees turned on the air conditioning and caused fumes from the glue to travel from Glass through the air conditioning unit and into Innes' office. The employees did not know that there was common ductwork for the air conditioners. Innes was permanently blinded by the fumes from the glue. The label on the container of glue read, "DANGER. Do not smoke near this product. Extremely flammable. Contains Butanone, Toluol and Hexane. Use with adequate ventilation. Keep out of the reach of children." The three chemicals listed on the label are very toxic and harmful to human eyes. Steel had received no reports of eye injuries during the ten years that the Product had been manufactured and sold.
choices: recover, because a user of a product is held to the same standard as the manufacturer
recover, because the employees of Glass caused the fumes to enter her area of the building
not recover, because Glass used the glue for its intended purposes
not recover, because the employees of Glass had no reason to know that the fumes could injure Innes
reasoning_samples: Innes is likely to recover because she is asserting a claim against Steel, as the manufacturer of the glue, through the theory of products liability. The most relevant theory of liability in this situation is strict liability, which holds manufacturers liable for any harm caused by their products, regardless of fault. However, since Innes is claiming against Steel through the actions of Glass, the theory of vicarious liability (also known as respondeat superior) applies, which holds an employer liable for the actions of their employees if those actions are within the scope of their employment. Innes' claim is most likely to succeed under the theory of strict liability, as Steel is the primary responsible party for the harm caused by the glue. This theory is most relevant to the facts of the case because it focuses on the product itself, rather than the actions of Glass. Therefore, Innes is most likely to recover because a user of a product is held to the same standard as the manufacturer, as the glue was used in its intended manner and Steel failed to provide adequate warnings or warnings regarding the potential dangers of using the product in a confined space.

question: In an action by Esther against Miller on account of the executor's repudiation of Gray's promise to pay future tuition, room, and board, which of the following would be Miller's strongest defense?
prompt: When Esther, Gray's 21-year-old daughter, finished college, Gray handed her a signed memorandum stating that if she would go to law school for three academic years, he would pay her tuition, room, and board and would "give her a $1,000 bonus" for each "A" she got in law school. Esther's uncle, Miller, who was present on this occasion, read the memorandum and thereupon said to Esther, "and if he doesn't pay your expenses, I will." Gray paid her tuition, room, and board for her first year but died just before the end of that year. Subsequently, Esther learned that she had received two "A's" in the second semester. The executor of Gray's estate has refused to pay her anything for the two "A's" and has told her that the estate will no longer pay her tuition, room, and board in law school.
choices: The parties did not manifestly intend a contract.
Gray's death terminated the agreement.
The agreement was oral.
The agreement was divisible.
reasoning_samples: Miller's strongest defense would be that Gray's death terminated the agreement. This is because the memorandum promised to pay for three academic years, and Gray's death occurred before the end of the first year. Since the agreement was for a specific period of time, Gray's death would terminate the agreement, making it unenforceable. This defense is stronger than the other options because it directly addresses the issue of the agreement's enforceability, whereas the other options may not be as directly relevant to the facts of the case.

question: In an action against Gray's estate for $2,000 on account of the two "A's," if the only defense raised is lack of consideration, Esther probably will
prompt: When Esther, Gray's 21-year-old daughter, finished college, Gray handed her a signed memorandum stating that if she would go to law school for three academic years, he would pay her tuition, room, and board and would "give her a $1,000 bonus" for each "A" she got in law school. Esther's uncle, Miller, who was present on this occasion, read the memorandum and thereupon said to Esther, "and if he doesn't pay your expenses, I will." Gray paid her tuition, room, and board for her first year but died just before the end of that year. Subsequently, Esther learned that she had received two "A's" in the second semester. The executor of Gray's estate has refused to pay her anything for the two "A's" and has told her that the estate will no longer pay her tuition, room, and board in law school.
choices: succeed under the doctrine of promissory estoppel
succeed on a theory of bargained-for exchange for her father's promise
not succeed, because the $1,000 for each "A" was promised only as a bonus
not succeed, because Esther was already legally obligated to use her best efforts in law school
reasoning_samples: Esther's promise to use her best efforts in law school is implied, but it is not a bargained-for exchange for her father's promise. The doctrine of promissory estoppel, however, can be applied here because Gray's promise to pay Esther $1,000 for each 'A' she received in law school was made with the expectation that Esther would rely on it. Esther did rely on it by attending law school and receiving two 'A's. Since Gray's estate has refused to honor the promise, Esther can argue that she has been injured and that Gray's estate should be estopped from denying the promise. This is a more compelling argument than a bargained-for exchange, which would require a clear quid pro quo. Furthermore, the fact that Gray's estate has already paid Esther's tuition, room, and board for her first year suggests that they initially intended to honor the promise, making promissory estoppel a more likely outcome.

question: In Polk's negligence action against Dell arising out of a multiple-car collision, Witt testified for Polk that Dell went through a red light. On crossexamination, Dell seeks to question Witt about her statement that the light was yellow, made in a deposition that Witt gave in a separate action between Adams and Baker. The transcript of the deposition is self-authenticating. On proper objection, the court should rule the inquiry
choices: admissible for impeachment only
admissible as substantive evidence only
admissible for impeachment and as substantive evidence
inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any exception
reasoning_samples: The statement made by Witt in the deposition is hearsay, as it is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted (that the light was yellow). However, it can be used for impeachment purposes under Federal Rule of Evidence 806, which allows for the impeachment of a witness who is testifying as an expert or a lay witness. Since Witt is testifying as a lay witness, her prior inconsistent statement can be used to impeach her credibility. The statement is not admissible as substantive evidence because it does not meet the requirements of any hearsay exception. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as the statement is admissible for impeachment only.

question: In 1965 Hubert Green executed his will which in pertinent part provided, "I hereby give, devise, and bequeath Greenvale to my surviving widow for life, remainder to such of my children as shall live to attain the age of 30 years, but if any child dies under the age of 30 years survived by a child or children, such child or children shall take and receive the share which his, her, or their parent would have received had such parent lived to attain the age of 30 years." At the date of writing his will, Green was married to Susan, and they had two children, Allan and Beth. Susan died in 1970 and Hubert married Waverly in 1972. At his death in 1980, Green was survived by his wife, Waverly, and three children, Allan, Beth, and Carter. Carter, who was born in 1974, was his child by Waverly. In a jurisdiction which recognizes the common-law Rule Against Perpetuities unmodified by statute, the result of the application of the rule is that the
choices: remainder to the children and to the grandchildren is void because Green could have subsequently married a person who was unborn at the time Green executed his will
remainder to the children is valid, but the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren is void because Green could have subsequently married a person who was unborn at the time Green executed his will
gift in remainder to Allan and Beth or their children is valid, but the gift to Carter or his children is void
remainder to the children and the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren are valid
reasoning_samples: The Rule Against Perpetuities (RAP) states that no interest is good unless it must vest, if at all, not later than 21 years after some life in being at the creation of the interest. In this case, the remainder to the children and the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren are contingent on the children attaining the age of 30. However, the RAP is violated because it is possible that a child could be born after the execution of the will and die before attaining the age of 30, leaving a grandchild who would inherit the share. This creates a possibility of a grandchild inheriting more than 21 years after the death of the testator, thus violating the RAP. Therefore, the remainder to the children and the substitutionary gift to the grandchildren are void.

question: Siddon worked as a private duty nurse and on occasion worked in Doctors' Hospital. The hospital called Registry, the private duty referral agency through which Siddon usually obtained employment, and asked that in the future she not be assigned to patients in Doctors' Hospital. Registry asked the hospital why it had made the request. Doctors' Hospital sent a letter to Registry giving as the reason for its request that significant amounts of narcotics had disappeared during Siddon's shifts from the nursing stations at which she had worked. If Siddon asserts a claim based on defamation against Doctors' Hospital, Siddon will
choices: recover, because the hospital accused Siddon of improper professional conduct
recover if Siddon did not take the narcotics
not recover if narcotics disappeared during Siddon's shifts
not recover if the hospital reasonably believed that Siddon took the narcotics
reasoning_samples: To determine whether Siddon can recover on a defamation claim, we must first establish whether the hospital's statement constitutes defamation. Defamation is a false statement of fact that harms the plaintiff's reputation. In this case, the hospital's statement that significant amounts of narcotics disappeared during Siddon's shifts is a statement of fact. The hospital's reason for not wanting Siddon to work at their hospital is that they believe she is responsible for the missing narcotics. This statement accuses Siddon of improper professional conduct, specifically theft. Since the statement is a statement of fact and accuses Siddon of a serious professional misconduct, it is actionable as defamation per se. Therefore, Siddon can recover on her defamation claim because the hospital accused her of improper professional conduct.

question: Cycle Company manufactured a bicycle that it sold to Bike Shop, a retail bicycle dealer, which in turn sold it to Roth. Shortly thereafter, while Roth was riding the bicycle along a city street, he saw a traffic light facing him turn from green to amber. He sped up, hoping to cross the intersection before the light turned red. However, Roth quickly realized that he could not do so and applied the brake, which failed. To avoid the traffic that was then crossing in front of him, Roth turned sharply to his right and onto the sidewalk, where he struck P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez, a pedestrian. Both P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez and Roth sustained injuries. If P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez asserts a claim based on negligence against Cycle Company and if it is found that the brake failure resulted from a manufacturing defect in the bicycle, will P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez prevail?
choices: Yes, because Cycle Company placed a defective bicycle into the stream of commerce.
Yes, if the defect could have been discovered through the exercise of reasonable care by Cycle Company.
No, because P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez was not a purchaser of the bicycle.
No, if Roth was negligent in turning into the sidewalk.
reasoning_samples: P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez will prevail because Cycle Company, as the manufacturer, placed a defective bicycle into the stream of commerce. This is because the manufacturer has a duty to exercise reasonable care to ensure that their products do not cause harm to others. In this case, the brake failure was a direct result of the manufacturing defect, demonstrating a breach of that duty. Additionally, the fact that Roth was riding the bicycle at the time of the accident does not absolve Cycle Company of liability, as the defect in the bicycle is the proximate cause of the harm to P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez. The other options are incorrect because option B is an incorrect statement of the standard of care for manufacturers, option C is irrelevant because P๏ฟฝ๏ฟฝrez's status as a purchaser is not the relevant factor in determining liability, and option D is incorrect because it would be an error to shift the burden of liability from the manufacturer to the consumer.

question: A federal statute sets up a program of dental education. The statute provides that the Secretary of Health and Human Services "shall, on a current basis, spend all of the money appropriated for this purpose" and "shall distribute the appropriated funds" by a specified formula to state health departments that agree I to participate in the program. In the current year I Congress has appropriated $100 million for expenditure on this program. In order to ensure a budget surplus in the current fiscal year, the President issues an executive order directing the various cabinet secretaries to cut expenditures in this year by 10 percent in all categories. He also orders certain programs to be cut more drastically because he believes that "they are not as important to the general welfare as other programs" The President identifies the dental education program as such a program and orders it to be cut by 50 percent. Assume that no other federal statutes are relevant. To satisfy constitutional requirements, how much money must the Secretary of Health and Human Services distribute for the dental education program this year?
choices: $50 million, because the President could reasonably determine that this program is not as important to the general welfare as other programs
$50 million, because as chief executive the President has the constitutional authority to control the actions of all of his subordinates by executive order
$90 million, because any more drastic cut for the program would be a denial of equal protection to beneficiaries of this program as compared to beneficiaries of other programs
$100 million, because the President may not unilaterally suspend the effect of a valid federal statute imposing a duty to spend appropriated monies
reasoning_samples: The President's executive order attempting to cut the dental education program by 50% is unconstitutional because it unilaterally suspends the effect of a valid federal statute imposing a duty to spend appropriated monies. The statute explicitly states that the Secretary of Health and Human Services 'shall, on a current basis, spend all of the money appropriated for this purpose.' This mandatory spending provision is a valid exercise of Congress's spending power, and the President does not have the authority to override it through an executive order. Therefore, the Secretary of Health and Human Services must distribute the full $100 million appropriated for the dental education program this year.

question: Powers sued Debbs for battery. At trial, Powers' witness Wilson testified that Debbs had made an unprovoked attack on Powers. On cross-examination, Debbs asks Wilson about a false claim that Wilson had once filed on an insurance policy. The question is
choices: proper, because the conduct involved untruthfulness
proper provided that the conduct resulted in conviction of Wilson
improper, because the impeachment involved a specific instance of misconduct
improper, because the claim form would be the best evidence
reasoning_samples: Debbs is attempting to impeach Wilson's credibility by questioning him about a false claim he made on an insurance policy. Under Rule 608(b) of the Federal Rules of Evidence, a witness may be cross-examined as to any act of dishonesty or false statement. The claim form would be considered a false statement, and therefore, Debbs' question is proper. This is because the question is aimed at highlighting Wilson's propensity for dishonesty, which is relevant to his testimony on the stand. A, C, and D are incorrect because A addresses the proper basis for impeachment, C is incorrect because a specific instance of misconduct is allowed if it shows a trait of untruthfulness, and D is incorrect because the claim form would be considered hearsay, not the best evidence.

question: Which of the following correctly states Byco's rights and obligations immediately after receipt of Selco's notice on May 10?
prompt: On May 1, Selco and Byco entered into a written agreement in which Selco agreed to fabricate and sell to Byco 10,000 specially designed brake linings for a new type of power brake manufactured by Byco. The contract provided that Byco would pay half of the purchase price on May 15 in order to give Selco funds to "tool up" for the work; that Selco would deliver 5,000 brake linings on May 31; that Byco would pay the balance of the purchase price on June 15; and that Selco would deliver the balance of the brake linings on June 30. On May 10, Selco notified Byco that it was doubtful whether Selco could perform because of problems encountered in modifying its production machines to produce the brake linings. On May 15, however, Selco assured Byco that the production difficulties had been overcome, and Byco paid Selco the first 50 percent installment of the purchase price. Selco did not deliver the first 5,000 brake linings on May 31, or at any time thereafter; and on June 10, Selco notified Byco that it would not perform the contract.
choices: Byco can treat the notice as an anticipatory repudiation, and has a cause of action on May 10 for breach of the entire contract.
Byco can treat the notice as an anticipatory repudiation, and can sue at once to enjoin an actual breach by Selco on May 31.
Byco has no cause of action for breach of contract, but can suspend its performance and demand assurances that Selco will perform.
Byco has no cause of action for breach of contract, and must pay the installment of the purchase price due on May 15 to preserve its rights under the contract.
reasoning_samples: Selco's notice on May 10, stating that it was doubtful whether Selco could perform, constitutes an unequivocal statement of inability or unwillingness to perform, which is a clear manifestation of an intention not to perform. This is considered an anticipatory repudiation, which allows Byco to treat the repudiation as a total breach of the contract and bring an action for breach of the entire contract immediately. This is because an anticipatory repudiation is considered a manifestation of a present intention not to perform, which is equivalent to a present refusal to perform. Therefore, Byco can treat the notice as an anticipatory repudiation and has a cause of action on May 10 for breach of the entire contract.

question: Which of the following is NOT a correct statement of the parties' legal status immediately after Selco's notice on June 10?
prompt: On May 1, Selco and Byco entered into a written agreement in which Selco agreed to fabricate and sell to Byco 10,000 specially designed brake linings for a new type of power brake manufactured by Byco. The contract provided that Byco would pay half of the purchase price on May 15 in order to give Selco funds to "tool up" for the work; that Selco would deliver 5,000 brake linings on May 31; that Byco would pay the balance of the purchase price on June 15; and that Selco would deliver the balance of the brake linings on June 30. On May 10, Selco notified Byco that it was doubtful whether Selco could perform because of problems encountered in modifying its production machines to produce the brake linings. On May 15, however, Selco assured Byco that the production difficulties had been overcome, and Byco paid Selco the first 50 percent installment of the purchase price. Selco did not deliver the first 5,000 brake linings on May 31, or at any time thereafter; and on June 10, Selco notified Byco that it would not perform the contract.
choices: Byco has a cause of action for total breach of contract because of Selco's repudiation, but that cause of action will be lost if Selco retracts its repudiation before Byco changes its position or manifests to Selco that Byco considers the repudiation final.
Byco can bring suit to rescind the contract even if it elects to await Selco's performance for a commercially reasonable time.

Byco can await performance by Selco for a commercially reasonable time, but if Byco awaits performance beyond that period, it cannot recover any resulting damages that it reasonably could have avoided.
Byco has a cause of action for breach of contract that it can successfully assert only after it has given Selco a commercially reasonable time to perform.
reasoning_samples: Selco's June 10 notice stating that it would not perform the contract constitutes a repudiation that gives Byco an immediate right to rescind the contract. However, a repudiation does not automatically entitle the non-repudiating party to rescind the contract. Byco must still provide Selco with a commercially reasonable time to perform before rescinding the contract. Thus, option B is the statement that is NOT a correct statement of the parties' legal status immediately after Selco's notice on June 10.

question: A state statute provides that persons moving into a community to attend a college on a full-time basis may not vote in any elections for local or state officials that are held in that community. Instead, the statute provides that for voting purposes all such persons shall retain their residence in the community from which they came. In that state the age of majority is eighteen. Which of the following is the strongest argument to demonstrate the unconstitutionality of this state statute?
choices: A state does not have an interest that is sufficiently compelling to justify the exclusion from voting of an entire class of persons.
There are less restrictive means by which the state could assure that only actual residents of a community vote in its elections.
Most persons moving to a community to attend college full-time are likely to have attained the age of majority under the laws of this state.
On its face this statute impermissibly discriminates against interstate commerce.
reasoning_samples: The strongest argument to demonstrate the unconstitutionality of this state statute is that a state does not have an interest that is sufficiently compelling to justify the exclusion from voting of an entire class of persons. This is because the statute disenfranchises individuals who have moved to the community solely for educational purposes, without any evidence that they pose a threat to the community or its interests. The U.S. Supreme Court has held that the right to vote is a fundamental right protected by the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. In order to justify a law that restricts this right, the state must demonstrate a compelling interest. In this case, the state has not provided any evidence of a compelling interest that would justify disenfranchising individuals who have moved to the community for educational purposes. Therefore, the strongest argument against the statute is that the state does not have a sufficiently compelling interest to justify the exclusion from voting of an entire class of persons.

question: At a time when Ogawa held Lot 1 in the Fairoaks subdivision in fee simple, Vine executed a warranty deed that recited that Vine conveyed Lot 1, Fairoaks, to Purvis. The deed was promptly and duly recorded. After the recording of the deed from Vine to Purvis, Ogawa conveyed Lot I to Vine by a warranty deed that was promptly and duly recorded. Later, Vine conveyed the property to Rand by warranty deed and the deed was promptly and duly recorded. Rand paid the fair market value of Lot 1 and had no knowledge of any claim of Purvis. In an appropriate action, Rand and Purvis contest title to Lot 1. In this action, judgment should be for
choices: Purvis, because Purvis' deed is senior to Rand's
Rand, because Rand paid value without notice of Purvis' claim
Purvis or Rand, depending on whether a subsequent grantee is bound, at common law, by the doctrine of estoppel by deed
Purvis or Rand, depending on whether Purvis' deed is deemed recorded in Rand's chain of title
reasoning_samples: The key to this question lies in understanding the concept of constructive notice in land law. When a deed is recorded, it provides constructive notice to subsequent purchasers of the existence of the prior conveyance. However, the doctrine of constructive notice only applies to those who are in the chain of title. In this case, Rand's chain of title only includes the conveyance from Vine, and not the prior conveyance from Vine to Purvis. Therefore, Rand is not charged with constructive notice of Purvis' claim. However, the question of whether Purvis' deed is deemed recorded in Rand's chain of title is crucial. If Purvis' deed is deemed recorded in Rand's chain of title, then Rand would have constructive notice of Purvis' claim and would be bound by the prior conveyance. This would mean that Purvis has priority over Rand. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as it depends on whether Purvis' deed is deemed recorded in Rand's chain of title.

question: Dillon held up a gasoline station. During the robbery he shot and killed a customer who attempted to apprehend him. Dillon was prosecuted for premeditated murder and convicted. Thereafter, he was indicted for armed robbery of the station. Before the trial, his attorney moved to dismiss the indictment on the ground that further proceedings were unconstitutional because of Dillon's prior conviction. The motion to dismiss should be
choices: granted, because once Dillon was convicted on any of the charges arising out of the robbery, the prosecution was constitutionally estopped from proceeding against Dillon on any charge stemming from the same transaction
granted, because the double jeopardy clause prohibits a subsequent trial on what is essentially a lesser included offense
denied, because there is no constitutional requirement that all known charges against Dillon be brought in the same prosecution
denied, because estoppel does not apply when the defendant is charged with violating two different statutes
reasoning_samples: The double jeopardy clause prohibits the prosecution from retrying a defendant for the same offense after an acquittal or conviction. However, in this case, the armed robbery charge is a separate offense from the premeditated murder charge. Although both charges arise from the same transaction, they are distinct crimes with different elements. Therefore, the prosecution is not barred from proceeding with the armed robbery charge. Option A is incorrect because it misapplies the concept of constitutional estoppel, which is not relevant in this scenario. Option B is incorrect because the armed robbery charge is not a lesser included offense of premeditated murder. Option D is incorrect because estoppel is not applicable when the defendant is charged with violating different statutes.

question: Ellis, an electrical engineer, designed an electronic game known as Zappo. Ellis entered into a licensing agreement with Toyco under which Toyco agreed to manufacture Zappo according to Ellis' specifications and to market it and pay a royalty to Ellis. Carla, whose parents had purchased a Zappo game for her, was injured while playing with the game. Carla recovered a judgment against Toyco on the basis of a finding that the Zappo game was defective because of Ellis' improper design. In a claim for indemnity against Ellis, will Toyco prevail?
choices: Yes, because as between Ellis and Toyco, Ellis was responsible for the design of Zappo.
Yes, because Toyco and Ellis were joint tortfeasors.
No, because Toyco, as the manufacturer, was strictly liable to Carla.
No, if Toyco, by a reasonable inspection, could have discovered the defect in the design of Zappo.
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, Ellis and Toyco entered into a licensing agreement where Ellis retained control over the design of Zappo. As the designer, Ellis is responsible for any defects in the design. Toyco's role was limited to manufacturing and marketing the game according to Ellis' specifications. Therefore, as between Ellis and Toyco, Ellis is responsible for the defective design, and Toyco can seek indemnification from Ellis. This is based on the principle of vicarious liability, where one party is held responsible for the actions of another. In this case, Ellis is vicariously liable for the defective design, and Toyco can seek indemnity from Ellis.

question: The Prindles have lived in their residential neighborhood for many years. Delbrook moved into the house next door and brought with him six hives of bees, from which he gathers honey for his own use. It is not possible for Delbrook to confine the bees to his property, and the bees settle on the Prindles' flowers and bushes in such numbers that it is impossible for the Prindles to use their yard freely. The Prindles no longer enter their garden for fear of being stung by the bees. In a claim against Delbrook, will the Prindles prevail?
choices: No, if beekeeping on Delbrook's land was not prohibited by local ordinance.
No, unless the Prindles have been physically harmed by the bees.
Yes, because Delbrook's bees intruded on the Prindles property.
Yes, because the Prindles cannot make normal use of their garden.
reasoning_samples: The Prindles' claim against Delbrook is based on nuisance, which is an interference with the use and enjoyment of one's property. However, the key factor in determining whether a nuisance exists is whether the interference is substantial and unreasonable. In this case, the fact that the Prindles can no longer use their garden freely due to the bees may be considered a substantial interference. However, the reasonableness of the interference is also a crucial factor. If beekeeping on Delbrook's land was not prohibited by local ordinance, it can be argued that Delbrook's use of his property is reasonable and therefore not a nuisance. Therefore, the Prindles will not prevail if beekeeping on Delbrook's land was not prohibited by local ordinance.

question: While crossing Spruce Street, Pesko was hit by a car that she did not see. Pesko sued Dorry for her injuries. At trial, Pesko calls Williams, a police officer, to testify that, ten minutes after the accident, a driver stopped him and said, "Officer, a few minutes ago I saw a hit-and-run accident on Spruce Street involving a blue convertible, which I followed to the drive-in restaurant at Oak and Third," and that a few seconds later Williams saw Dorry sitting alone in a blue convertible in the drive-in restaurant's parking lot. Williams' testimony about the driver's statement should be
choices: admitted as a statement of recent perception
admitted as a present sense impression
excluded, because it is hearsay not within any exception
excluded, because it is more prejudicial than probative
reasoning_samples: The driver's statement to Williams is an out-of-court statement that is being offered for the truth of the matter asserted, i.e., that Dorry was involved in the hit-and-run accident. However, it is admissible as a statement of recent perception under Federal Rule of Evidence 803(1), which allows for the admission of a statement describing or explaining an event or condition made while the declarant was perceiving the event or condition, or immediately thereafter. In this case, the driver's statement was made 'a few minutes ago,' which is close enough to the time of the accident to qualify as 'immediately thereafter.' Therefore, the driver's statement should be admitted as a statement of recent perception.

question: Post sued Dean for personal injury alleged to have been caused by Dean's negligence. A major issue at trial was whether Post's disability was caused solely by trauma or by a preexisting condition of osteoarthritis. Post called Dr. Cox, who testified that the disability was caused by trauma. On cross-examination, Dr. Cox testified that a medical textbook entitled Diseases of the Joints was authoritative and that she agreed with the substance of passages from the textbook that she was directed to look at, but that the passages were inapplicable to Post's condition because they dealt with rheumatoid arthritis rather than with the Osteoarthritis that Post was alleged to have. Dean then called his expert, Dr. Freed, who testified that, with reference to the issue being litigated, there is no difference between the two kinds of arthritis. Dean's counsel than asks permission to read to the jury the textbook passages earlier shown to Dr. Cox. The judge should rule the textbook passages
choices: admissible only for the purpose of impeaching Cox
admissible as substantive evidence if the judge determines that the passages are relevant.
inadmissible, because they are hearsay not within any exception.
inadmissible, because Cox contended that they are not relevant to Post's condition
reasoning_samples: The textbook passages are being offered for the truth of the matter asserted, which is that there is no difference between rheumatoid and osteoarthritis. However, Dr. Cox has already testified that she agrees with the substance of the passages, but they are inapplicable to Post's condition. Therefore, the passages are being offered to impeach Dr. Cox's credibility by showing that she previously agreed with the passages, but now claims they are inapplicable. This is a classic example of impeachment by prior inconsistent statement, which is admissible under Federal Rule of Evidence 613.

question: At the trial, can Vault prove Kernel's oral commitment to repay the loan on or before July 1?
prompt: The Kernel Corporation, through its president, Demeter Gritz, requested from Vault Finance, Inc., a short-term loan of $100,000. On April 1, Gritz and Vault's loan officer agreed orally that Vault would make the loan on the following terms: (1) the loan would be repaid in full on or before the following July 1 and would carry interest at an annual rate of 15 percent (a lawful rate under the applicable usury law); and (2) Gritz would personally guarantee repayment. The loan was approved and made on April 5. The only document evidencing the loan was a memorandum, written and supplied by Vault and signed by Gritz for Kernel, that read in its entirety: April 5 In consideration of a loan advanced on this date, Kernel Corporation hereby promises to pay Vault Finance, Inc., $100,000 on September 1. Kernel Corporation By /s /Demeter Gritz Demeter Gritz, President Kernel Corporation did not repay the loan on or before July 1, although it had sufficient funds to do so. On July 10, Vault sued Kernel as principal debtor and Gritz individually as guarantor for $100,000, plus 15 percent interest from April 5.
choices: Yes, because the oral agreement was supported by an independent consideration.
Yes, because evidence of the parties' negotiations is relevant to their contractual intent concerning maturity of the debt.
No, because such evidence is barred by the preexisting duty rule.
No, because such evidence contradicts the writing and is barred by the parol evidence rule.
reasoning_samples: Although the parol evidence rule generally bars extrinsic evidence of prior agreements that contradict the terms of a final written contract, the rule does not apply when the extrinsic evidence is offered to interpret the meaning of the written contract. In this case, the written contract states that the loan is due on September 1, but the parties' oral agreement indicates that the loan was due on July 1. The extrinsic evidence of the parties' negotiations is relevant to their contractual intent concerning the maturity of the debt, and therefore, it is admissible to interpret the meaning of the written contract.

question: At the trial, can Vault prove Gritz's oral promise to guarantee the loan?
prompt: The Kernel Corporation, through its president, Demeter Gritz, requested from Vault Finance, Inc., a short-term loan of $100,000. On April 1, Gritz and Vault's loan officer agreed orally that Vault would make the loan on the following terms: (1) the loan would be repaid in full on or before the following July 1 and would carry interest at an annual rate of 15 percent (a lawful rate under the applicable usury law); and (2) Gritz would personally guarantee repayment. The loan was approved and made on April 5. The only document evidencing the loan was a memorandum, written and supplied by Vault and signed by Gritz for Kernel, that read in its entirety: April 5 In consideration of a loan advanced on this date, Kernel Corporation hereby promises to pay Vault Finance, Inc., $100,000 on September 1. Kernel Corporation By /s /Demeter Gritz Demeter Gritz, President Kernel Corporation did not repay the loan on or before July 1, although it had sufficient funds to do so. On July 10, Vault sued Kernel as principal debtor and Gritz individually as guarantor for $100,000, plus 15 percent interest from April 5.
choices: Yes, because Gritz signed the memorandum.
Yes, because, as president of the debtor-company, Gritz is a third-party beneficiary of the loan.
No, because there was no separate consideration for Gritz's promise.
No, because such proof is barred by the statute of frauds.
reasoning_samples: A is the correct answer because Gritz's signature on the memo constitutes a written promise to guarantee the loan. The statute of frauds does not apply to this situation because there is no requirement for a written contract between the guarantor (Gritz) and the lender (Vault) to be enforced. The memo, which was written and supplied by Vault and signed by Gritz, serves as sufficient evidence to prove Gritz's promise to guarantee the loan. This is because the memo is an adhesion contract, and Gritz, as a party to the contract with the debtor, will be bound by its terms without needing a separate written promise.

question: O'Neal entered into a written contract to sell her house and six acres known as Meadowacre to Perez for $75,000. Delivery of the deed and payment of the purchase price were to be made six months after the contract. The contract provided that Meadowacre was to be conveyed "subject to easements, covenants, and restrictions of record"' The contract was not recorded. After the contract was signed but before the deed was delivered, Electric Company decided to run a highvoltage power line in the area and required an easement through a portion of Meadowacre. O'Neal, by deed, granted an easement to Electric Company in consideration of $5,000; the deed was duly recorded. The power line would be a series of towers with several high-voltage lines that would be clearly visible from the house on Meadowacre but would in no way interfere with the house. When Perez caused the title to Meadowacre to be searched, the deed of easement to Electric Company was found. O'Neal appeared at the time and place scheduled for the closing and proffered an appropriate deed to Perez and demanded the purchase price. Perez refused to accept the deed. In an appropriate action for specific performance against Perez, O'Neal demanded $75,000. In this action, O'Neal should
choices: obtain an order for specific performance at a price of $75,000
Obtain an order for specific performance at a price of $70,000
lose, because Perez did not contract to take subject to the easement to Electric Company
lose, because a high-voltage power line is a nuisance per se
reasoning_samples: Perez contracted to purchase Meadowacre 'subject to easements, covenants, and restrictions of record.' This language is a standard caveat emptor clause, which means that the buyer is aware of the potential for easements, covenants, and restrictions on the property. Since the easement to Electric Company was recorded, Perez had constructive notice of the easement. Therefore, Perez's refusal to accept the deed due to the newly created easement is not a valid reason to avoid the contract. O'Neal should be able to obtain an order for specific performance at the original price of $75,000.

question: Darden was prosecuted for armed robbery. At trial, Darden testified in his own behalf, denying that he had committed the robbery. On cross-examination the prosecutor intends to ask Darden whether he had been convicted of burglary six years earlier. The question concerning the burglary conviction is
choices: proper if the court finds that the probative value for impeachment outweighs the prejudice to Darden
proper, because the prosecutor is entitled to make this inquiry as a matter of right
improper, because burglary does not involve dishonesty or false statement
improper, because the conviction must be proved by court record, not by question on cross-examination
reasoning_samples: The question concerning Darden's burglary conviction is proper if the court finds that the probative value for impeachment outweighs the prejudice to Darden. This is because Federal Rule of Evidence 609(a)(1) allows for the admission of a prior conviction for impeachment purposes if the crime 'involved dishonesty or false statement, regardless of the punishment.' Burglary is not inherently a crime of dishonesty or false statement, but it can be used to impeach if the court finds that the probative value outweighs the prejudice. Therefore, the court must make a balancing test to determine whether the question is proper.

question: Osif owned Broadacres in fee simple. For a consideration of $5,000, Osif gave Bard a written option to purchase Broadacres for $300,000. The option was assignable. For a consideration of $10,000, Bard subsequently gave an option to Cutter to purchase Broadacres for $325,000. Cutter exercised his option. Bard thereupon exercised his option. Bard paid the agreed price of $300,00 and took title to Broadacres by deed from Osif. Thereafter, Cutter refused to consummate his purchase. Bard brought an appropriate action against Cutter for specific performance, or, if that should be denied, then for damages. Cutter counterclaimed for return of the $10,000. In this action, the court will
choices: grant money damages only to Bard
grant specific performance to Bard
grant Bard only the right to retain the $10,000
require Bard to refund the $10,000 to Cutter
reasoning_samples: When Bard exercised his option to purchase Broadacres, he became the equitable owner of the property. However, Cutter's refusal to consummate his purchase does not affect Bard's obligation to pay the purchase price to Osif. Since Bard has already paid the purchase price to Osif, he is entitled to retain the property. Cutter's counterclaim for return of the $10,000 is also unfounded, as he had a valid option to purchase the property, which he exercised. However, Bard is not entitled to specific performance against Cutter because Cutter's refusal to consummate the purchase does not give rise to a valid claim for specific performance. Therefore, the court will grant money damages only to Bard, as he has already paid the purchase price to Osif and is entitled to retain the property.

question: In Peel's personal injury action, Wilson, a physician who had no previous knowledge of the matter, sat in court and heard all of the evidence about Peel's symptoms and conditions. Wilson is called to give her opinion whether Peel's injuries are permanent. May Wilson so testify?
choices: Yes, provided she first identifies the data on which her opinion is based.
Yes, because an expert may base her opinion on facts made known to her at the trial.
No, because she has no personal knowledge of Peel's condition.
No, because permanence of injury is an issue to be decided by the jury.
reasoning_samples: Wilson, as an expert, can testify about the permanence of Peel's injuries, but only if she can identify the specific data or facts on which her opinion is based. This is because expert testimony is allowed in court as long as it is based on sufficient facts or data, and the expert can explain the basis for their opinion. In this case, Wilson has no prior knowledge of the matter, but she has heard all the evidence presented in court. As long as she can identify the specific facts or data that led her to form her opinion, her testimony will be admissible. This is in line with the principles of Federal Rule of Evidence 703, which allows experts to base their opinions on facts or data that they have not personally observed, as long as those facts or data are made known to the expert at or before the hearing or trial.

question: A federal criminal law makes it a crime for any citizen of the United States not specifically authorized by the President to negotiate with a foreign government for the purpose of influencing the foreign government in relation to a dispute with the United States. The strongest constitutional grounds for the validity of this law is that
choices: under several of its enumerated powers, Congress may legislate to preserve the monopoly of the national government over the conduct of United States foreign affairs

the President's inherent power to negotiate for the United States with foreign countries authorizes the President, even in the absence of statutory authorization, to punish citizens who engage in such negotiations without permission
the law deals with foreign relations and therefore is not governed by the First Amendment
federal criminal laws dealing with international affairs need not be as specific as those dealing with domestic affairs
reasoning_samples: The strongest constitutional grounds for the validity of this law is that under several of its enumerated powers, Congress may legislate to preserve the monopoly of the national government over the conduct of United States foreign affairs. This is because the Constitution grants Congress the power to declare war (Article I, Section 8, Clause 11), make treaties (Article II, Section 2, Clause 2), and regulate commerce with foreign nations (Article I, Section 8, Clause 3). These powers collectively give Congress the authority to regulate and control the conduct of foreign affairs, including the negotiation of disputes with foreign governments. By making it a crime for citizens to negotiate with foreign governments without permission, Congress is exercising its power to preserve the national government's monopoly over foreign affairs, thereby ensuring that foreign policy is conducted in a unified and coherent manner. This is the strongest constitutional ground for the validity of the law because it is based on the explicit powers granted to Congress in the Constitution, rather than on implied powers or other constitutional provisions.

question: Arthur and Celia, brother and sister, both of legal age, inherited Goodacre, their childhood home, from their father. They thereby became tenants in common. Goodacre had never been used as anything except a residence. Arthur had been residing on Goodacre with his father at the time his father died. Celia had been residing in a distant city. After their father's funeral, Arthur continued to live on Goodacre, but Celia returned to her own residence. There was no discussion between Arthur and Celia concerning their common ownership, nor had there ever been any administration of their father's estate. Arthur paid all taxes, insurance, and other carrying charges on Goodacre. He paid no rent or other compensation to Celia, nor did Celia request any such payment. Thirty years later, a series of disputes arose between Arthur and Celia for the first time concerning their respective rights to Goodacre. The jurisdiction where the land is located recognizes the usual common-law types of cotenancies, and there is no applicable legislation on the subject. If Arthur claims the entire title to Goodacre in fee simple and brings an action against Celia to quiet title in himself, and if the state where the land is located has an ordinary 20-year adverse possession statute, the decision should be for
choices: Arthur, because during the past 30 years Arthur has exercised the type of occupancy ordinarily considered sufficient to satisfy the adverse possession requirements
Arthur, because the acts of the parties indicate Celia's intention to renounce her right to inheritance
Celia, because there is no evidence that Arthur has performed sufficient acts to constitute her ouster
Celia, because one cotenant cannot acquire title by adverse possession against another
reasoning_samples: Arthur's actions over the past 30 years, including paying all taxes, insurance, and other carrying charges on Goodacre without Celia's contribution or request, demonstrate a clear intent to possess the property exclusively. This is particularly evident given that Arthur continued to reside on the property while Celia did not. The jurisdiction's 20-year adverse possession statute applies, and Arthur's actions satisfy the requirements for adverse possession. Celia's lack of involvement and Arthur's exclusive possession for the requisite period establish that Arthur has acquired title to the property by adverse possession, thereby defeating Celia's claim to the property.

question: If Farber asserts a claim against Gasco for the los of his lettuce crop and-is unable to show any negligence on the part of Gasco, will Farber prevail?
prompt: Gasco owns a storage facility where flammable gases are stored in liquefied form under high pressure in large spherical tanks. The facility was constructed for Gasco by Acme Company, a firm that specializes in the construction of such facilities. After the facility had been in use for five years, an explosion in the facility started a large fire that blanketed the surrounding countryside with a high concentration of oily smoke and soot. Farber owns a large truck farm near the facility. His entire lettuce crop was destroyed by oily deposits left by the smoke. Johnson, who lives near the facility, inhaled a large amount of the smoke and thereafter became obsessed by a fear that the inhalation would destroy his health and ultimately cause his death.
choices: Yes, because the operation of the storage facility was an abnormally dangerous activity.
Yes, because the intrusion of the smoke onto Farber's farm amounted to a trespass.
No, if the explosion was caused by internal corrosion that reasonable inspection procedures would not have disclosed.
No, if the explosion was caused by negligent construction on Acme's part.
reasoning_samples: The key to this question lies in the concept of abnormally dangerous activities. An abnormally dangerous activity is one that involves a high degree of risk of serious harm to persons or property, and is not capable of being performed with complete safety no matter how much care is taken. In this case, the storage of flammable gases in liquefied form under high pressure in large spherical tanks is an activity that is inherently dangerous and poses a significant risk of serious harm to persons and property. The fact that Gasco was unable to show any negligence on its part is irrelevant, as the activity itself is considered to be abnormally dangerous. Therefore, Farber will prevail in his claim against Gasco, regardless of whether Gasco was negligent or not. This is because Gasco's abnormally dangerous activity is the proximate cause of Farber's loss, and Gasco will be held strictly liable for the resulting harm.

question: If Farber asserts a claim against Acme Company for the loss of his lettuce crop will Farber prevail?
prompt: Gasco owns a storage facility where flammable gases are stored in liquefied form under high pressure in large spherical tanks. The facility was constructed for Gasco by Acme Company, a firm that specializes in the construction of such facilities. After the facility had been in use for five years, an explosion in the facility started a large fire that blanketed the surrounding countryside with a high concentration of oily smoke and soot. Farber owns a large truck farm near the facility. His entire lettuce crop was destroyed by oily deposits left by the smoke. Johnson, who lives near the facility, inhaled a large amount of the smoke and thereafter became obsessed by a fear that the inhalation would destroy his health and ultimately cause his death.
choices: No, if Acme did not design the storage facility.
No, because Acme was an independent contractor.
Yes, because the operation of the storage facility was an abnormally dangerous activity.
Yes, if the explosion resulted from a defect of which Acme was aware.
reasoning_samples: Since Acme Company was an independent contractor hired specifically for the construction of the storage facility, they are not vicariously liable for any damages that may have occurred due to its operation. The question of whether the explosion was caused by a defect of which Acme was aware is irrelevant; the key issue is whether Acme had a duty to Farber. Since Acme had no such duty, Farber's claim against them is likely to fail.

question: Johnson and Tenfliel owned Brownacre as joint tenants with the right of survivorship. Johnson executed a mortgage on Brownacre to Lowden in order to secure a loan. Subsequently, but before the indebtedness was paid to Lowden, Johnson died intestate with Stokes as her only heir at law. The jurisdiction in which Brownacre is located recognizes the title theory of mortgages. In an appropriate action, the court should determine that title to Brownacre is vested.
choices: in Tenniel, with the entire interest subject to the mortgage
In Tenniel, free and clear of the mortgage
half in Tenniel, free of the mortgage, and half in Stokes subject to the mortgage
half in Tenniel and half in Stokes, with both subject to the mortgage
reasoning_samples: Johnson and Tenfliel owned Brownacre as joint tenants with the right of survivorship, meaning that upon Johnson's death, the property automatically passes to Tenfliel. The mortgage, however, is a separate obligation that is not affected by the joint tenancy. As the surviving joint tenant, Tenfliel's interest in the property is subject to the mortgage, which was executed by Johnson to secure a loan. Therefore, the court should determine that title to Brownacre is vested in Tenfliel, with the entire interest subject to the mortgage.

question: Pursuant to a state statute, Clovis applied for tuition assistance to attend the Institute of Liberal Arts. He was qualified for such assistance in every way except that he was a resident alien who did not intend to become a United States citizen. The state's restriction of such grants to United States citizens or resident aliens seeking such citizenship is probably
choices: valid, because aliens are not per se "a discrete and insular minority" specially protected by the Fourteenth Amendment
valid, because the line drawn by the state for extending aid was reasonably related to a legitimate state interest
invalid, because the justifications for this restriction are insufficient to overcome the burden imposed on a state when it uses such an alienage classification
invalid, because the privileges and immunities clause of Article IV does not permit such an arbitrary classification
reasoning_samples: The state's restriction of tuition assistance grants to United States citizens or resident aliens seeking such citizenship is probably invalid because the justifications for this restriction are insufficient to overcome the burden imposed on a state when it uses such an alienage classification. The Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause prohibits states from using alienage classifications unless they are necessary to achieve a compelling state interest. In this case, the state's interest in limiting tuition assistance to citizens or those seeking citizenship is not compelling enough to justify the restriction. Furthermore, the state's classification is not narrowly tailored, as it excludes all resident aliens who do not intend to become citizens, regardless of their qualifications or contributions to the state. Therefore, option C is the best answer.

question: Simmons and Boyd entered into a written contract for the sale and purchase of Wideacre. The contract provided that "Simmons agrees to convey a good and marketable title to Boyd sixty days from the date of this contract' The purchase price was stated as $60,000. At the time set for closing Simmons tendered a deed in the form agreed to in the contract. Boyd's examination of the record prior to the date of closing had disclosed, however, that the owner of record was not Simmons, but Olson. Further investigation by Boyd revealed that, notwithstanding the state of the record, Simmons had been in what Boyd concedes is adverse possession for fifteen years. The period of time to acquire title by adverse possession in the jurisdiction is ten years. Boyd refuses to pay the purchase price or to take possession "because of the inability of Simmons to transfer a marketable title"' In an appropriate action by Simmons against Boyd for a specific performance, Simmons will
choices: prevail, because he has obtained a "good and marketable title" by adverse possession
prevail, because Simmons' action for specific performance is an action in rem even though Olson is not a party
not prevail, because Boyd cannot be required to buy a lawsuit even if the probability is great that Boyd would prevail against Olson
not prevail, because Simmons' failure to disclose his lack of record title constitutes fraud
reasoning_samples: Simmons has acquired a good and marketable title by adverse possession, which is a valid method of acquiring title in the jurisdiction. Although Boyd's examination of the record prior to closing disclosed that the owner of record was not Simmons, this information does not negate Simmons' actual possession and ownership of the property for the requisite period. The fact that Simmons' title may be subject to a potential lawsuit against Olson is irrelevant to the question of whether Simmons has a marketable title. A court will look to the facts on the ground to determine the validity of a title, and Simmons' fifteen-year adverse possession of the property is sufficient to establish a good and marketable title. Therefore, Simmons will prevail in his action for specific performance.

question: Congress passes an act requiring that all owners of bicycles in the United States register them with a federal bicycle registry. The purpose of the law is to provide reliable evidence of ownership to reduce bicycle theft. No fee is charged for the registration. Although most stolen bicycles are kept or resold by the thieves in the same cities in which the bicycles were stolen, an increasing number of bicycles are being taken to cities in other states for resale. Is this act of Congress constitutional?
choices: Yes, because Congress has the power to regulate property for the general welfare.
Yes, because Congress could determine that in inseverable aggregates bicycle thefts affect interstate commerce.
No, because most stolen bicycles remain within the state in which they were stolen.
No, because the registration of vehicles is a matter reserved to the states by the Tenth Amendment.
reasoning_samples: The Commerce Clause grants Congress the power to regulate activities that have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. Although most stolen bicycles remain within the state in which they were stolen, the increasing number of bicycles being taken to cities in other states for resale has a substantial effect on interstate commerce. The federal bicycle registry is a reasonable means to address this issue, and therefore, Congress has the power to regulate property for the general welfare under the Commerce Clause. This reasoning aligns with the Supreme Court's decision in Wickard v. Filburn, which held that Congress can regulate activities that, while local in nature, have a cumulative effect on interstate commerce.

question: Donaldson broke into Professor Ruiz' office in order to look at examination questions. The questions were locked in a drawer, and Donaldson could not find them. Donaldson believed that looking at examination questions was a crime, but in this belief he was mistaken. Charged with burglary, Donaldson should be
choices: acquitted, because he did not complete the crime and he has not been charged with attempt
acquitted, because what he intended to do when he broke in was not a crime
convicted, because he had the necessary mental state and committed the act of breaking and entering
convicted, because factual impossibility is not a defense
reasoning_samples: To determine the correct answer, we must first understand the elements of burglary. Burglary typically requires two elements: (1) the intent to commit a crime, and (2) the breaking and entering of a dwelling or other structure. In this case, Donaldson broke into Professor Ruiz' office, which satisfies the second element. However, the key issue is whether Donaldson had the necessary intent to commit a crime. Donaldson believed that looking at examination questions was a crime, but in this belief he was mistaken. This mistaken belief negates the intent element of burglary. Since Donaldson did not have the necessary intent to commit a crime, he cannot be convicted of burglary. Therefore, the correct answer is A) acquitted, because he did not complete the crime and he has not been charged with attempt.

question: A statute of the state of Lanape flatly bans the sale or distribution of contraceptive devices to minors. Drugs, Inc., a national retailer of drugs and related items, is charged with violating the Lenape statute. Which of the following is the strongest constitutional argument Drugs, Inc., could make in defending itself against prosecution for violation of this statute?
choices: The statute constitutes an undue burden on interstate commerce.
The statute denies minors one of their fundamental rights without due process.
The statute denies Drugs, Inc., a privilege or immunity of state citizenship.
The statute violates the First Amendment right to freedom of religion because it regulates morals.
reasoning_samples: The strongest constitutional argument Drugs, Inc., could make in defending itself against prosecution for violation of the Lenape statute is that the statute constitutes an undue burden on interstate commerce. This is because the statute flatly bans the sale or distribution of contraceptive devices to minors, which would likely impact Drugs, Inc.'s ability to engage in interstate commerce. As a national retailer, Drugs, Inc. likely sources its products from out-of-state suppliers and sells them to customers across state lines. The Lenape statute would impose a significant burden on Drugs, Inc.'s interstate business, potentially forcing it to alter its business practices or risk prosecution. This would be a classic example of an undue burden on interstate commerce, which is a key principle of the Commerce Clause of the US Constitution (Article I, Section 8, Clause 3). The Commerce Clause prohibits states from imposing regulations that unduly burden interstate commerce, and the Lenape statute's blanket ban on the sale of contraceptive devices to minors would likely be seen as such a burden. Therefore, option A is the strongest constitutional argument Drugs, Inc. could make in defending itself against prosecution.

question: In a tort action, Fisher testified against Dawes. Dawes then called Jones, who testified that Fisher had a bad reputation for veracity. Dawes then also called Weld to testify that Fisher once perpetrated a hoax on the police. Weld's testimony is
choices: admissible, because a hoax involves untruthfullness
admissible, provided that the hoax resulted in conviction of Fisher
inadmissible, because it is merely cumulative impeachment
inadmissible, because it is extrinsic evidence of a specific instance of misconduct
reasoning_samples: Fisher's testimony was used to impeach Dawes' credibility. Dawes then attempted to impeach Fisher's credibility by calling Jones to testify about Fisher's bad reputation for veracity. However, Dawes also called Weld to testify about a specific instance of misconduct, namely the hoax perpetrated by Fisher. Under Federal Rule of Evidence 608(b), specific instances of misconduct, such as the hoax, are inadmissible to impeach a witness unless they result in a criminal conviction. However, in this case, the question does not specify that the hoax resulted in a conviction. Nevertheless, the key point is that the question asks about Weld's testimony, which is about a specific instance of misconduct. The correct answer is not about whether the hoax is admissible or inadmissible, but rather whether it is extrinsic evidence of a specific instance of misconduct. However, the correct answer is A because the hoax involves untruthfulness, which is a characteristic of untruthfulness that can be used to impeach a witness. This is an exception to the general rule that specific instances of misconduct are inadmissible. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

question: Astin left her car at Garrison's Garage to have repair work done. After completing the repairs, Garrison took the car out for a test drive and was involved in an accident that caused damages to Placek. A statute imposes liability on the owner of an automobile for injuries to a third party tht are caused by the negligence of any person driving the automobile with the owner's consent. The statute applies to situations of this kind, even if the owner did not specifically authorize the mechanic to test-drive the car. Placek sued Astin and Garrison jointly for damages arising from the accident. In that action, Astin cross-claims to recover from Garrison the amount of any payment Astin may be required to make to Placek. The trier of fact has determined that the accident was caused solely by negligent driving on Garrison's part, and that Placek's damages were $100,000. In this action, the proper outcome will be that
choices: Placek should have judgment for $50,000 each against Astin and Garrison; Astin should recover nothing from Garrison
Placek should have judgment for $100,000 against Garrison only
Placek should have judgment for $100,000 against Astin and Garrison jointly, and Astin should have judgment against Garrison for 50 percent of any amount collected from Astin by Placek
Placek should have judgment for $100,000 against Astin and Garrison jointly, and Astin should have judgment against Garrison for any amount collected from Astin by Placek
reasoning_samples: The statute imposes liability on the owner of an automobile for injuries to a third party caused by the negligence of any person driving the automobile with the owner's consent. Since Astin gave Garrison consent to drive her car, Astin is liable for the damages caused by Garrison's negligence. However, the statute does not impose joint and several liability on the owner and the driver. Instead, each person is liable only for their proportionate share of the damages. Therefore, Placek should have judgment for $100,000 against Astin and Garrison, but Astin should only be liable for 50% of the damages, and Garrison should be liable for the remaining 50%. Since Astin cross-claimed to recover from Garrison the amount of any payment Astin may be required to make to Placek, Astin should recover nothing from Garrison because Astin is only liable for 50% of the damages.

question: Martinez, a widower, owns in fee simple a ranch, Ranchacre. Martinez has one child, Enrique, who is married. Enrique has one child, Ana Maria, who is also married but has no children. In an effort to dispose of Ranchacre to his descendants and to honor a request by Ana Maria that she be skipped in any such disposition, Martinez conveys Ranchacre to his son, Enrique, for life with the remainder to Ana Maria's children in fee simple. What interest, if any, is created in favor of Ana Maria's unborn children at the time of the conveyance?
choices: A contingent remainder
A vested remainder subject to divestment
A springing use
nan
reasoning_samples: To determine the interest created in favor of Ana Maria's unborn children, we must first identify the key elements of the conveyance. Martinez conveys Ranchacre to Enrique for life, with the remainder to Ana Maria's children in fee simple. A remainder is a future interest that takes effect after the termination of a preceding estate. In this case, the remainder is vested in Ana Maria's children because it is certain to take effect when the preceding estate (Enrique's life estate) terminates. However, the remainder is contingent because it is subject to a condition precedent (the birth of Ana Maria's children). A contingent remainder is a vested remainder subject to a condition precedent, which must be satisfied before the remainder can take effect. Therefore, the interest created in favor of Ana Maria's unborn children is a contingent remainder.

question: Did Clothier properly reject the ties delivered on June 3?
prompt: On June 1, Kravat, a manufacturer of men's neckties, received the following order from Clothier: "Ship 500 two-inch ties, assorted stripes, your catalogue No. V34. Delivery by July 1." On June 1, Kravat shipped 500 three-inch ties that arrived at Clothier's place of business on June 3. Clothier immediately telegraphed Kravat: "Reject your shipment. Order was for two-inch ties!" Clothier, however, did not ship the ties back to Kravat. Kravat replied by telegram: "Will deliver proper ties before July 1 Clothier received this telegram on June 4, but did not reply to it. On June 30, Kravat tendered 500 two-inch ties in assorted stripes, designated in his catalogue as item No. V34; but Clothier refused to accept them.
choices: Yes, because the ties were nonconforming goods.
Yes, because Kravat did not notify Clothier that the ties were shipped as an accommodation to Clothier.
No, because Kravat could accept Clothier's offer by prompt shipment of either conforming or nonconforming goods.
No, because Clothier waived his right to reject the ties by not returning them promptly to Kravat.
reasoning_samples: Clothier properly rejected the ties delivered on June 3 because they were nonconforming goods. The UCC's perfect tender rule (UCC ยง 2-601) allows a buyer to reject nonconforming goods, and Clothier did so immediately upon receiving the shipment. Kravat's shipment of three-inch ties instead of two-inch ties was a clear breach of the contract, and Clothier's rejection was timely and justified. Options B, C, and D do not apply to this situation because there is no evidence that Kravat made an accommodation to Clothier, Kravat's initial shipment was not an acceptance of Clothier's offer, and Clothier's failure to return the ties promptly does not waive his right to reject nonconforming goods.

question: Did Clothier properly reject the ties tendered on June 30?
prompt: On June 1, Kravat, a manufacturer of men's neckties, received the following order from Clothier: "Ship 500 two-inch ties, assorted stripes, your catalogue No. V34. Delivery by July 1." On June 1, Kravat shipped 500 three-inch ties that arrived at Clothier's place of business on June 3. Clothier immediately telegraphed Kravat: "Reject your shipment. Order was for two-inch ties!" Clothier, however, did not ship the ties back to Kravat. Kravat replied by telegram: "Will deliver proper ties before July 1 Clothier received this telegram on June 4, but did not reply to it. On June 30, Kravat tendered 500 two-inch ties in assorted stripes, designated in his catalogue as item No. V34; but Clothier refused to accept them.
choices: Yes, because Kravat's shipping the three-inch ties on June 1 was a present breach of contract.
Yes, because Kravat's shipping the three-inch ties on June 1 was an anticipatory repudiation.
No, because Kravat cured the June 1 defective delivery by his tender of conforming goods on June 30.
No, because a contract for the sale of goods can be modified without consideration.
reasoning_samples: Kravat's initial shipment of three-inch ties on June 1 constituted a present breach of contract because it failed to conform to the contract terms. Clothier properly rejected the shipment on June 3. Kravat's subsequent tender of conforming goods on June 30 did not cure the initial breach because it was made after the July 1 delivery deadline specified in the contract. Under UCC ยง 2-508, a buyer may reject nonconforming goods and the seller is not entitled to cure if the nonconformity substantially impairs the value of the contract. In this case, the initial breach by Kravat substantially impaired the value of the contract because it failed to deliver the goods as specified. Therefore, Clothier properly rejected the ties tendered on June 30.

question: Dent, while eating in a restaurant, noticed that a departing customer at the next table had left a fivedollar bill as a tip for the waitress. Dent reached over, picked up the five-dollar bill, and put it in his pocket. As he stood up to leave, another customer who had seen him take the money ran over to him and hit him in the face with her umbrella. Enraged, Dent choked the customer to death. Dent is charged with murder. He requests the court to charge the jury that they can find him guilty of voluntary manslaughter rather than murder. Dent's request should be
choices: granted, because the jury could find that Dent acted recklessly and not with the intent to cause death or serious bodily harm
granted, because the jury could find that being hit in the face with an umbrella constitutes adequate provocation
denied, because the evidence shows that Dent intended to kill or to cause serious bodily harm
denied, because the evidence shows that Dent provoked the assault on himself by his criminal misconduct
reasoning_samples: To determine whether Dent's request should be granted, we need to consider the elements of voluntary manslaughter. Voluntary manslaughter is a lesser-included offense of murder, and it requires a provocation that would cause an ordinary person to lose control and act impulsively. In this case, being hit in the face with an umbrella could be considered a sufficient provocation to cause an ordinary person to lose control and act impulsively. The fact that Dent was enraged and choked the customer to death suggests that he acted impulsively in response to the provocation. Therefore, the jury should be allowed to consider whether Dent's actions constitute voluntary manslaughter, and the court should grant Dent's request.

question: Dever drove his car into an intersection and collided with a fire engine that had entered the intersection from Dever's right. The accident was caused by negligence on Dever's part. As a result of the accident, the fire engine was delayed in reaching Peters' house, which was entirely consumed by fire. Peters' house was located about ten blocks from the scene of the accident. If Peters asserts a claim against Dever, Peters will recover
choices: that part of his loss that would have been prevented if the collision had not occurred
the value of his house before the fire
nothing if Dever had nothing to do with causing the fire
nothing, because Dever's conduct did not create an apparent danger to Peters
reasoning_samples: Peters' claim against Dever is a claim for damages resulting from the delay of the fire engine. Since Dever's negligence caused the collision, which in turn delayed the fire engine, Peters is entitled to recover the damages that would have been prevented if the collision had not occurred. This is a classic example of proximate cause, where the defendant's negligence is the legal cause of the plaintiff's damages. The fact that the fire engine was delayed in reaching Peters' house, which was located about ten blocks from the scene of the accident, is a foreseeable consequence of Dever's negligence. Therefore, Peters will recover that part of his loss that would have been prevented if the collision had not occurred.

question: Miller applied to the state liquor board for transfer of the license of Miller's Bar and Grill to a new site. The board held a hearing on the application. At that hearing, Hammond appeared without being subpoenaed and stated that Miller had underworld connections. Although Hammond did not know this information to be true, he had heard rumors about Miller's character and had noticed several underworld figures going in and out of Miller's Bar and Grill. In fact, Miller had no underworld connections. In a claim against Hammond based on defamation, Miller will
choices: not recover if Hammond reasonably believed his statement to be true
not recover if the board granted Miller's application
recover, because Hammond's statement was false
recover, because Hammond appeared before the board voluntarily
reasoning_samples: In a defamation claim, the plaintiff must prove that the defendant made a false and defamatory statement about the plaintiff with 'actual malice.' However, in this case, Hammond did not know the information to be true or false, but rather had heard rumors. To establish actual malice, the plaintiff must show that the defendant in fact knew the statement was false or entertained serious doubts as to the truth of the statement. Since Hammond did not know the information to be true or false, he cannot be held to have acted with actual malice. Therefore, Miller will not recover if Hammond reasonably believed his statement to be true.

question: Santos agreed to sell and Perrine agreed to buy a described lot on which a single-family residence had been built. Under the contract, Santos agreed to convey marketable title subject only to conditions, covenants, and restrictions of record and all applicable zoning laws and ordinances. The lot was subject to a 10-foot side line setback originally set forth in the developer's duly recorded subdivision plot. The applicable zoning ordinance zones the property for single-family units and requires an 8.5-foot side line setback. Prior to closing, a survey of the property was made. It revealed that a portion of Santos' house was 8.4 feet from the side line. Perrine refused to consummate the transaction on the ground that Santos' title is not marketable. In an appropriate action, Santos seeks specific performance. Who will prevail in such an action?
choices: Santos, because any suit against Perrine concerning the setback would be frivolous
Santos, because the setback violation falls within the doctrine de minimis non curat lex
