This is why Tenny will lose if Len owned both Lot 1 and Lot 2 until eight years ago.

question: Dewar, a developer, needing a water well on one of his projects, met several times about the matter with Waterman, a well driller. Subsequently, Waterman sent Dewar an unsigned typewritten form captioned "WELL DRILLING PROPOSAL" and stating various terms the two had discussed but not agreed upon, including a "proposed price of $5,000." The form concluded, "This proposal will not become a contract until signed by you [Dewar] and then returned to and signed by me [Waterman]." Dewar signed the form and returned it to Waterman, who neglected to sign it but promptly began drilling the well at the proposed site on Dewar's project. After drilling for two days, Waterman told Dewar during one of Dewar's daily visits that he would not finish unless Dewar would agree to pay twice the price recited in the written proposal. Dewar refused, Waterman quit, and Dewar hired Subbo to drill the well to completion for a price of $7,500. In an action by Dewar against Waterman for damages, which of the following is the probable decision?
choices: Dewar wins, because his signing of Waterman's form constituted an acceptance of an offer by Waterman.
Dewar wins, because Waterman's commencement of performance constituted an acceptance by Waterman of an offer by Dewar and an implied promise by Waterman to complete the well.
Waterman wins, because he never signed the proposal as required by its terms.
Waterman wins, because his commencement of performance merely prevented Dewar from revoking his offer, made on a form supplied by Waterman, and did not obligate Waterman to complete the well.
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, Waterman's unsigned proposal can be considered an offer to Dewar. When Dewar signed the proposal, it constituted an acceptance of Waterman's offer, forming a contract. Although Waterman did not sign the proposal, the fact that Dewar signed it and returned it to Waterman indicates that he intended to accept the terms of the proposal. Since the terms of the proposal stated that it would not become a contract until signed by both parties, Dewar's signature is sufficient to create a binding contract. Moreover, even if Waterman did not intend to be bound by the proposal, his actions (beginning drilling) demonstrate that he is estopped from denying that a contract existed. As such, Dewar's signing of the proposal constituted an acceptance of Waterman's offer, making option A the probable decision.

question: In an action brought against Driver by Walker's legal representative, the only proofs that the legal representative offered on liability were that: (1) Walker, a pedestrian, was killed instantly while walking on the shoulder of the highway; (2) Driver was driving the car that struck Walker; and (3) there were no living witnesses to the accident other than Driver, who denied negligence. Assume the jurisdiction has adopted a rule of pure comparative negligence. If, at the end of the plaintiffs case, Driver moves for a directed verdict, the trial judge should
choices: grant the motion, because the legal representative has offered no specific evidence from which reasonable jurors may conclude that Driver was negligent.
grant the motion, because it is just as likely that Walker was negligent as that Driver was negligent.
deny the motion, unless Walker was walking with his back to traffic, in violation of the state highway code.
deny the motion, because, in the circumstances, negligence on the part of Driver may be inferred.
reasoning_samples: To determine whether the trial judge should grant the motion for a directed verdict, we must consider the burden of proof and the standard of evidence required for liability. In a pure comparative negligence jurisdiction, the plaintiff must establish a prima facie case to proceed with the trial. A prima facie case requires sufficient evidence to support a reasonable inference of liability. In this scenario, the legal representative has offered only circumstantial evidence that Driver was driving the car that struck Walker, but there is no direct evidence of Driver's negligence. Furthermore, the lack of living witnesses and Driver's denial of negligence create a significant evidentiary gap. Without specific evidence from which reasonable jurors may conclude that Driver was negligent, the legal representative has failed to establish a prima facie case. Therefore, the trial judge should grant the motion for a directed verdict.

question: Smith joined a neighborhood gang. At a gang meeting, as part of the initiation process, the leader ordered Smith to kill Hardy, a member of a rival gang. Smith refused, saying he no longer wanted to be part of the group. The leader, with the approval of the other members, told Smith that he had become too involved with the gang to quit and that they would kill him if he did not accomplish the murder of Hardy. The next day Smith shot Hardy to death while Hardy was sitting on his motorcycle outside a restaurant. Smith is charged with first-degree murder. First-degree murder is defined in the jurisdiction as the intentional premeditated killing of another. Second-degree murder is all other murder at common law. If Smith killed Hardy because of the threat to his own life, Smith should be found
choices: not guilty, because of the defense of duress.
not guilty, because of the defense of necessity.
guilty of first-degree murder.
guilty of second-degree murder.
reasoning_samples: Smith should be found not guilty because of the defense of duress. Duress is a defense to a crime when a person is coerced into committing the crime by the threat of imminent harm to themselves or a loved one. In this case, Smith was threatened with death by the gang if he did not kill Hardy. This threat of imminent harm to his own life constitutes duress, which negates the intent required for first-degree murder. Although Smith's actions were still criminal, the defense of duress excuses his conduct because he was acting under the influence of the gang's threat. Therefore, Smith should be found not guilty of first-degree murder.

question: A federal law provides that all motor vehicle tires discarded in this country must be disposed of in facilities licensed by the federal Environmental Protection Agency. Pursuant to this federal law and all proper federal procedural requirements, that agency has adopted very strict standards for the licensing of such facilities. As a result, the cost of disposing of tires in licensed facilities is substantial. The state of East Dakota has a very large fleet of motor vehicles, including trucks used to support state-owned commercial activities and police cars. East Dakota disposes of used tires from both kinds of state motor vehicles in a state-owned and -operated facility. This state facility is unlicensed, but its operation in actual practice meets most of the standards imposed by the federal Environmental Protection Agency on facilities it licenses to dispose of tires. Consistent with United States Supreme Court precedent, may the state of East Dakota continue to dispose of its used tires in this manner?
choices: No, because a state must comply with valid federal laws that regulate matters affecting interstate commerce.
No, because some of the tires come from vehicles that are used by the state solely in its commercial activities.
Yes, because some of the tires come from vehicles that are used by the state in the performance of core state governmental functions such as law enforcement.

Yes, because the legitimate needs of the federal government are satisfied by the fact that the unlicensed state disposal scheme meets, in actual practice, most of the federal standards for the licensing of such facilities.
reasoning_samples: The federal law in question regulates matters affecting interstate commerce, as it pertains to the disposal of motor vehicle tires. The Supremacy Clause of the US Constitution (Article VI, Clause 2) establishes that federal law takes precedence over state law in the event of a conflict. Since the federal law is valid and regulates a matter affecting interstate commerce, the state of East Dakota must comply with it. The fact that the state facility meets most of the federal standards in practice does not exempt it from the requirement of obtaining a federal license. Therefore, the state of East Dakota cannot continue to dispose of its used tires in an unlicensed facility, and answer A is the correct choice.

question: Arnold and Beverly owned a large tract of land, Blackacre, in fee simple as joint tenants with rights of survivorship. While Beverly was on an extended safari in Kenya, Arnold learned that there were very valuable coal deposits within Blackacre, but he made no attempt to inform Beverly. Thereupon, Arnold conveyed his interest in Blackacre to his wife, Alice, who immediately reconveyed that interest to Arnold. The common-law joint tenancy is unmodified by statute. Shortly thereafter, Arnold was killed in an automobile accident. His will, which was duly probated, specifically devised his one-half interest in Blackacre to Alice. Beverly then returned from Kenya and learned what had happened. Beverly brought an appropriate action against Alice, who claimed a one-half interest in Blackacre, seeking a declaratory judgment that she, Beverly, was the sole owner of Blackacre. In this action, who should prevail?
choices: Alice, because Arnold and Beverly were tenants in common at the time of Arnold's death.
Alice, because Arnold's will severed the joint tenancy.
Beverly, because the joint tenancy was reestablished by Alice's reconveyance to Arnold.
Beverly, because Arnold breached his fiduciary duty as her joint tenant.
reasoning_samples: When Arnold conveyed his interest in Blackacre to Alice and she immediately reconveyed it back to Arnold, this created a situation where the joint tenancy was severed. However, the reconveyance did not reestablish the joint tenancy because it was a mere sham transaction. The joint tenancy was effectively severed, and Arnold and Beverly became tenants in common. When Arnold died, his one-half interest in Blackacre passed to Alice under his will. Therefore, at the time of Arnold's death, Arnold and Beverly were tenants in common, and Alice's interest in Blackacre was valid. Beverly's claim that she is the sole owner of Blackacre is incorrect because Alice has a valid one-half interest in the property.

question: Dent operates a residential rehabilitation center for emotionally disturbed and ungovernable children who have been committed to his custody by their parents or by juvenile authorities. The center's purpose is to modify the behavior of the children through a teaching program carried out in a family-like environment. Though the children are not permitted to leave the center without his permission, there are no bars or guards to prevent them from doing so. It has been held in the state where the center is located that persons having custody of children have the same duties and responsibilities that they would have if they were the parents of the children. Camden, aged 12, who had been in Dent's custody for six months, left the center without permission. Dent became aware of Camden's absence almost immediately, but made no attempt to locate him or secure his return, though reports reached him that Camden had been seen in the vicinity. Thirty-six hours after Camden left the center, Camden committed a brutal assault upon Pell, a five-year-old child, causing Pell to suffer extensive permanent injury. If an action is brought against Dent on behalf of Pell to recover damages for Pell's injuries, will Pell prevail?
choices: No, because parents are not personally liable for their child's intentional torts.
Yes, if Camden was old enough to be liable for battery.
Yes, because Camden was in Dent's custody.
No, unless Dent knew or had reason to know that Camden had a propensity to attack younger children.
reasoning_samples: Dent's liability can be established under the theory of respondeat superior, which holds an employer or custodian liable for the actions of their employee or ward. However, for respondeat superior to apply, the custodian must have had knowledge or reason to know of the child's propensity for the type of harm caused. In this case, Dent became aware of Camden's absence and had reports that Camden was seen in the vicinity, but there is no indication that he had knowledge or reason to know of Camden's propensity to attack younger children. Therefore, option D is the best answer because it requires the most specific knowledge or reason to know of the child's propensity, which is the most stringent standard for liability.

question: Deetz was prosecuted for homicide. He testified that he shot in self-defense. In rebuttal, Officer Watts testified that he came to the scene in response to a telephone call from Deetz. Watts offers to testify that he asked, "What is the problem here, sir?" and Deetz replied, "I was cleaning my gun and it went off accidentally." The offered testimony is
choices: admissible, as an excited utterance.
admissible, to impeach Deetz and as evidence that he did not act in selfdefense.
inadmissible, because of Deetz's privilege against self-incrimination.
inadmissible, because it tends to exculpate without corroboration.
reasoning_samples: Deetz's statement to Officer Watts is an admission by a party-opponent and is admissible to impeach Deetz's testimony that he acted in self-defense. The statement is also admissible as evidence that Deetz did not act in self-defense, as it suggests that the shooting was accidental rather than intentional. The statement is not an excited utterance, as it was made in response to a question from Officer Watts rather than being a spontaneous statement made in response to a startling event. Additionally, the statement does not implicate Deetz's privilege against self-incrimination, as it was made in a non-custodial setting and was not compelled by the government. Finally, the statement is not inadmissible because it tends to exculpate without corroboration, as it is being offered to impeach Deetz's testimony rather than as substantive evidence of the shooting.

question: Landco owns and operates a 12-story apartment building containing 72 apartments, 70 of which are rented. Walker has brought an action against Landco alleging that while he was walking along a public sidewalk adjacent to Landco's apartment building a flower pot fell from above and struck him on the shoulder, causing extensive injuries. The action was to recover damages for those injuries. If Walker proves the foregoing facts and offers no other evidence explaining the accident, will his claim survive a motion for directed verdict offered by the defense?
choices: Yes, because Walker was injured by an artificial condition of the premises while using an adjacent public way.
Yes, because such an accident does not ordinarily happen in the absence of negligence.
No, if Landco is in no better position than Walker to explain the accident.
No, because there is no basis for a reasonable inference that Landco was negligent.
reasoning_samples: Walker's claim will survive a motion for directed verdict because he was injured by an artificial condition of the premises while using an adjacent public way. This is a key factor in establishing liability under premises liability law. The fact that Walker was walking on a public sidewalk adjacent to Landco's apartment building creates a duty on the part of Landco to ensure that its property does not pose a hazard to those in the adjacent public way. The fact that a flower pot fell from above and struck Walker on the shoulder suggests that the condition of the premises was not properly maintained, which is a breach of Landco's duty. Therefore, Walker's claim will survive a motion for directed verdict because he has established a prima facie case of premises liability.

question: At the time of his death last week, Test owned Blackacre, a small farm. By his duly probated will, drawn five years ago, Test did the following: (1) devised Blackacre "to Arthur for the life of Baker, then to Casper"; (2) gave "all the rest, residue and remainder of my Estate, both real and personal, to my friend Fanny." At his death, Test was survived by Arthur, Casper, Sonny (Test's son and sole heir), and Fanny. Baker had died a week before Test. Title to Blackacre is now inx
choices: Arthur for life, remainder to Casper.
Casper, in fee simple.
Sonny, in fee simple.
Fanny, in fee simple.
reasoning_samples: The will devises Blackacre 'to Arthur for the life of Baker, then to Casper.' Since Baker has died, Arthur's life estate is still in effect. The remainder interest, which is a vested remainder subject to open, now passes to Casper. Therefore, title to Blackacre is now in Arthur for life, remainder to Casper.

question: If Tower refuses to accept Copter's services, which of the following clauses in the GyroTower contract will best support Tower's contention that Gyro's duties under the contract were not delegable without Tower's consent?
prompt: Gyro, an expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings, contracted in a signed writing to lift and emplace certain air-conditioning equipment atop Tower's building. An exculpatory clause in the contract provided that Gyro would not be liable for any physical damage to Tower's building occurring during installation of the air-conditioning equipment. There was also a clause providing for per diem damages if Gyro did not complete performance by a specified date and a clause providing that "time is of the essence." Another clause provided that any subsequent agreement for extra work under the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties. With ample time remaining under the contract for commencement and completion of his performance, Gyro notified Tower that he was selling his business to Copter, who was equally expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings, and that Copter had agreed to "take over the Gyro-Tower contract."
choices: The exculpatory clause.
The liquidated-damage clause.
The "time is of the essence" clause.
The extra-work clause.
reasoning_samples: The exculpatory clause is the best support for Tower's contention that Gyro's duties under the contract were not delegable without Tower's consent. This is because the exculpatory clause specifically limits Gyro's liability for physical damage to Tower's building, which implies that Gyro is taking on a unique responsibility for that specific risk. By limiting Gyro's liability, the clause suggests that Gyro is not simply hiring a subcontractor to perform the work, but rather is personally guaranteeing the quality of the work. Therefore, if Gyro attempts to delegate his duties to Copter without Tower's consent, Tower can argue that Gyro is attempting to shift his unique responsibility to Copter, which would be inconsistent with the exculpatory clause. This clause is the best support for Tower's contention because it specifically addresses the issue of Gyro's liability and responsibility, which is at the heart of the delegation issue.

question: For this question only, assume that Tower orally agreed with Gyro to accept Copter's services and that Copter performed on time but negligently installed the wrong airconditioning equipment. Will Tower succeed in an action against Gyro for damages for breach of contract?
prompt: Gyro, an expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings, contracted in a signed writing to lift and emplace certain air-conditioning equipment atop Tower's building. An exculpatory clause in the contract provided that Gyro would not be liable for any physical damage to Tower's building occurring during installation of the air-conditioning equipment. There was also a clause providing for per diem damages if Gyro did not complete performance by a specified date and a clause providing that "time is of the essence." Another clause provided that any subsequent agreement for extra work under the contract must be in writing and signed by both parties. With ample time remaining under the contract for commencement and completion of his performance, Gyro notified Tower that he was selling his business to Copter, who was equally expert in lifting and emplacing equipment atop tall buildings, and that Copter had agreed to "take over the Gyro-Tower contract."
choices: Yes, because Tower did not agree to release Gyro from liability under the Gyro-Tower contract.
Yes, because Tower received no consideration for the substitution of Copter for Gyro.
No, because by accepting the substitution of Copter for Gyro, Tower effected a novation, and Gyro was thereby discharged of his duties under the GyroTower contract.
No, because the liquidated-damage clause in the Gyro-Tower contract provided only for damages caused by delay in performance.
reasoning_samples: Tower did not agree to release Gyro from liability under the Gyro-Tower contract. The novation argument in choice C is not supported because novation requires a new contract between the original obligor (Gyro), the original obligee (Tower), and the new obligor (Copter). Here, there is no new contract between Gyro and Tower, and Gyro is not released from liability. Choice D is incorrect because the liquidated-damage clause in the Gyro-Tower contract provided for per diem damages if Gyro did not complete performance by a specified date, not for damages caused by delay in performance. Choice A is incorrect because Tower did agree to accept Copter's services, which may be seen as a release of Gyro from liability. However, the key issue is that Tower received no consideration for the substitution of Copter for Gyro, which is a requirement for a valid release. Therefore, Tower's agreement to accept Copter's services is not a valid release of Gyro from liability, and Tower will succeed in an action against Gyro for damages for breach of contract.

question: Allen owned Greenacre in fee simple of record on January 10. On that day, Maria loaned Allen $50,000 and Allen mortgaged Greenacre to Maria as security for the loan. The mortgage was recorded on January 18. Allen conveyed Greenacre to Barnes for a valuable consideration on January 11. Maria did not know of this, nor did Barnes know of the mortgage to Maria, until both discovered the facts on January 23, the day on which Barnes recorded Allen's deed. The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: "No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record." There is no provision for a period of grace and there is no other relevant statutory provision. Maria sued Barnes to establish that her mortgage was good against Greenacre. The court should decide for
choices: Barnes, because he paid valuable consideration without notice before Maria recorded her mortgage.
Barnes, because Maria's delay in recording means that she is estopped from asserting her priority in time.
Maria, because Barnes did not record his deed before her mortgage was recorded.
Maria, because after the mortgage to her, Allen's deed to Barnes was necessarily subject to her mortgage.
reasoning_samples: The recording act of the jurisdiction provides: 'No unrecorded conveyance or mortgage of real property shall be good against subsequent purchasers for value without notice, who shall first record.' This provision indicates that a subsequent purchaser for value without notice will have priority over any prior unrecorded conveyance or mortgage. In this case, Barnes purchased Greenacre from Allen for valuable consideration without notice of Maria's mortgage. Although Maria's mortgage was recorded before Barnes recorded his deed, it was not recorded before Barnes purchased Greenacre, and he did not have notice of it. Therefore, the court should decide in favor of Barnes.

question: Park sued Dunlevy for copyright infringement for using in Dunlevy's book some slightly disguised house plans on which Park held the copyright. Park is prepared to testify that he heard Dunlevy's executive assistant for copyright matters say that Dunlevy had obtained an advance copy of the plans from Park's office manager. Park's testimony is
choices: admissible as reporting a statement of an employee of a party opponent.
admissible as a statement of a coconspirator.
inadmissible, because it is hearsay not within any exception.
inadmissible, because there is no showing that the assistant was authorized to speak for Dunlevy.
reasoning_samples: Park's testimony is admissible as a statement of an employee of a party opponent. This is because the statement is being offered against the party opponent (Dunlevy) and the declarant (Dunlevy's executive assistant) is an employee of that party opponent. Under Federal Rule of Evidence 801(d)(2)(D), a statement made by an agent or employee of a party opponent is not considered hearsay when offered against the party opponent. This exception allows Park's testimony to be admissible, as it is a statement of an employee of a party opponent, and it directly relates to the issue of whether Dunlevy obtained the plans from Park's office manager.

question: Congress enacted a statute providing grants of federal funds for the restoration and preservation of courthouses that were built before 1900 and are still in use. The statute contains an inseverable condition requiring that any courthouse restored with the aid of such a grant must be equipped with ramps and other facilities necessary to accommodate physically handicapped people. A law of the state of Blue requires public buildings in Blue to have ramps and other facilities for handicapped people. It exempts from those requirements any building that is more than 70 years old if the State Board of Architects finds that the installation of such facilities would destroy the architectural integrity of the building. The Red County Courthouse in the state of Blue was built in 1895 and is still in use. It does not contain ramps or other special facilities for handicapped people. The State Board of Architects has determined that the installation of those facilities would destroy the architectural integrity of the building. Nevertheless, the County Board of Red County applies for a federal grant to restore and preserve that county's courthouse. If the County Board of Red County restores the Red County Courthouse with the aid of a federal restoration and preservation grant, is the board bound to install ramps and other facilities for handicapped people in that building?
choices: Yes, because Congress may impose reasonable conditions related to the public welfare on grants of federal funds to public bodies when the public bodies are free to accept or reject the grants.
Yes, because the rights of handicapped and disabled people are fundamental rights that take precedence, as a constitutional matter, over considerations of architectural integrity.

No, because the Constitution does not authorize the federal government to direct the actions of the states or any of their political subdivisions with respect to matters affecting their own governmental buildings.
No, because any acceptance of this condition by the Red County Board of Supervisors would, as a matter of law, be considered to be under duress.
reasoning_samples: The federal government has the authority to impose conditions on grants of federal funds to public bodies when those bodies are free to accept or reject the grants. In this case, the Red County Board of Supervisors is free to accept or reject the federal grant, and by accepting it, they are implicitly agreeing to the conditions attached to the grant, including the requirement to install ramps and other facilities for handicapped people. This is a reasonable condition related to the public welfare, as it promotes accessibility and equality for physically handicapped individuals. The fact that the state of Blue has its own law requiring public buildings to have ramps and other facilities for handicapped people does not preclude the federal government from imposing a similar condition on a federal grant. Therefore, the County Board of Red County is bound to install ramps and other facilities for handicapped people in the Red County Courthouse if they accept the federal grant.

question: Arnold decided to destroy an old warehouse that he owned because the taxes on the structure exceeded the income that he could receive from it. He crept into the building in the middle of the night with a can of gasoline and a fuse and set the fuse timer for 30 minutes. He then left the building. The fuse failed to ignite, and the building was not harmed. Arson is defined in this jurisdiction as "The intentional burning of any building or structure of another, without the consent of the owner." Arnold believed, however, that burning one's own building was arson, having been so advised by his lawyer. Has Arnold committed attempted arson?
choices: Yes, because factual impossibility is no defense.
Yes, because a mistake of law even on the advice of an attorney is no defense.
No, because his mistake negated a necessary mental state.
No, because even if his actions had every consequence he intended, they would not have constituted arson.
reasoning_samples: To determine if Arnold committed attempted arson, we need to consider the elements of the crime. In this jurisdiction, arson is defined as 'The intentional burning of any building or structure of another, without the consent of the owner.' Since Arnold owned the warehouse, his actions were not directed at another's property. However, the question is whether he committed attempted arson. Attempted arson is the intentional act of doing something with the intent to commit arson, but failing to complete the act. In this case, Arnold's intention was to burn the building, and he took a substantial step toward completing that intention by setting the fuse. The fact that the fuse failed to ignite is irrelevant to the attempted arson charge. Therefore, the correct answer is A, because factual impossibility is no defense to attempted arson.

question: "Look-alike drugs" is the term used to describe nonprescription drugs that look like narcotic drugs and are sold on the streets as narcotic drugs. After extensive hearings, Congress concluded that the sale of look-alike drugs was widespread in this country and was creating severe health and law enforcement problems. To combat these problems, Congress enacted a comprehensive statute that regulates the manufacture, distribution, and sale of all nonprescription drugs in the United States. Which of the following sources of constitutional authority can most easily be used to justify the authority of Congress to enact this statute?
choices: The spending power.
The commerce clause.
The general welfare clause.
The enforcement powers of the Fourteenth Amendment.
reasoning_samples: The commerce clause (Article I, Section 8, Clause 3) grants Congress the power to regulate commerce among the states. The sale of look-alike drugs on the streets is a form of interstate commerce, as the drugs are being sold across state lines. Congress can regulate this activity under the commerce clause because it has a substantial effect on interstate commerce. The statute regulating the manufacture, distribution, and sale of nonprescription drugs is a valid exercise of Congress's power under the commerce clause. This is the most direct and relevant source of constitutional authority for Congress to enact this statute.

question: After several well-publicized deaths caused by fires in products made from highly flammable fabrics, the state of Orange enacted a statute prohibiting "the manufacture or assembly of any product in this state which contains any fabric that has not been tested and approved for flame retardancy by the Zetest Testing Company." The Zetest Testing Company is a privately owned and operated business located in Orange. For many years, Fabric Mill, located in the state of Orange, has had its fabric tested for flame retardancy by the Alpha Testing Company, located in the state of Green. Alpha Testing Company is a reliable organization that uses a process for testing and approving fabrics for flame retardancy identical in all respects to that used by the Zetest Testing Company. Because Fabric Mill wishes to continue to have its fabric tested solely by Alpha Testing Company, Fabric Mill files an action in Orange state court challenging the constitutionality of the Orange statute as applied to its circumstances. In this suit, the court should hold the statute to be
choices: constitutional, because it is reasonably related to the protection of the reputation of the fabric industry located in the state of Orange.
constitutional, because it is a legitimate means of protecting the safety of the public.
unconstitutional, because it denies to Fabric Mill the equal protection of the laws.
unconstitutional, because it imposes an unreasonable burden on interstate commerce.
reasoning_samples: The statute is a legitimate means of protecting the safety of the public. The state of Orange has a compelling interest in protecting its citizens from fires caused by highly flammable fabrics. The statute requires manufacturers to test and approve fabrics for flame retardancy, which is a reasonable means of achieving this goal. The fact that the Zetest Testing Company is a privately owned business does not render the statute unconstitutional, as the state is not favoring one business over another. The state is simply requiring that fabrics be tested by a company that meets certain standards. The statute does not violate the Equal Protection Clause or the Commerce Clause, as it is a legitimate exercise of the state's police power. Therefore, the statute is constitutional.

question: Decker, charged with armed robbery of a store, denied that he was the person who had robbed the store. In presenting the state's case, the prosecutor seeks to introduce evidence that Decker had robbed two other stores in the past year. This evidence is
choices: admissible, to prove a pertinent trait of Decker's character and Decker's action in conformity therewith.
admissible, to prove Decker's intent and identity.
inadmissible, because character must be proved by reputation or opinion and may not be proved by specific acts.
inadmissible, because its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.
reasoning_samples: The evidence of Decker's past robberies is admissible to prove his identity and intent. This is because the past robberies share a common characteristic with the current crime, namely the modus operandi (MO) of the robberies. The MO is a unique set of circumstances that defines the crime, and in this case, the past robberies have a similar MO to the current crime. The jury can infer that the same person committed the crimes based on the similarities in the MO. This is an exception to the general rule that character evidence is not admissible to prove a person's conduct on a particular occasion. The probative value of the evidence outweighs the potential prejudice, as it is directly relevant to the issue of identity and intent.

question: Mom owned Blackacre, a two-family apartment house on a small city lot not suitable for partition-in-kind. Upon Mom's death, her will devised Blackacre to "my sons, Joe and John." A week ago, Ken obtained a money judgment against Joe, and properly filed the judgment in the county where Blackacre is located. A statute in the jurisdiction provides: any judgment properly filed shall, for ten years from filing, be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered. Joe needed cash, but John did not wish to sell Blackacre. Joe commenced a partition action against John and Ken. Assume that the court properly ordered a partition by judicial sale. After the sale, Ken's judgment will be a lien on
choices: all of Blackacre.
only a one-half interest in Blackacre.
all of the proceeds of sale of Blackacre.
only the portion of the proceeds of sale due Joe.
reasoning_samples: The statute in question provides that a judgment properly filed shall be a lien on the real property then owned or subsequently acquired by any person against whom the judgment is rendered. Since the judgment was filed against Joe, and the property was sold as a result of a partition action, the lien will attach to the proceeds of the sale of Blackacre. This is because the proceeds of the sale are considered the 'real property' that was sold, and the lien will follow the property as it changes hands. Therefore, Ken's judgment will be a lien on all of the proceeds of the sale of Blackacre.

question: Suspecting that Scott had slain his wife, police detectives persuaded one of Scott's employees to remove a drinking glass from Scott's office so that it could be used for fingerprint comparisons with a knife found near the body. The fingerprints matched. The prosecutor announced that he would present comparisons and evidence to the grand jury. Scott's lawyer immediately filed a motion to suppress the evidence of the fingerprint comparisons to bar its consideration by the grand jury, contending that the evidence was illegally acquired. The motion should be
choices: granted, because, if there was no probable cause, the grand jury should not consider the evidence.
granted, because the employee was acting as a police agent and his seizure of the glass without a warrant was unconstitutional.
denied, because motions based on the exclusionary rule are premature in grand jury proceedings.
denied, because the glass was removed from Scott's possession by a private citizen and not a police officer.
reasoning_samples: The motion to suppress should be denied because motions based on the exclusionary rule are generally premature in grand jury proceedings. The exclusionary rule is a remedy for Fourth Amendment violations, and its application is typically limited to trials. In grand jury proceedings, the focus is on determining whether there is probable cause to indict, rather than on the admissibility of evidence. Therefore, the court should deny the motion to suppress and allow the grand jury to consider the evidence, as the issue of admissibility can be addressed later in the trial process.

question: Adam entered into a valid written contract to sell Blackacre, a large tract of land, to Betsy. At that time, Blackacre was owned by Adam's father, Fred; Adam had no title to Blackacre and was not the agent of Fred. After the contract was executed and before the scheduled closing date, Fred died intestate, leaving Adam as his sole heir. Shortly thereafter, Adam received an offer for Blackacre that was substantially higher than the purchase price in the contract with Betsy. Adam refused to close with Betsy although she was ready, willing, and able to close pursuant to the contract. Betsy brought an appropriate action for specific performance against Adam. In that action, Betsy should be awarded
choices: nothing, because Adam had no authority to enter into the contract with Betsy.
nothing, because the doctrine of afteracquired title does not apply to executory contracts.
judgment for specific performance, because Adam acquired title prior to the scheduled closing.
judgment for specific performance, to prevent unjust enrichment of Adam.
reasoning_samples: Adam had no authority to enter into the contract with Betsy. At the time of contracting, Adam was not the owner of Blackacre and was not acting as an agent for Fred. Therefore, Adam had no capacity to bind himself to the contract. Since the contract was entered into without authority, it is voidable at the option of the party who did not have authority. In this case, Betsy did not have authority, but Adam's actions are the ones being scrutinized. As such, the contract is voidable at Adam's option and thus unenforceable against him. Therefore, Betsy should be awarded nothing.

question: Dayton operates a collection agency. He was trying to collect a $400 bill for medical services rendered to Pratt by Doctor. Dayton went to Pratt's house and when Martina, Pratt's mother, answered the door, Dayton told Martina he was there to collect a bill owed by Pratt. Martina told Dayton that because of her illness, Pratt had been unemployed for six months, that she was still ill and unable to work, and that she would pay the bill as soon as she could. Dayton, in a loud voice, demanded to see Pratt and said that if he did not receive payment immediately, he would file a criminal complaint charging her with fraud. Pratt, hearing the conversation, came to the door. Dayton, in a loud voice, repeated his demand for immediate payment and his threat to use criminal process. If Pratt asserts a claim against Dayton, based on infliction of emotional distress, will Pratt prevail?
choices: Yes, if Pratt suffered severe emotional distress as a result of Dayton's conduct.
Yes, unless the bill for medical services was valid and past due.
No, unless Pratt suffered physical harm as a result of Dayton's conduct.
No, if Dayton's conduct created no risk of physical harm to Pratt.
reasoning_samples: To determine if Pratt will prevail in her claim against Dayton for infliction of emotional distress, we must consider the elements of this tort. Infliction of emotional distress is typically a claim for intentional or reckless conduct that causes severe emotional distress in another person. In this scenario, Dayton's loud and threatening behavior, including his demand for immediate payment and his threat to use criminal process, can be seen as intentional and reckless conduct. The question then becomes whether Pratt suffered severe emotional distress as a result of Dayton's conduct. While the facts do not provide explicit details about the extent of Pratt's emotional distress, the scenario suggests that she was subjected to a significant level of stress and anxiety. Therefore, if Pratt suffered severe emotional distress as a result of Dayton's conduct, she will prevail in her claim against him. This is because the key element of severe emotional distress is present, and the other elements of the tort are also met. Choice A is the best answer because it accurately reflects the elements of infliction of emotional distress and the facts of the scenario.

question: Public schools in the state of Green are financed, in large part, by revenue derived from real estate taxes imposed by each school district on the taxable real property located in that district. Public schools also receive other revenue from private gifts, federal grants, student fees, and local sales taxes. For many years, Green has distributed additional funds, which come from the state treasury, to local school districts in order to equalize the funds available on a per-student basis for each public school district. These additional funds are distributed on the basis of a state statutory formula that considers only the number of students in each public school district and the real estate tax revenue raised by that district. The formula does not consider other revenue received by a school district from different sources. The school boards of two school districts, together with parents and schoolchildren in those districts, bring suit in federal court to enjoin the state from allocating the additional funds from the state treasury to individual districts pursuant to this formula. They allege that the failure of the state, in allocating this additional money, to take into account a school district's sources of revenue other than revenue derived from taxes levied on real estate located there violates the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The complaint does not allege that the allocation of the additional state funds based on the current statutory formula has resulted in a failure to provide minimally adequate education to any child. Which of the following best describes the appropriate standard by which the court should review the constitutionality of the state statutory funding formula?
choices: Because classifications based on wealth are inherently suspect, the state must demonstrate that the statutory formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest.
Because the statutory funding formula burdens the fundamental right to education, the state must demonstrate that the formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest.

Because no fundamental right or suspect classification is implicated in this case, the plaintiffs must demonstrate that the funding allocation formula bears no rational relationship to any legitimate state interest.

Because the funding formula inevitably leads to disparities among the school districts in their levels of total funding, the plaintiffs must only demonstrate that the funding formula is not substantially related to the furtherance of an important state interest.
reasoning_samples: The correct answer is A because the court should apply strict scrutiny, which requires the state to demonstrate that the statutory formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest. This is because classifications based on wealth are inherently suspect and trigger strict scrutiny. While the plaintiffs do not allege that the allocation of the additional state funds based on the current statutory formula has resulted in a failure to provide minimally adequate education to any child, this does not necessarily mean that the classification is not suspect. The wealth-based classification is inherently suspect, and the state must demonstrate that the statutory formula is necessary to vindicate a compelling state interest. A rational basis review (option C) is not applicable because the plaintiffs have challenged a wealth-based classification, and a heightened scrutiny standard is necessary. Option D is incorrect because it misstates the applicable standard. Option B is incorrect because the right to education is not a fundamental right, and the court does not need to apply strict scrutiny.

question: A car driven by Dan entered land owned by and in the possession of Peter, without Peter's permission. Which, if any, of the following allegations, without additional facts, would provide a sufficient basis for a claim by Peter against Dan? I. Dan intentionally drove his car onto Peter's land. II. Dan negligently drove his car onto Peter's land. III. Dan's car damaged Peter's land.
choices: I only.
III only.
I, II, or III.
Neither I, nor II, nor III.
reasoning_samples: To determine which allegations would provide a sufficient basis for a claim by Peter against Dan, we must consider the tort of trespass to chattels and trespass to land. Trespass to land involves unauthorized entry onto someone else's property, which is a tort. Trespass to chattels involves unauthorized use or interference with someone else's personal property. However, there is no mention of Dan using or interfering with Peter's personal property. Therefore, allegations I and II, which involve Dan's intentional and negligent actions, respectively, would be sufficient to establish trespass to land. Allegation III, however, does not provide a sufficient basis for a claim, as the damage to Peter's land is only a consequence of the initial trespass. Hence, the best answer is A.

question: In which of the following cases is Morrow most likely to be convicted if she is charged with receiving stolen property?
choices: Morrow bought a car from Aster, who operates a used car lot. Before the purchase, Aster told Morrow that the car had been stolen, which was true. Unknown to Morrow, Aster is an undercover police agent who is operating the lot in cooperation with the police in exchange for leniency in connection with criminal charges pending against him.

Morrow bought a car from Ball. Before the purchase, Ball told Morrow that the car was stolen. Ball had stolen the car with the help of Eames, who, unknown to Morrow or Ball, was an undercover police agent who feigned cooperation with Ball in the theft of the car.

Morrow bought a car from Cooper. Before the purchase, Cooper told Morrow that the car was stolen. Unknown to Morrow, Cooper had stolen the car from a parking lot and had been caught by the police as he was driving it away. He agreed to cooperate with the police and carry through with his prearranged sale of the car to Morrow.

Morrow bought a car from Dixon. Before the purchase, Dixon told Morrow that the car was stolen. Unknown to Morrow, Dixon was in fact the owner of the car but had reported it to the police as stolen and had collected on a fraudulent claim of its theft from his insurance company.
reasoning_samples: In option A, Morrow is most likely to be convicted because she knowingly purchased a stolen car from Aster, who is an undercover police agent. Although Aster's cooperation with the police may have been in exchange for leniency, it does not negate the fact that Morrow was aware that the car was stolen when she purchased it. This is a clear case of receiving stolen property, which is a crime. In contrast, the other options either involve ignorance of the car's true ownership (B and C) or a legitimate claim of ownership (D), which would make it more difficult to convict Morrow of receiving stolen property.

question: Leaseco owned Blackacre, a tract of 100 acres. Six years ago, Leaseco leased a one-acre parcel, Oneacre, located in the northeasterly corner of Blackacre, for a term of 30 years, to Eatco. Eatco intended to and did construct a fast-food restaurant on Oneacre. The lease provided that: 1. Eatco was to maintain Oneacre and improvements thereon, to maintain full insurance coverage on Oneacre, and to pay all taxes assessed against Oneacre. 2. Leaseco was to maintain the access roads and the parking lot areas platted on those portions of Blackacre that adjoined Oneacre and to permit the customers of Eatco to use them in common with the customers of the other commercial users of the remainder of Blackacre. 3. Eatco was to pay its share of the expenses for the off-site improvements according to a stated formula. Five years ago, Leaseco sold Oneacre to Jones, an investor; the conveyance was made subject to the lease to Eatco. However, Jones did not assume the obligations of the lease and Leaseco retained the remainder of Blackacre. Since that conveyance five years ago, Eatco has paid rent to Jones. Eatco refused to pay its formula share of the off-site improvement costs as provided in the lease. Leaseco brought an appropriate action against Eatco to recover such costs. The most likely outcome would be in favor of
choices: Leaseco, because the use of the improvements by the customers of Eatco imposes an implied obligation on Eatco.
Leaseco, because the conveyance of Oneacre to Jones did not terminate Eatco's covenant to contribute.
Eatco, because the conveyance of Oneacre to Jones terminated the privity of estate between Leaseco and Eatco.
Eatco, because Jones, as Eatco's landlord, has the obligation to pay the maintenance costs by necessary implication.
reasoning_samples: The conveyance of Oneacre to Jones did not terminate Eatco's covenant to contribute to the off-site improvement costs because the lease agreement specifically provides that such costs are to be paid according to a stated formula, which is a personal covenant, not a real covenant. Personal covenants (also known as equitable servitudes) are enforceable against the original parties to the covenant and their heirs and assigns, not against subsequent grantees like Jones. Since Jones did not assume the lease, Eatco continues to be bound by the personal covenant to contribute to the off-site improvements.

question: While Patty was riding her horse on what she thought was a public path, the owner of a house next to the path approached her, shaking a stick and shouting, "Get off my property." Unknown to Patty, the path on which she was riding crossed the private property of the shouting owner. When Patty explained that she thought the path was a public trail, the man cursed her, approached Patty's horse, and struck the horse with the stick. As a result of the blow, the horse reared, causing Patty to fear that she would fall. However, Patty managed to stay on the horse, and then departed. Neither Patty nor the horse suffered bodily harm. If Patty brings an action for damages against the property owner, the result should be for
choices: Patty, for trespass to her chattel property.
Patty, for battery and assault.
the defendant, because Patty suffered no physical harm.
the defendant, because he was privileged to exclude trespassers from his property.
reasoning_samples: Patty's horse was a chattel, and the property owner intentionally struck it with a stick. This constitutes trespass to chattel, which is a tort that protects personal property from intentional interference. The fact that Patty was able to stay on the horse does not negate the property owner's liability, as trespass to chattel does not require actual damage to the property. The other options are incorrect because battery and assault require physical contact or a credible threat of physical contact, which is not present in this scenario, and the property owner's privilege to exclude trespassers does not extend to using force to do so.

question: Five years ago, Sally acquired Blackacre, improved with a 15-year-old dwelling. This year Sally listed Blackacre for sale with Bill, a licensed real estate broker. Sally informed Bill of several defects in the house that were not readily discoverable by a reasonable inspection, including a leaky basement, an inadequate water supply, and a roof that leaked. Paul responded to Bill's advertisement, was taken by Bill to view Blackacre, and decided to buy it. Bill saw to it that the contract specified the property to be "as is" but neither Bill nor Sally pointed out the defects to Paul, who did not ask about the condition of the dwelling. After closing and taking possession, Paul discovered the defects, had them repaired, and demanded that Sally reimburse him for the cost of the repairs. Sally refused and Paul brought an appropriate action against Sally for damages. If Sally wins, it will be because
choices: Sally fulfilled the duty to disclose defects by disclosure to Bill.
the contract's "as is" provision controls the rights of the parties.
Bill became the agent of both Paul and Sally and thus knowledge of the defects was imputed to Paul.
the seller of a used dwelling that has been viewed by the buyer has no responsibility toward the buyer.
reasoning_samples: Sally's duty to disclose defects is fulfilled if she discloses the information to a licensed real estate broker, in this case Bill. As a licensed broker, Bill has a duty to disclose the information to potential buyers, including Paul. Since Bill did not disclose the defects to Paul, Sally's disclosure to Bill is sufficient to fulfill her duty. This is based on the principle that a seller's duty to disclose defects can be fulfilled by disclosure to a licensed real estate broker, who then has a duty to disclose the information to potential buyers.

question: In which of the following situations would a court applying common-law doctrine be most likely to convict Defendant of the crime charged, despite Defendant's mistake?
choices: Defendant was charged with bigamy. He married his neighbor four years after her husband was reported missing at sea. The rescued husband returns alive. A state statute provides that a person is presumed dead after five years of unexplained absence. Defendant believed the statutory period was three years.

Defendant was charged with murder after he shot and killed a man who had extorted money from him. Defendant mistakenly thought the victim had raised his hand to shoot, when, in fact, the victim was shaking his fist at Defendant to frighten him.
Defendant was charged with assault with intent to rape a woman who he mistakenly believed had agreed to have sexual intercourse with him.
Defendant was charged with burglary. He had broken into an office where he once worked and had taken a typewriter that he erroneously believed had been given to him before he was fired.
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, Defendant's mistake is not about the existence of a fact, but rather his misunderstanding of the statutory period. The common-law doctrine of mistake of law generally does not provide a defense to a crime. However, in this case, the statute itself provides a presumption of death after five years of unexplained absence. If Defendant had relied on this statutory presumption, he would have been justified in believing the husband was dead. Since the statute is the source of the mistake, it is more likely that the court would convict Defendant of bigamy, despite his mistake, as the mistake is based on a misunderstanding of the law rather than a mistake of fact.

question: Assuming that there is no controlling statute, is the April 1 agreement an effective defense for Spender?
prompt: Spender owed Midas $1,000, plus interest at 8% until paid, on a long-overdue promissory note, collection of which would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30. On the preceding April 1, Spender and Midas both signed a writing in which Spender promised to pay the note in full on the following December 31, plus interest at 8% until that date, and Midas promised not to sue on the note in the meantime. Midas, having received some advice from his nonlawyer brother-in-law, became concerned about the legal effect of the April 1 agreement. On May 1, acting pro se as permitted by the rules of the local small claims court, he filed suit to collect the note.
choices: Yes, because Spender's promise to pay interest until December 31 was consideration for Midas's promise not to sue.
Yes, because the law creates a presumption that Spender relied on Midas's promise not to sue.
No, because there was no consideration for Midas's promise not to sue, in that Spender was already obligated to pay $1,000 plus interest at 8% until the payment date.
No, because Spender's April 1 promise is enforceable with or without consideration.
reasoning_samples: A is the correct answer because the April 1 agreement is enforceable as a contract. To be enforceable, a contract must have consideration. In this case, Spender's promise to pay interest until December 31 was consideration for Midas's promise not to sue. This is because Spender's promise gave Midas something he did not already have - an extension of the payment deadline and the promise to pay interest until that date. Without this consideration, Midas would not have been bound by the promise to not sue, which would otherwise be a gratuitous promise. Therefore, Spender's promise to pay interest until December 31 was sufficient consideration to support the April 1 agreement, making it an effective defense against Midas's claim.

question: For this question only, assume that on January 2 of the following year Midas's suit has not come to trial, Spender has not paid the note, Midas has retained a lawyer, and the lawyer, with leave of court, amends the complaint to add a second count to enforce the promise Spender made in the April 1 agreement. Does the new count state a claim upon which relief can be granted?
prompt: Spender owed Midas $1,000, plus interest at 8% until paid, on a long-overdue promissory note, collection of which would become barred by the statute of limitations on June 30. On the preceding April 1, Spender and Midas both signed a writing in which Spender promised to pay the note in full on the following December 31, plus interest at 8% until that date, and Midas promised not to sue on the note in the meantime. Midas, having received some advice from his nonlawyer brother-in-law, became concerned about the legal effect of the April 1 agreement. On May 1, acting pro se as permitted by the rules of the local small claims court, he filed suit to collect the note.
choices: Yes, because Spender's failure to pay the note, plus interest, on December 31 makes Midas's breach of promise not to sue before that date no longer material.
Yes, because Spender's April 1 promise is enforceable by reason of his moral obligation to pay the debt.
No, because such relief would undermine the policy of the statute of limitations against enforcement of stale claims.
No, because Spender's April 1 promise was lawfully conditioned upon Midas's forbearing to sue prior to December 31.
reasoning_samples: The new count states a claim upon which relief can be granted because Spender's failure to pay the note on December 31 constitutes a breach of his promise to do so. This breach of promise makes Midas's forbearance from suing prior to December 31 no longer material. The April 1 agreement was a valid consideration for the promise not to sue, and Spender's failure to fulfill his end of the bargain renders the agreement enforceable. This is because a promise to forbear from suing is sufficient consideration to support a promise to pay a debt, and Spender's failure to pay the debt on the agreed-upon date constitutes a breach of that promise.

question: Which of the following acts by the United States Senate would be constitutionally IMPROPER?
choices: The Senate decides, with the House of Representatives, that a disputed state ratification of a proposed constitutional amendment is valid.
The Senate determines the eligibility of a person to serve as a senator.
The Senate appoints a commission to adjudicate finally a boundary dispute between two states.
The Senate passes a resolution calling on the President to pursue a certain foreign policy.
reasoning_samples: The Senate's power to advise and consent on presidential appointments, including Supreme Court justices, ambassadors, and federal judges, is explicitly stated in Article II, Section 2 of the US Constitution. However, the Constitution does not grant the Senate the authority to adjudicate finally a boundary dispute between two states. This power is typically reserved for the judicial branch, specifically the Supreme Court, as stated in Article III, Section 2. Therefore, the Senate's appointment of a commission to adjudicate a boundary dispute would be an improper exercise of its powers.

question: Pater and his adult daughter, Carmen, encountered Tertius, an old family friend, on the street. Carmen said to Tertius, "How about lending me $1,000 to buy a used car? I'll pay you back with interest one year from today." Pater added, "And if she doesn't pay it back as promised, I will." Tertius thereupon wrote out and handed to Carmen his personal check, payable to her, for $1,000, and Carmen subsequently used the funds to buy a used car. When the debt became due, both Carmen and Pater refused to repay it, or any part of it. In an action by Tertius against Pater to recover $1,000 plus interest, which of the following statements would summarize Pater's best defense?
choices: He received no consideration for his conditional promise to Tertius.
His conditional promise to Tertius was not to be performed in less than a year from the time it was made.
His conditional promise to Tertius was not made for the primary purpose of benefiting himself (Pater).
The loan by Tertius was made without any agreement concerning the applicable interest rate.
reasoning_samples: Pater's best defense is that he received no consideration for his conditional promise to Tertius. This is because Carmen's promise to repay the loan with interest was not supported by consideration, as she was already obligated to repay the loan. Pater's promise to repay the loan if Carmen did not was also not supported by consideration, as it was a secondary obligation that did not provide any additional benefit to Tertius. Therefore, Pater's promise to repay the loan is unenforceable for lack of consideration.

question: In litigation on a federal claim, Plaintiff had the burden of proving that Defendant received a notice. Plaintiff relied on the presumption of receipt by offering evidence that the notice was addressed to Defendant, properly stamped, and mailed. Defendant, on the other hand, testified that she never received the notice. Which of the following is correct?
choices: The jury must find that the notice was received.
The jury may find that the notice was received.
The burden shifts to Defendant to persuade the jury of nonreceipt.
The jury must find that the notice was not received, because the presumption has been rebutted and there is uncontradicted evidence of nonreceipt.
reasoning_samples: When a presumption is raised, the burden of production shifts to the party against whom the presumption is directed (in this case, Defendant) to rebut the presumption. However, the burden of persuasion remains with the party that raised the presumption (in this case, Plaintiff). Defendant's testimony that she never received the notice is sufficient to rebut the presumption, but it does not shift the burden of persuasion to Defendant. Therefore, the jury may find that the notice was received, but it is not required to do so. This is consistent with the general principle that a presumption is a permissive inference, not a mandatory one.

question: In a medical malpractice suit by Payne against Dr. Dock, Payne seeks to introduce a properly authenticated photocopy of Payne's hospital chart. The chart contained a notation made by a medical resident that an aortic clamp had broken during Payne's surgery. The resident made the notation in the regular course of practice, but had no personal knowledge of the operation, and cannot remember which of the operating physicians gave him the information. The document is
choices: admissible as a record of regularly conducted activity.
admissible as recorded recollection.
inadmissible as a violation of the best evidence rule.
inadmissible, because it is hearsay within hearsay.
reasoning_samples: The notation in the hospital chart is admissible as a record of regularly conducted activity under Federal Rule of Evidence 803(6). This rule allows for the admission of records that are kept in the regular course of a business, organization, or activity, and are made at or near the time by, or from information transmitted by, a person with knowledge. In this case, the notation was made by a medical resident in the regular course of practice, even though he did not have personal knowledge of the operation. The resident's lack of personal knowledge does not affect the admissibility of the notation, as the rule focuses on the regularity of the activity and the proximity of the notation to the event, rather than the knowledge of the person making the notation. Therefore, option A is the best answer.

question: Parr sued Davis for damages for physical injuries allegedly caused by Davis's violation of the federal civil rights law. The incident occurred wholly within the state of Chippewa but the case was tried in federal court. The Chippewa state code says, "The common-law privileges are preserved intact in this state." At trial, Davis called Dr. Webb, Parr's physician, to testify to confidential statements made to him by Parr in furtherance of medical treatment for the injuries allegedly caused by Davis. Parr objects, claiming a physicianpatient privilege. The court should apply
choices: state law and recognize the claim of privilege.
federal law and recognize the claim of privilege.
state law and reject the claim of privilege.
federal law and reject the claim of privilege.
reasoning_samples: The case was tried in federal court, but the incident occurred wholly within the state of Chippewa. Since the incident occurred in state, the state's common law, including the physician-patient privilege, should be applied. The Chippewa state code explicitly preserves common-law privileges intact. Therefore, the court should apply state law and recognize the claim of privilege.

question: Kathy, a two-year-old, became ill with meningitis. Jim and Joan, her parents, were members of a group that believed fervently that if they prayed enough, God would not permit their child to die. Accordingly, they did not seek medical aid for Kathy and refused all offers of such aid. They prayed continuously. Kathy died of the illness within a week. Jim and Joan are charged with murder in a common-law jurisdiction. Their best defense to the charge is that
choices: they did not intend to kill or to harm Kathy.
they were pursuing a constitutionally protected religious belief.
Kathy's death was not proximately caused by their conduct.
they neither premeditated nor deliberated.
reasoning_samples: In a common-law jurisdiction, the charge of murder requires proof of malice aforethought. Malice aforethought can be established through intent to kill, intent to cause serious bodily harm, or a depraved heart. In this case, Jim and Joan's actions demonstrate a reckless disregard for Kathy's well-being, as they refused medical aid despite knowing she was ill. However, their motivation for doing so - a fervent belief in prayer - does not necessarily imply an intent to kill. Their best defense is to argue that they did not intend to kill or harm Kathy, which aligns with the mens rea requirement for murder. This defense is more plausible than arguing that their religious beliefs are constitutionally protected (B), as the court may not consider their actions justified by their faith. Option C is incorrect because the death was indeed proximately caused by their conduct. Option D is also incorrect because the question is focused on the mens rea element, not the premeditation or deliberation element.

question: In a prosecution of Dahle for assault, Wharton is called to testify that the victim, Valerian, had complained to Wharton that Dahle was the assailant. Wharton's testimony is most likely to be admitted if Wharton is
choices: a doctor, whom Valerian consulted for treatment.
a minister, whom Valerian consulted for counseling.
Valerian's husband, whom she telephoned immediately after the event.
a police officer, whom Valerian called on instructions from her husband.
reasoning_samples: To determine the admissibility of Wharton's testimony, we need to consider the hearsay rule. Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted. In this case, Wharton is testifying about Valerian's statement that Dahle was the assailant. This would be hearsay, but it's a statement made for medical treatment. Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, a statement made for medical treatment is an exception to the hearsay rule (Fed. R. Evid. ยง 803(4)). Therefore, Wharton's testimony is most likely to be admitted if he is a doctor, whom Valerian consulted for treatment.

question: On January 15, Geetus is entitled to a judgment against Bower for which of the following amounts?
prompt: Betty Bower, an adult, asked Jeff Geetus to lend her $1,000. Geetus replied that he would do so only if Bower's father, Cash, would guarantee the loan. At Bower's request, Cash mailed a signed letter to Geetus: "If you lend $1,000 to my daughter, I will repay it if she doesn't." On September 15, Geetus, having read Cash's letter, lent $1,000 to Bower, which Bower agreed to repay in installments of $100 plus accrued interest on the last day of each month beginning October 31. Cash died on September 16. Later that same day, unaware of Cash's death, Geetus mailed a letter to Cash advising that he had made the $1,000 loan to Bower on September 15. Bower did not pay the installments due on October 31, November 30, or December 31, and has informed Geetus that she will be unable to make repayments in the foreseeable future.
choices: Nothing, because if he sues before the entire amount is due, he will be splitting his cause of action.
$300 plus the accrued interest, because Bower's breach is only a partial breach.
$1,000 plus the accrued interest, because Bower's unexcused failure to pay three installments is a material breach.
$1,000 plus the accrued interest, because the failure to pay her debts as they come due indicates that Bower is insolvent and Geetus is thereby entitled to accelerate payment of the debt.
reasoning_samples: In this scenario, Geetus's cause of action against Bower is for breach of contract due to non-payment of installments. However, Bower was only obligated to make payments as they came due, with the first installment due on October 31. Since Geetus has not yet reached the point where the entire amount is due, he should wait until the entire amount is due before bringing suit. Splitting his cause of action is a doctrine aimed at preventing piecemeal litigation and avoiding the risk of inconsistent judgments. This doctrine is applicable here, because Geetus is not yet entitled to full payment of the debt, and thus, he should not be able to bring suit for the full amount. Therefore, Bower cannot be held liable for the entire debt at this stage.

question: For this question only, assume that Bower's entire $1,000 debt is due and that she has failed to repay any part of it. In an action by Geetus against Cash's estate for $1,000 plus accrued interest, which of the following, if any, will serve as (an) effective defense(s) for Cash's estate? I. There was no consideration to support Cash's promise, because he did not receive any benefit. II. Cash died before Geetus accepted his offer. III. Cash died before Geetus notified him that his offer had been accepted.
prompt: Betty Bower, an adult, asked Jeff Geetus to lend her $1,000. Geetus replied that he would do so only if Bower's father, Cash, would guarantee the loan. At Bower's request, Cash mailed a signed letter to Geetus: "If you lend $1,000 to my daughter, I will repay it if she doesn't." On September 15, Geetus, having read Cash's letter, lent $1,000 to Bower, which Bower agreed to repay in installments of $100 plus accrued interest on the last day of each month beginning October 31. Cash died on September 16. Later that same day, unaware of Cash's death, Geetus mailed a letter to Cash advising that he had made the $1,000 loan to Bower on September 15. Bower did not pay the installments due on October 31, November 30, or December 31, and has informed Geetus that she will be unable to make repayments in the foreseeable future.
choices: I only.
II only.
I and III only.
Neither I nor II nor III.
reasoning_samples: Option I is incorrect because consideration is not required for a suretyship agreement. A surety is one who promises to pay the debt of another if the other fails to do so. In this case, Cash's promise to repay the debt if Bower fails to do so is a suretyship agreement. Since Cash's promise is a suretyship agreement, consideration is not required. Option II is incorrect because the offer was accepted when Geetus lent the money to Bower on September 15, which was before Cash's death. Option III is also incorrect because the notification of acceptance is not required for a valid contract. The contract was formed when Geetus lent the money to Bower, and Cash's promise was a suretyship agreement that did not require consideration. Therefore, neither I, II, nor III is an effective defense for Cash's estate.

question: The Federal Family Film Enhancement Act assesses an excise tax of 10% on the price of admission to public movie theaters when they show films that contain actual or simulated scenes of human sexual intercourse. Which of the following is the strongest argument against the constitutionality of this federal act?
choices: The act imposes a prior restraint on the freedom of speech protected by the First Amendment.
The act is not rationally related to any legitimate national interest.

The act violates the equal protection concepts embodied in the due process clause of the Fifth Amendment because it imposes a tax on the price of admission to view certain films and not on the price of admission to view comparable live performances.
The act imposes a tax solely on the basis of the content of speech without adequate justification and, therefore, it is prohibited by the freedom of speech clause of the First Amendment.
reasoning_samples: The strongest argument against the constitutionality of the Federal Family Film Enhancement Act is that it imposes a tax solely on the basis of the content of speech without adequate justification. This is a direct infringement on the freedom of speech clause of the First Amendment. The act specifically targets films containing actual or simulated scenes of human sexual intercourse, which is a form of expression protected by the First Amendment. The government must have a compelling interest to restrict speech, and a tax on the content of speech is not a permissible restriction. Therefore, option D is the strongest argument against the constitutionality of the act.

question: As a result of an accident at the NPP nuclear power plant, a quantity of radioactive vapor escaped from the facility and two members of the public were exposed to excessive doses of radiation. According to qualified medical opinion, that exposure will double the chance that these two persons will ultimately develop cancer. However, any cancer that might be caused by this exposure will not be detectable for at least ten years. If the two exposed persons do develop cancer, it will not be possible to determine whether it was caused by this exposure or would have developed in any event. If the exposed persons assert a claim for damages against NPP shortly after the escape of the radiation, which of the following questions will NOT present a substantial issue?
choices: Will the court recognize that the plaintiffs have suffered a present legal injury?
Can the plaintiffs prove the amount of their damages?
Can the plaintiffs prove that any harm they may suffer was caused by this exposure?
Can the plaintiffs prevail without presenting evidence of specific negligence on the part of NPP?
reasoning_samples: The question asks which issue will NOT present a substantial issue. The other options (B, C, and D) all present potential problems for the plaintiffs. However, the issue of whether the court will recognize that the plaintiffs have suffered a present legal injury (A) is not a substantial issue in this case. The plaintiffs have been exposed to excessive radiation, which has doubled their chance of developing cancer. This is a present legal injury, as it is an immediate and direct result of the defendant's actions. The fact that the cancer may not be detectable for ten years or that it may not be possible to determine whether it was caused by the exposure does not change the fact that the plaintiffs have suffered a present legal injury. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

question: A city ordinance makes the city building inspector responsible for ensuring that all buildings in that city are kept up to building code standards, and requires the inspector to refer for prosecution all known building code violations. Another ordinance provides that the city building inspector may be discharged for "good cause." The building inspector took a newspaper reporter through a number of rundown buildings in a slum neighborhood. After using various epithets and slurs to describe the occupants of these buildings, the building inspector stated to the reporter: "I do not even try to get these buildings up to code or to have their owners prosecuted for code violations because if these buildings are repaired, the people who live in them will just wreck them again."
